description: Rick Guidotti is a fashion photographer with a passion project: finding and sharing the beauty of kids with albinism and other conditions that affect their physical appearance -- and the way society treats them. At TEDxPhoenix, he shares some of their stories and the empowering effects of a little glamour as he redefines their beauty in a flash.
name: Rick Guidotti: From stigma to supermodel
title_vid: From stigma to supermodel

title_talk: Stacey Kramer: The best gift I ever survived
description: Stacey Kramer offers a moving, personal, 3-minute parable that shows how an unwanted experience -- frightening, traumatic, costly -- can turn out to be a priceless gift.
name: Stacey Kramer: The best gift I ever survived
title_vid: The best gift I ever survived

title_talk: A simple birth kit for mothers in the developing world | Zubaida Bai
description: TED Fellow Zubaida Bai works with medical professionals, midwives and mothers to bring dignity and low-cost interventions to women's health care. In this quick, inspiring talk, she presents her clean birth kit in a purse, which contains everything a new mother needs for a hygienic birth and a healthy delivery -- no matter where in the world (or how far from a medical clinic) she might be.
name: Zubaida Bai: A simple birth kit for mothers in the developing world
title_vid: A simple birth kit for mothers in the developing world

title_talk: The career advice you probably didn't get | Susan Colantuono
description: You’re doing everything right at work, taking all the right advice, but you’re just not moving up. Why? Susan Colantuono shares a simple, surprising piece of advice you might not have heard before quite so plainly. This talk, while aimed at an audience of women, has universal takeaways -- for men and women, new grads and midcareer workers.
name: Susan Colantuono: The career advice you probably didn’t get
title_vid: The career advice you probably didn’t get

title_talk: Robert Gupta: Between music and medicine
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: We the People, and the Republic we must reclaim | Lawrence Lessig
description: There is a corruption at the heart of American politics, caused by the dependence of Congressional candidates on funding from the tiniest percentage of citizens. That's the argument at the core of this blistering talk by legal scholar Lawrence Lessig. With rapid-fire visuals, he shows how the funding process weakens the Republic in the most fundamental way, and issues a rallying bipartisan cry that will resonate with many in the U.S. and beyond.
name: Lawrence Lessig: We the People, and the Republic we must reclaim
title_vid: We the People, and the Republic we must reclaim

title_talk: A tribute to nurses | Carolyn Jones
description: Carolyn Jones spent five years interviewing, photographing and filming nurses across America, traveling to places dealing with some of the nation's biggest public health issues. She shares personal stories of unwavering dedication in this celebration of the everyday heroes who work at the front lines of health care.
name: Carolyn Jones: A tribute to nurses
title_vid: A tribute to nurses

title_talk: 3 ways to fix a broken news industry | Lara Setrakian
description: Something is very wrong with the news industry. Trust in the media has hit an all-time low; we're inundated with sensationalist stories, and consistent, high-quality reporting is scarce, says journalist Lara Setrakian. She shares three ways we can fix the news to better inform all of us about the complex issues of our time.
name: Lara Setrakian: 3 ways to fix a broken news industry
title_vid: 3 ways to fix a broken news industry

title_talk: How We Can Make the World a Better Place by 2030 | Michael Green | TED Talks
description: Can we end hunger and poverty, halt climate change and achieve gender equality in the next 15 years? The governments of the world think we can. Meeting at the UN in September 2015, they agreed to a new set of Global Goals for the development of the world to 2030. Social progress expert Michael Green invites us to imagine how these goals and their vision for a better world can be achieved.
name: Michael Green: How we can make the world a better place by 2030
title_vid: How we can make the world a better place by 2030

title_talk: A story of mixed emoticons | Rives
description: Rives tells a typographical fairy tale that's short and bittersweet ;)
name: Rives: A story of mixed emoticons
title_vid: A story of mixed emoticons

title_talk: Stephen Lawler: Look! Up in the sky! It's Virtual Earth!
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Dave Meslin: The antidote to apathy
description: Local politics -- schools, zoning, council elections -- hit us where we live. So why don't more of us actually get involved? Is it apathy? Dave Meslin says no. He identifies 7 barriers that keep us from taking part in our communities, even when we truly care.
name: Dave Meslin: The antidote to apathy
title_vid: The antidote to apathy

title_talk: Sylvia Earle: How to protect the oceans (TED Prize winner!)
description: Legendary ocean researcher Sylvia Earle shares astonishing images of the ocean -- and shocking stats about its rapid decline -- as she makes her TED Prize wish: that we will join her in protecting the vital blue heart of the planet.
name: Sylvia Earle: My wish: Protect our oceans
title_vid: My wish: Protect our oceans

title_talk: Dan Buettner: How to live to be 100+
description: To find the path to long life and health, Dan Buettner and team study the world's "Blue Zones," communities whose elders live with vim and vigor to record-setting age. In his talk, he shares the 9 common diet and lifestyle habits that keep them spry past age 100.
name: Dan Buettner: How to live to be 100+
title_vid: How to live to be 100+

title_talk: Khadija Gbla: My mother’s strange definition of empowerment
description: Khadija Gbla grew up caught between two definitions of what it means to be an “empowered woman.” While her Sierra Leonean mother thought that circumsizing her — and thus stifling her sexual urges — was the ultimate form of empowerment, her culture as a teenager in Australia told her that she deserved pleasure and that what happened to her was called “female genital mutilation.” In a candid and funny talk, she shares what it was like to make her way in a “clitoris-centric society,” and how she works to make sure other women don’t have to figure this out. (Warning: This talk contains hard-to-hear details.)
name: Khadija Gbla: My mother’s strange definition of empowerment
title_vid: My mother’s strange definition of empowerment

title_talk: What we're missing in the debate about immigration | Duarte Geraldino
description: Between 2008 and 2016, the United States deported more than three million people. What happens to those left behind? Journalist Duarte Geraldino picks up the story of deportation where the state leaves off. Learn more about the wider impact of forced removal as Geraldino explains how the sudden absence of a mother, a local business owner or a high school student ripples outward and wreaks havoc on the relationships that hold our communities together.
name: Duarte Geraldino: What we're missing in the debate about immigration
title_vid: What we're missing in the debate about immigration

title_talk: The new era of positive psychology | Martin Seligman
description: Martin Seligman talks about psychology -- as a field of study and as it works one-on-one with each patient and each practitioner. As it moves beyond a focus on disease, what can modern psychology help us to become?
name: Martin Seligman: The new era of positive psychology
title_vid: The new era of positive psychology

title_talk: Nicholas Christakis: The hidden influence of social networks
description: We're all embedded in vast social networks of friends, family, co-workers and more. Nicholas Christakis tracks how a wide variety of traits -- from happiness to obesity -- can spread from person to person, showing how your location in the network might impact your life in ways you don't even know.
name: Nicholas Christakis: The hidden influence of social networks
title_vid: The hidden influence of social networks

title_talk: Trash cart superheroes | Mundano
description: In Brazil, "catadores" collect junk and recyclables. But while they provide a vital service that benefits all, they are nearly invisible as they roam the streets. Enter graffiti artist Mundano, a TED Fellow. In a spirited talk, he describes his project "Pimp My Carroça," which has transformed these heroic workers' carts into things of beauty and infused them with a sense of humor. It's a movement that is going global.
name: Mundano: Trash cart superheroes
title_vid: Trash cart superheroes

title_talk: Joe Madiath: Better toilets, better life
description: In rural India, the lack of toilets creates a big, stinking problem. It leads to poor quality water, one of the leading causes of disease in India, and has a disproportionately negative effect on women. Joe Madiath introduces a program to help villagers help themselves, by building clean, protected water and sanitation systems and requiring everyone in the village to collaborate -- with significant benefits that ripple across health, education and even government.
name: Joe Madiath: Better toilets, better life
title_vid: Better toilets, better life

title_talk: John La Grou plugs smart power outlets
description: John La Grou unveils an ingenious new technology that will smarten up the electrical outlets in our homes, using microprocessors and RFID tags. The invention, Safeplug, promises to prevent deadly accidents like house fires -- and to conserve energy.
name: John La Grou: A plug for smart power outlets
title_vid: A plug for smart power outlets

title_talk: An interview with the founders of Black Lives Matter | Alicia Garza, Patrisse Cullors, Opal Tometi
description: Born out of a social media post, the Black Lives Matter movement has sparked discussion about race and inequality across the world. In this spirited conversation with Mia Birdsong, the movement's three founders share what they've learned about leadership and what provides them with hope and inspiration in the face of painful realities. Their advice on how to participate in ensuring freedom for everybody: join something, start something and "sharpen each other, so that we all can rise."
main_speaker: Alicia Garza, Patrisse Cullors and Opal Tometi
name: Alicia Garza, Patrisse Cullors and Opal Tometi: An interview with the founders of Black Lives Matter
title_vid: An interview with the founders of Black Lives Matter

title_talk: Mike Matas: A next-generation digital book
description: Software developer Mike Matas demos the first full-length interactive book for the iPad -- with clever, swipeable video and graphics and some very cool data visualizations to play with. The book is "Our Choice," Al Gore's sequel to "An Inconvenient Truth."
name: Mike Matas: A next-generation digital book
title_vid: A next-generation digital book

title_talk: The dream we haven't dared to dream | Dan Pallotta
description: What are your dreams? Better yet, what are your broken dreams? Dan Pallotta dreams of a time when we are as excited, curious and scientific about the development of our humanity as we are about the development of our technology. "What we fear most is that we will be denied the opportunity to fulfill our true potential," Pallotta says. "Imagine living in a world where we simply recognize that deep, existential fear in one another -- and love one another boldly because we know that to be human is to live with that fear."
name: Dan Pallotta: The dream we haven't dared to dream
title_vid: The dream we haven't dared to dream

title_talk: Peter Singer: The why and how of effective altruism
description: If you're lucky enough to live without want, it's a natural impulse to be altruistic to others. But, asks philosopher Peter Singer, what's the most effective way to give? He talks through some surprising thought experiments to help you balance emotion and practicality -- and make the biggest impact with whatever you can share. NOTE: Starting at 0:30, this talk contains 30 seconds of graphic footage.
name: Peter Singer: The why and how of effective altruism
title_vid: The why and how of effective altruism

title_talk: I leapt from the stratosphere. Here's how I did it | Alan Eustace
description: On October 24, 2014, Alan Eustace donned a custom-built, 235-pound spacesuit, attached himself to a weather balloon, and rose above 135,000 feet, from which point he dove to Earth, breaking both the sound barrier and previous records for high-altitude jumps. Hear his story of how -- and why.
name: Alan Eustace: I leapt from the stratosphere. Here's how I did it
title_vid: I leapt from the stratosphere. Here's how I did it

title_talk: Could We Cure HIV with Lasers? | Patience Mthunzi | TED Talks
description: Swallowing pills to get medication is a quick, painless and often not entirely effective way of treating disease. A potentially better way? Lasers. In this passionate talk, TED Fellow Patience Mthunzi explains her idea to use lasers to deliver drugs directly to cells infected with HIV. It's early days yet, but could a cure be on the horizon?
name: Patience Mthunzi: Could we cure HIV with lasers?
title_vid: Could we cure HIV with lasers?

title_talk: Extreme wingsuit flying (The TEDTalk)
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: How to green the world's deserts and reverse climate change | Allan Savory
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: How computers learn to recognize objects instantly | Joseph Redmon
description: Ten years ago, researchers thought that getting a computer to tell the difference between a cat and a dog would be almost impossible. Today, computer vision systems do it with greater than 99 percent accuracy. How? Joseph Redmon works on the YOLO (You Only Look Once) system, an open-source method of object detection that can identify objects in images and video -- from zebras to stop signs -- with lightning-quick speed. In a remarkable live demo, Redmon shows off this important step forward for applications like self-driving cars, robotics and even cancer detection.
name: Joseph Redmon: How computers learn to recognize objects instantly
title_vid: How computers learn to recognize objects instantly

title_talk: Taryn Simon: The stories behind the bloodlines
description: Taryn Simon captures the essence of vast, generation-spanning stories by photographing the descendants of people at the center of the narrative. In this riveting talk she shows a stream of these stories from all over the world, investigating the nature of genealogy and the way our lives are shaped by the interplay of many different forces.
name: Taryn Simon: The stories behind the bloodlines
title_vid: The stories behind the bloodlines

title_talk: Carlo Ratti: Architecture that senses and responds
description: With his team at SENSEable City Lab, MIT's Carlo Ratti makes cool things by sensing the data we create. He pulls from passive data sets -- like the calls we make, the garbage we throw away -- to create surprising visualizations of city life. And he and his team create dazzling interactive environments from moving water and flying light, powered by simple gestures caught through sensors.
name: Carlo Ratti: Architecture that senses and responds
title_vid: Architecture that senses and responds

title_talk: Scott McCloud: Understanding comics
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: How fake news does real harm | Stephanie Busari
description: On April 14, 2014, the terrorist organization Boko Haram kidnapped more than 200 schoolgirls from the town of Chibok, Nigeria. Around the world, the crime became epitomized by the slogan #BringBackOurGirls -- but in Nigeria, government officials called the crime a hoax, confusing and delaying efforts to rescue the girls. In this powerful talk, journalist Stephanie Busari points to the Chibok tragedy to explain the deadly danger of fake news and what we can do to stop it.
name: Stephanie Busari: How fake news does real harm
title_vid: How fake news does real harm

title_talk: Jarrett J. Krosoczka: How a boy became an artist
description: This talk paints the funny and touching story of a little boy who pursued a simple passion: to draw and write stories. With the help of a supporting cast of family and teachers, Jarrett J. Krosoczka tells how he grew up to create beloved children's books.
name: Jarrett J. Krosoczka: How a boy became an artist
title_vid: How a boy became an artist

title_talk: Ethan Zuckerman: How to listen to global voices
description: Sure, the web connects the globe, but most of us end up hearing mainly from people just like ourselves. Blogger and technologist Ethan Zuckerman wants to help share the stories of the whole wide world. He talks about clever strategies to open up your Twitter world and read the news in languages you don't even know.
name: Ethan Zuckerman: Listening to global voices
title_vid: Listening to global voices

title_talk: Hillel Cooperman: Legos for grownups
description: Lego blocks: playtime mainstay for industrious kids, obsession for many (ahem!) mature adults. Hillel Cooperman takes us on a trip through the beloved bricks' colorful, sometimes oddball grownup subculture, featuring CAD, open-source robotics and a little adult behavior.
name: Hillel Cooperman: Legos for grownups
title_vid: Legos for grownups

title_talk: Daphne Koller: What we're learning from online education
description: Daphne Koller is enticing top universities to put their most intriguing courses online for free -- not just as a service, but as a way to research how people learn. With Coursera (cofounded by Andrew Ng), each keystroke, quiz, peer-to-peer discussion and self-graded assignment builds an unprecedented pool of data on how knowledge is processed.
name: Daphne Koller: What we're learning from online education
title_vid: What we're learning from online education

title_talk: Finding life we can't imagine | Christoph Adami
description: How do we search for alien life if it's nothing like the life that we know? Christoph Adami shows how he uses his research into artificial life -- self-replicating computer programs -- to find a signature, a "biomarker," that is free of our preconceptions of what life is.
name: Christoph Adami: Finding life we can't imagine
title_vid: Finding life we can't imagine

title_talk: Why we have too few women leaders | Sheryl Sandberg
description: Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg looks at why a smaller percentage of women than men reach the top of their professions -- and offers 3 powerful pieces of advice to women aiming for the C-suite.
name: Sheryl Sandberg: Why we have too few women leaders
title_vid: Why we have too few women leaders

title_talk: Jared Ficklin: New ways to see music (with color! and fire!)
description: Designer Jared Ficklin creates wild visualizations that let us see music, using color and even fire (a first for the TED stage) to analyze how sound makes us feel. He takes a brief digression to analyze the sound of a skatepark -- and how audio can clue us in to developing creativity.
name: Jared Ficklin: New ways to see music (with color! and fire!)
title_vid: New ways to see music (with color! and fire!)

title_talk: Arthur Potts Dawson: A vision for sustainable restaurants
description: If you've been in a restaurant kitchen, you've seen how much food, water and energy can be wasted there. Chef Arthur Potts-Dawson shares his very personal vision for drastically reducing restaurant, and supermarket, waste -- creating recycling, composting, sustainable engines for good (and good food).
name: Arthur Potts Dawson: A vision for sustainable restaurants
title_vid: A vision for sustainable restaurants

title_talk: Catherine Mohr builds green
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Cynthia Schneider: The surprising spread of "Idol" TV
description: Cynthia Schneider looks at two international "American Idol"-style shows -- one in Afghanistan, and one in the United Arab Emirates -- and shows the surprising effect that these reality-TV competitions are creating in their societies.
name: Cynthia Schneider: The surprising spread of Idol TV
title_vid: The surprising spread of Idol TV

title_talk: Ellen Dunham-Jones: Retrofitting suburbia
description: Can we rebuild our broken suburbs? Ellen Dunham-Jones shares a vision of dying malls rehabilitated, dead "big box" stores re-inhabited, and endless parking lots transformed into thriving wetlands.
name: Ellen Dunham-Jones: Retrofitting suburbia
title_vid: Retrofitting suburbia

title_talk: How an old loop of railroads is changing the face of a city | Ryan Gravel
description: Urban planner Ryan Gravel shares the story of how his hometown of Atlanta, Georgia, rallied to build a massive urban park that will transform an abandoned railroad track into 22 miles of public green space called the Atlanta BeltLine. The places we live aren't inevitable, he says -- and if we want something different, we need to speak up.
name: Ryan Gravel: How an old loop of railroads is changing the face of a city
title_vid: How an old loop of railroads is changing the face of a city

title_talk: David Deutsch: Chemical scum that dream of distant quasars
description: Legendary scientist David Deutsch puts theoretical physics on the back burner to discuss a more urgent matter: the survival of our species. The first step toward solving global warming, he says, is to admit that we have a problem.
name: David Deutsch: Chemical scum that dream of distant quasars
title_vid: Chemical scum that dream of distant quasars

title_talk: The violin, and my dark night of the soul | Ji-Hae Park
description: In her quest to become a world-famous violinist, Ji-Hae Park fell into a severe depression. Only music was able to lift her out again -- showing her that her goal needn’t be to play lofty concert halls, but instead to bring the wonder of the instrument to as many people as possible.
name: Ji-Hae Park: The violin, and my dark night of the soul
title_vid: The violin, and my dark night of the soul

title_talk: How I found myself through music | Anika Paulson
description: "Music is everywhere, and it is in everything," says musician, student and TED-Ed Clubs star Anika Paulson. Guitar in hand, she plays through the beats of her life in an exploration of how music connects us and makes us what we are.
name: Anika Paulson: How I found myself through music
title_vid: How I found myself through music

title_talk: Ivan Krastev: Can democracy exist without trust?
description: It seems the more we know about how democracy works -- through government transparency, better media coverage, even new insights about our brains -- the less we trust democracy itself. Yet it's still, arguably, the best system of government available. As Ivan Krastev says, "What went right is also what went wrong." Can democracy survive?
name: Ivan Krastev: Can democracy exist without trust?
title_vid: Can democracy exist without trust?

title_talk: Fred Jansen: How to land on a comet
description: As manager of the Rosetta mission, Fred Jansen was responsible for the successful 2014 landing of a probe on the comet known as 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. In this fascinating and funny talk, Jansen reveals some of the intricate calculations that went into landing the Philae probe on a comet 500 million kilometers from Earth -- and shares some incredible photographs taken along the way.
name: Fred Jansen: How to land on a comet
title_vid: How to land on a comet

title_talk: Toby Shapshak: You don't need an app for that
description: Are the simplest phones the smartest? While the rest of the world is updating statuses and playing games on smartphones, Africa is developing useful SMS-based solutions to everyday needs, says journalist Toby Shapshak. In this eye-opening talk, Shapshak explores the frontiers of mobile invention in Africa as he asks us to reconsider our preconceived notions of innovation.
name: Toby Shapshak: You don't need an app for that
title_vid: You don't need an app for that

title_talk: David Brooks: The social animal
description: Columnist David Brooks unpacks new insights into human nature from the cognitive sciences -- insights with massive implications for economics and politics as well as our own self-knowledge. In a talk full of humor, he shows how you can't hope to understand humans as separate individuals making choices based on their conscious awareness.
name: David Brooks: The social animal
title_vid: The social animal

title_talk: Chris Urmson: How a driverless car sees the road
description: Statistically, the least reliable part of the car is ... the driver. In 2015, Chris Urmson was head of Google's driverless car program, one of several efforts to remove humans from the driver's seat. He shares fascinating footage that shows how the car sees the road and makes autonomous decisions about what to do next.
name: Chris Urmson: How a driverless car sees the road
title_vid: How a driverless car sees the road

title_talk: Melinda French Gates: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola
description: Melinda Gates makes a provocative case: What can nonprofits learn from mega-corporations like Coca-Cola, whose global network of marketers and distributors ensures that every remote village wants -- and can get -- an ice-cold Coke? Maybe this model could work for distributing health care, vaccinations, sanitation, even condoms ...
name: Melinda Gates: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola
title_vid: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola

title_talk: Donald Sadoway: The missing link to renewable energy
description: What's the key to using alternative energy, like solar and wind? Storage -- so we can have power on tap even when the sun's not out and the wind's not blowing. In this accessible, inspiring talk, Donald Sadoway takes to the blackboard to show us the future of large-scale batteries that store renewable energy. As he says: "We need to think about the problem differently. We need to think big. We need to think cheap."
name: Donald Sadoway: The missing link to renewable energy
title_vid: The missing link to renewable energy

title_talk: Bring on the Learning Revolution! | Ken Robinson | TED Talks
description: In this poignant, funny follow-up to his fabled 2006 talk, Sir Ken Robinson makes the case for a radical shift from standardized schools to personalized learning -- creating conditions where kids' natural talents can flourish.
name: Ken Robinson: Bring on the learning revolution!
title_vid: Bring on the learning revolution!

title_talk: Amos Winter: The cheap all-terrain wheelchair
description: How do you build a wheelchair ready to blaze through mud and sand, all for under $200? MIT engineer Amos Winter guides us through the mechanics of an all-terrain wheelchair that's cheap and easy to build -- for true accessibility -- and gives us some lessons he learned along the road.
name: Amos Winter: The cheap all-terrain wheelchair
title_vid: The cheap all-terrain wheelchair

title_talk: We train soldiers for war. Let's train them to come home, too | Hector Garcia
description: Before soldiers are sent into combat, they're trained on how to function in an immensely dangerous environment. But they also need training on how to return from the battlefield to civilian life, says psychologist Hector Garcia. Applying the same principles used to prepare soldiers for war, Garcia is helping veterans suffering from PTSD get their lives back.
name: Hector Garcia: We train soldiers for war. Let's train them to come home, too
title_vid: We train soldiers for war. Let's train them to come home, too

title_talk: Josh Silver demos adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses
description: Josh Silver delivers his brilliantly simple solution for correcting vision at the lowest cost possible -- adjustable, liquid-filled lenses. At TEDGlobal 2009, he demos his affordable eyeglasses and reveals his global plan to distribute them to a billion people in need by 2020.
name: Joshua Silver: Adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses
title_vid: Adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses

title_talk: How I defend the rule of law | Kimberley Motley
description: Every human deserves protection under their country’s laws — even when that law is forgotten or ignored. Sharing three cases from her international legal practice, Kimberley Motley, an American litigator practicing in Afghanistan and elsewhere, shows how a country’s own laws can bring both justice and “justness”: using the law for its intended purpose, to protect.
name: Kimberley Motley: How I defend the rule of law
title_vid: How I defend the rule of law

title_talk: The moral dangers of non-lethal weapons | Stephen Coleman
description: Pepper spray, Tasers, tear gas, rubber bullets -- these "non-lethal" weapons are being used by more and more local police forces, as well as military forces brought in to control civilian crowds and other situations. Despite their name, non-lethal weapons have been known to cause deaths ... and as Stephen Coleman suggests, there are other, more insidious hazards as well. He explores the complex ethics -- and the unexpected consequences -- of using non-lethal weapons to control civilians.
name: Stephen Coleman: Non-lethal weapons, a moral hazard?
title_vid: Non-lethal weapons, a moral hazard?

title_talk: Inside the mind of a master procrastinator | Tim Urban
description: Tim Urban knows that procrastination doesn't make sense, but he's never been able to shake his habit of waiting until the last minute to get things done. In this hilarious and insightful talk, Urban takes us on a journey through YouTube binges, Wikipedia rabbit holes and bouts of staring out the window -- and encourages us to think harder about what we're really procrastinating on, before we run out of time.
name: Tim Urban: Inside the mind of a master procrastinator
title_vid: Inside the mind of a master procrastinator

title_talk: How human noise affects ocean habitats | Kate Stafford
description: Oceanographer Kate Stafford lowers us into the sonically rich depths of the Arctic Ocean, where ice groans, whales sing to communicate over vast distances -- and climate change and human noise threaten to alter the environment in ways we don't understand. Learn more about why this underwater soundscape matters and what we might do to protect it.
name: Kate Stafford: How human noise affects ocean habitats
title_vid: How human noise affects ocean habitats

title_talk: Want kids to learn well? Feed them well | Sam Kass
description: What can we expect our kids to learn if they're hungry or eating diets full of sugar and empty of nutrients? Former White House Chef and food policymaker Sam Kass discusses the role schools can play in nourishing students' bodies in addition to their minds.
name: Sam Kass: Want kids to learn well? Feed them well
title_vid: Want kids to learn well? Feed them well

title_talk: Daniel Goleman: Why arent we all Good Samaritans?
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Uldus Bakhtiozina: Wry photos that turn stereotypes upside down
description: Artist Uldus Bakhtiozina uses photographs to poke fun at societal norms in her native Russia. A glimpse into Russian youth culture and a short, fun reminder not to take ourselves too seriously.
name: Uldus Bakhtiozina: Wry photos that turn stereotypes upside down
title_vid: Wry photos that turn stereotypes upside down

title_talk: What we can do to die well | Timothy Ihrig
description: The healthcare industry in America is so focused on pathology, surgery and pharmacology -- on what doctors "do" to patients -- that it often overlooks the values of the human beings it's supposed to care for. Palliative care physician Timothy Ihrig explains the benefits of a different approach, one that fosters a patient's overall quality of life and navigates serious illness from diagnosis to death with dignity and compassion.
name: Timothy Ihrig: What we can do to die well
title_vid: What we can do to die well

title_talk: Your body is my canvas | Alexa Meade
description: Alexa Meade takes an innovative approach to art. Not for her a life of sketching and stretching canvases. Instead, she selects a topic and then paints it--literally. She covers everything in a scene--people, chairs, food, you name it--in a mask of paint that mimics what's below it. In this eye-opening talk Meade shows off photographs of some of the more outlandish results, and shares a new project involving people, paint and milk.
name: Alexa Meade: Your body is my canvas
title_vid: Your body is my canvas

title_talk: His Holiness the Karmapa: The technology of the heart
description: His Holiness the Karmapa talks about how he was discovered to be the reincarnation of a revered figure in Tibetan Buddhism. In telling his story, he urges us to work on not just technology and design, but the technology and design of the heart. He is translated onstage by Tyler Dewar.
name: His Holiness the Karmapa: The technology of the heart
title_vid: The technology of the heart

title_talk: Cameron Sinclair: A call for open-source architecture
description: Accepting his 2006 TED Prize, Cameron Sinclair demonstrates how passionate designers and architects can respond to world housing crises. He unveils his TED Prize wish for a network to improve global living standards through collaborative design.
name: Cameron Sinclair: My wish: A call for open-source architecture
title_vid: My wish: A call for open-source architecture

title_talk: Sherwin Nuland: A meditation on hope
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: JP Rangaswami: Information is food
description: How do we consume data? At TED@SXSWi, technologist JP Rangaswami muses on our relationship to information, and offers a surprising and sharp insight: we treat it like food.
name: JP Rangaswami: Information is food
title_vid: Information is food

title_talk: The forgotten art of the zoetrope | Eric Dyer
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Ben Saunders: Three things to know before you ski to the North Pole
description: Arctic explorer Ben Saunders recounts his harrowing solo ski trek to the North Pole, complete with engaging anecdotes, gorgeous photos and never-before-seen video.
name: Ben Saunders: Why did I ski to the North Pole?
title_vid: Why did I ski to the North Pole?

title_talk: Stanley McChrystal: Listen, learn ... then lead
description: Four-star general Stanley McChrystal shares what he learned about leadership over his decades in the military. How can you build a sense of shared purpose among people of many ages and skill sets? By listening and learning -- and addressing the possibility of failure.
name: Stanley McChrystal: Listen, learn ... then lead
title_vid: Listen, learn ... then lead

title_talk: Vinay Venkatraman: Technology crafts for the digitally underserved
description: Two-thirds of the world may not have access to the latest smartphone, but local electronic shops are  adept at fixing older tech using low-cost parts. Vinay Venkatraman explains his work in "technology crafts," through which a mobile phone, a lunchbox and a flashlight can become a digital projector for a village school, or an alarm clock and a mouse can be melded into a medical device for local triage.
name: Vinay Venkatraman: Technology crafts for the digitally underserved
title_vid: Technology crafts for the digitally underserved

title_talk: The laws that sex workers really want | Juno Mac
description: Everyone has an opinion about how to legislate sex work (whether to legalize it, ban it or even tax it) ... but what do workers themselves think would work best? Activist Juno Mac explains four legal models that are being used around the world and shows us the model that she believes will work best to keep sex workers safe and offer greater self-determination. "If you care about gender equality or poverty or migration or public health, then sex worker rights matter to you," she says. "Make space for us in your movements." (Adult themes)
name: Juno Mac: The laws that sex workers really want
title_vid: The laws that sex workers really want

title_talk: Rory Stewart: Why democracy matters
description: The public is losing faith in democracy, says British MP Rory Stewart. Iraq and Afghanistan’s new democracies are deeply corrupt; meanwhile, 84 percent of people in Britain say politics is broken. In this important talk, Stewart sounds a call to action to rebuild democracy, starting with recognizing why democracy is important -- not as a tool, but as an ideal.
name: Rory Stewart: Why democracy matters
title_vid: Why democracy matters

title_talk: Less stuff, more happiness | Graham Hill
description: Writer and designer Graham Hill asks: Can having less stuff, in less room, lead to more happiness? He makes the case for taking up less space, and lays out three rules for editing your life.
name: Graham Hill: Less stuff, more happiness
title_vid: Less stuff, more happiness

title_talk: Jack Horner: Shape-shifting dinosaurs
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: In the Internet age, dance evolves ... | The LXD
description: The LXD (the Legion of Extraordinary Dancers) electrify the TED2010 stage with an emerging global street-dance culture, revved up by the Internet.  In a preview of Jon Chu's upcoming Web series, this astonishing troupe show off their superpowers.
name: The LXD: In the Internet age, dance evolves ...
title_vid: In the Internet age, dance evolves ...

title_talk: Naturally 7 beatbox a whole band
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Nathalie Miebach: Art made of storms
description: Artist Nathalie Miebach takes weather data from massive storms and turns it into complex sculptures that embody the forces of nature and time. These sculptures then become musical scores for a string quartet to play.
name: Nathalie Miebach: Art made of storms
title_vid: Art made of storms

title_talk: Why is our universe fine-tuned for life? | Brian Greene
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: 4 ways to make a city more walkable | Jeff Speck
description: How do we solve the problem of the suburbs? Urbanist Jeff Speck shows how we can free ourselves from dependence on the car -- which he calls "a gas-belching, time-wasting, life-threatening prosthetic device" -- by making our cities more walkable and more pleasant for more people.
name: Jeff Speck: The walkable city
title_vid: The walkable city

title_talk: 4 ways to make a city more walkable | Jeff Speck
description: Freedom from cars, freedom from sprawl, freedom to walk your city! City planner Jeff Speck shares his "general theory of walkability" -- four planning principles to transform sprawling cities of six-lane highways and 600-foot blocks into safe, walkable oases full of bike lanes and tree-lined streets.
name: Jeff Speck: 4 ways to make a city more walkable
title_vid: 4 ways to make a city more walkable

title_talk: We should all be feminists | Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
description: We teach girls that they can have ambition, but not too much ... to be successful, but not too successful, or they'll threaten men, says author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie. In this classic talk that started a worldwide conversation about feminism, Adichie asks that we begin to dream about and plan for a different, fairer world -- of happier men and women who are truer to themselves.
name: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: We should all be feminists
title_vid: We should all be feminists

title_talk: Jean-Baptiste Michel: The mathematics of history
description: What can mathematics say about history? According to TED Fellow Jean-Baptiste Michel, quite a lot. From changes to language to the deadliness of wars, he shows how digitized history is just starting to reveal deep underlying patterns.
name: Jean-Baptiste Michel: The mathematics of history
title_vid: The mathematics of history

title_talk: The power of vulnerability | Brené Brown
description: Brené Brown studies human connection -- our ability to empathize, belong, love. In a poignant, funny talk, she shares a deep insight from her research, one that sent her on a personal quest to know herself as well as to understand humanity. A talk to share.
name: Brené Brown: The power of vulnerability
title_vid: The power of vulnerability

title_talk: The danger of silence | Clint Smith
description: "We spend so much time listening to the things people are saying that we rarely pay attention to the things they don't," says poet and teacher Clint Smith. A short, powerful piece from the heart, about finding the courage to speak up against ignorance and injustice.
name: Clint Smith: The danger of silence
title_vid: The danger of silence

title_talk: James Geary, metaphorically speaking
description: Aphorism enthusiast and author James Geary waxes on a fascinating fixture of human language: the metaphor. Friend of scribes from Aristotle to Elvis, metaphor can subtly influence the decisions we make, Geary says.
name: James Geary: Metaphorically speaking
title_vid: Metaphorically speaking

title_talk: David Hanson: Robots that "show emotion"
description: David Hanson's robot faces look and act like yours: They recognize and respond to emotion, and make expressions of their own. Here, an "emotional" live demo of the Einstein robot offers a peek at a future where robots truly mimic humans.
name: David Hanson: Robots that "show emotion"
title_vid: Robots that "show emotion"

title_talk: The first 21 days of a bee’s life | Anand Varma
description: We’ve heard that bees are disappearing. But what is making bee colonies so vulnerable? Photographer Anand Varma raised bees in his backyard — in front of a camera — to get an up close view. This project, for National Geographic, gives a lyrical glimpse into a beehive, and reveals one of the biggest threats to its health, a mite that preys on baby bees in their first 21 days of life. With footage set to music from Rob Moose and the Magik*Magik Orchestra, Varma shows the problem ... and what’s being done to solve it. (This talk was part of a session at TED2015 guest-curated by Pop-Up Magazine: popupmagazine.com or @popupmag on Twitter.)
name: Anand Varma: The first 21 days of a bee’s life
title_vid: The first 21 days of a bee’s life

title_talk: Jehane Noujaim: TEDPrize wish: Unite the world on Pangea Day
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Daniel H. Cohen: For argument's sake
description: Why do we argue? To out-reason our opponents, prove them wrong, and, most of all, to win! Right? Philosopher Daniel H. Cohen shows how our most common form of argument -- a war in which one person must win and the other must lose -- misses out on the real benefits of engaging in active disagreement.
name: Daniel H. Cohen: For argument's sake
title_vid: For argument's sake

title_talk: Street Art for Hope and Peace | eL Seed | TED Talks
description: What does this gorgeous street art say? It's Arabic poetry, inspired by bold graffiti and placed where a message of hope and peace can do the most good. In this quietly passionate talk, artist and TED Fellow eL Seed describes his ambition: to create art so beautiful it needs no translation.
name: eL Seed: Street art with a message of hope and peace
title_vid: Street art with a message of hope and peace

title_talk: The interspecies Internet? An idea in progress...
description: Apes, dolphins and elephants are animals with remarkable communication skills. Could the internet be expanded to include sentient species like them? A new and developing idea from a panel of four great thinkers -- dolphin researcher Diana Reiss, musician Peter Gabriel, internet of things visionary Neil Gershenfeld and Vint Cerf, one of the fathers of the internet.
main_speaker: Diana Reiss, Peter Gabriel, Neil Gershenfeld and Vint Cerf
name: The interspecies internet? An idea in progress
title_vid: The interspecies internet? An idea in progress

title_talk: Saki Mafundikwa: Ingenuity and elegance in ancient African alphabets
description: From simple alphabets to secret symbolic languages, graphic designer Saki Mafundikwa celebrates the many forms of written communication across the continent of Africa. He highlights the history and legacy that are embodied in written words and symbols, and urges African designers to draw on these graphic forms for fresh inspiration. It's summed up in his favorite Ghanaian glyph, Sankofa, which means "return and get it" -- or "learn from the past."
name: Saki Mafundikwa: Ingenuity and elegance in ancient African alphabets
title_vid: Ingenuity and elegance in ancient African alphabets

title_talk: Robert Full: Learning from the gecko's tail
description: Biologist Robert Full studies the amazing gecko, with its supersticky feet and tenacious climbing skill. But high-speed footage reveals that the gecko's tail harbors perhaps the most surprising talents of all.
name: Robert Full: Learning from the gecko's tail
title_vid: Learning from the gecko's tail

title_talk: We need nuclear power to solve climate change | Joe Lassiter
description: Joe Lassiter is a deep thinker and straight talker focused on developing clean, secure and carbon-neutral supplies of reliable, low-cost energy. His analysis of the world's energy realities puts a powerful lens on the stubbornly touchy issue of nuclear power, including new designs for plants that can compete economically with fossil fuels. We have the potential to make nuclear safer and cheaper than it's been in the past, Lassiter says. Now we have to make the choice to pursue it.
name: Joe Lassiter: We need nuclear power to solve climate change
title_vid: We need nuclear power to solve climate change

title_talk: Rory Stewart: Time to end the war in Afghanistan
description: British MP Rory Stewart walked across Afghanistan after 9/11, talking with citizens and warlords alike. Now, a decade later, he asks: Why are Western and coalition forces still fighting there? He shares lessons from past military interventions that worked -- Bosnia, for instance -- and shows that humility and local expertise are the keys to success.
name: Rory Stewart: Time to end the war in Afghanistan
title_vid: Time to end the war in Afghanistan

title_talk: Bruce Aylward: Humanity vs. Ebola. The winning strategies in a terrifying war
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Kim Gorgens: Protecting the brain against concussion
description: Neuropsychologist Kim Gorgens makes the case for better protecting our brains against the risk of concussion -- with a compelling pitch for putting helmets on kids.
name: Kim Gorgens: Protecting the brain against concussion
title_vid: Protecting the brain against concussion

title_talk: Colin Powell: Kids need structure
description: How can you help kids get a good start? In this heartfelt and personal talk, Colin Powell, the former U.S. Secretary of State, asks parents, friends and relatives to support children, starting before they even get to primary school, through community and a strong sense of responsibility.
name: Colin Powell: Kids need structure
title_vid: Kids need structure

title_talk: The deadly legacy of cluster bombs | Laura Boushnak
description: The destruction of war doesn't stop when the fighting is over. Photographer and TED Fellow Laura Boushnak shares a powerful photo essay about the survivors of cluster bombs, people who encountered these deadly submunitions years after the end of conflict. With her haunting photos, Boushnak asks those who still produce and condone the use of these weapons to abandon them.
name: Laura Boushnak: The deadly legacy of cluster bombs
title_vid: The deadly legacy of cluster bombs

title_talk: Johanna Blakley: Social media and the end of gender
description: Media and advertising companies still use the same old demographics to understand audiences, but they're becoming increasingly harder to track online, says media researcher Johanna Blakley. As social media outgrows traditional media, and women users outnumber men, Blakley explains what changes are in store for the future of media.
name: Johanna Blakley: Social media and the end of gender
title_vid: Social media and the end of gender

title_talk: Jonathan Harris: The web as art
description: At the EG conference in December 2007, artist Jonathan Harris discusses his latest projects, which involve collecting stories: his own, strangers', and stories collected from the Internet, including his amazing "We Feel Fine."
name: Jonathan Harris: The web as art
title_vid: The web as art

title_talk: Karen Bass: Unseen footage, untamed nature
description: At TED2012, filmmaker Karen Bass shares some of the astonishing nature footage she's shot for the BBC and National Geographic -- including brand-new, previously unseen footage of the tube-lipped nectar bat, who feeds in a rather unusual way ...
name: Karen Bass: Unseen footage, untamed nature
title_vid: Unseen footage, untamed nature

title_talk: Christina Warinner: Tracking ancient diseases using ... plaque
description: Imagine what we could learn about diseases by studying the history of human disease, from ancient hominids to the present. But how? TED Fellow Christina Warinner is an achaeological geneticist, and she's found a spectacular new tool -- the microbial DNA in fossilized dental plaque.
name: Christina Warinner: Tracking ancient diseases using ... plaque
title_vid: Tracking ancient diseases using ... plaque

title_talk: Robin Ince: Science versus wonder?
description: Does science ruin the magic of life? In this grumpy but charming monologue, Robin Ince makes the argument against. The more we learn about the astonishing behavior of the universe -- the more we stand in awe.
name: Robin Ince: Science versus wonder?
title_vid: Science versus wonder?

title_talk: John McWhorter: Txtng is killing language. JK!!!
description: Does texting mean the death of good writing skills? John McWhorter posits that there’s much more to texting -- linguistically, culturally -- than it seems, and it’s all good news.
name: John McWhorter: Txtng is killing language. JK!!!
title_vid: Txtng is killing language. JK!!!

title_talk: How equal do we want the world to be? You'd be surprised | Dan Ariely
description: The news of society's growing inequality makes all of us uneasy. But why? Dan Ariely reveals some new, surprising research on what we think is fair, as far as how wealth is distributed over societies ... then shows how it stacks up to the real stats.
name: Dan Ariely: How equal do we want the world to be? You'd be surprised
title_vid: How equal do we want the world to be? You'd be surprised

title_talk: Mena Trott: How blogs are building a friendlier world
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Didier Sornette: How we can predict the next financial crisis
description: The 2007-2008 financial crisis, you might think, was an unpredictable one-time crash. But Didier Sornette and his Financial Crisis Observatory have plotted a set of early warning signs for unstable, growing systems, tracking the moment when any bubble is about to pop. (And he's seeing it happen again, right now.)
name: Didier Sornette: How we can predict the next financial crisis
title_vid: How we can predict the next financial crisis

title_talk: Kwabena Boahen: Making a computer that works like the brain
description: Researcher Kwabena Boahen is looking for ways to mimic the brain's supercomputing powers in silicon -- because the messy, redundant processes inside our heads actually make for a small, light, superfast computer.
name: Kwabena Boahen: A computer that works like the brain
title_vid: A computer that works like the brain

title_talk: Siegfried Woldhek: The true face of Leonardo Da Vinci?
description: Mona Lisa is one of the best-known faces on the planet. But would you recognize an image of Leonardo da Vinci? Illustrator Siegfried Woldhek uses some thoughtful image-analysis techniques to find what he believes is the true face of Leonardo.
name: Siegfried Woldhek: The search for the true face of Leonardo
title_vid: The search for the true face of Leonardo

title_talk: Ryan Merkley: Online video -- annotated, remixed and popped
description: Videos on the web should work like the web itself: dynamic, full of links, maps and information that can be edited and updated live, says Ryan Merkley. On the TED stage he demos Mozilla's Popcorn Maker, a web-based tool for easy video remixing.
name: Ryan Merkley: Online video -- annotated, remixed and popped
title_vid: Online video -- annotated, remixed and popped

title_talk: The family I lost in North Korea. And the family I gained | Joseph Kim
description: A refugee now living in the US, Joseph Kim tells the story of his life in North Korea during the famine years. He's begun to create a new life -- but he still searches for the family he lost.
name: Joseph Kim: The family I lost in North Korea. And the family I gained.
title_vid: The family I lost in North Korea. And the family I gained.

title_talk: Harsha Bhogle: The rise of cricket, the rise of India
description: The tale of a major global cultural phenomenon: Cricket commentator Harsha Bhogle describes the spectacular arrival of fast-paced 20-20 cricket as it parallels the rise of modern India.  He traces the game from its sleepy English roots to the current world of celebrity owners and million-dollar player contracts.
name: Harsha Bhogle: The rise of cricket, the rise of India
title_vid: The rise of cricket, the rise of India

title_talk: Paper towns and why learning is awesome | John Green
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Jack Choi: On the virtual dissection table
description: Onstage at TED2012, Jack Choi demonstrates a powerful tool for training medical students: a stretcher-sized multi-touch screen of the human body that lets you explore, dissect and understand the body's parts and systems.
name: Jack Choi: On the virtual dissection table
title_vid: On the virtual dissection table

title_talk: Nellie McKay: "Clonie"
description: Singer-songwriter Nellie McKay performs the semi-serious song "Clonie" -- about creating the ultimate companion.
name: Nellie McKay: "Clonie"
title_vid: "Clonie"

title_talk: 10 myths about psychology: debunked | Ben Ambridge
description: How much of what you think about your brain is actually wrong? In this whistlestop tour of dis-proved science, Ben Ambridge walks through 10 popular ideas about psychology that have been proven wrong — and uncovers a few surprising truths about how our brains really work.
name: Ben Ambridge: 10 myths about psychology, debunked
title_vid: 10 myths about psychology, debunked

title_talk: Kiran Bedi: How I remade one of India's toughest prisons
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Why you think you're right -- even if you're wrong | Julia Galef
description: Perspective is everything, especially when it comes to examining your beliefs. Are you a soldier, prone to defending your viewpoint at all costs -- or a scout, spurred by curiosity? Julia Galef examines the motivations behind these two mindsets and how they shape the way we interpret information, interweaved with a compelling history lesson from 19th-century France. When your steadfast opinions are tested, Galef asks: "What do you most yearn for? Do you yearn to defend your own beliefs or do you yearn to see the world as clearly as you possibly can?"
name: Julia Galef: Why you think you're right -- even if you're wrong
title_vid: Why you think you're right -- even if you're wrong

title_talk: The surprising thing I learned sailing solo around the world | Dame Ellen MacArthur
description: What do you learn when you sail around the world on your own? When solo sailor Ellen MacArthur circled the globe – carrying everything she needed with her – she came back with new insight into the way the world works, as a place of interlocking cycles and finite resources, where the decisions we make today affect what's left for tomorrow. She proposes a bold new way to see the world's economic systems: not as linear, but as circular, where everything comes around.
name: Dame Ellen MacArthur: The surprising thing I learned sailing solo around the world
title_vid: The surprising thing I learned sailing solo around the world

title_talk: David Agus: A new strategy in the war against cancer
description: Too often, says David Agus cancer treatments have a short-sighted focus on individual cells. He suggests a new, cross-disciplinary approach, using atypical drugs, computer modeling and protein analysis to diagnose and treat the whole body.
name: David Agus: A new strategy in the war on cancer
title_vid: A new strategy in the war on cancer

title_talk: Juan Enriquez: Using biology to rethink the energy challenge
description: Juan Enriquez challenges our definition of bioenergy. Oil, coal, gas and other hydrocarbons are not chemical but biological products, based on plant matter -- and thus, growable. Our whole approach to fuel, he argues, needs to change.
name: Juan Enriquez: Using biology to rethink the energy challenge
title_vid: Using biology to rethink the energy challenge

title_talk: Sergey Brin and Larry Page: The genesis of Google
description: Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin offer a peek inside the Google machine, sharing tidbits about international search patterns, the philanthropic Google Foundation, and the company's dedication to innovation and employee happiness.
name: Sergey Brin + Larry Page: The genesis of Google
title_vid: The genesis of Google

title_talk: Greg Lynn: How calculus is changing architecture
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Gever Tulley teaches life lessons through tinkering
description: Gever Tulley uses engaging photos and footage to demonstrate the valuable lessons kids learn at his Tinkering School. When given tools, materials and guidance, these young imaginations run wild and creative problem-solving takes over to build unique boats, bridges and even a roller coaster!
name: Gever Tulley: Life lessons through tinkering
title_vid: Life lessons through tinkering

title_talk: Tim Berners-Lee: A Magna Carta for the web
description: Sir Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web 25 years ago. So it’s worth a listen when he warns us: There’s a battle ahead. Eroding net neutrality, filter bubbles and centralizing corporate control all threaten the web’s wide-open spaces. It’s up to users to fight for the right to access and openness. The question is, What kind of Internet do we want?
name: Tim Berners-Lee: A Magna Carta for the web
title_vid: A Magna Carta for the web

title_talk: Renny Gleeson: 404, the story of a page not found
description: Oops! Nobody wants to see the 404: Page Not Found. But as Renny Gleeson shows us, while he runs through a slideshow of creative and funny 404 pages, every error is really a chance to build a better relationship.
name: Renny Gleeson: 404, the story of a page not found
title_vid: 404, the story of a page not found

title_talk: Julia Sweeney has "The Talk"
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The future we're building -- and boring | Elon Musk
description: Elon Musk discusses his new project digging tunnels under LA, the latest from Tesla and SpaceX and his motivation for building a future on Mars in conversation with TED's Head Curator, Chris Anderson.
name: Elon Musk: The future we're building -- and boring
title_vid: The future we're building -- and boring

title_talk: "The Sacred Art of the Ori" | Laolu Senbanjo
description: Every artist has a name, and every artist has a story. Laolu Senbanjo's story started in Nigeria, where he was surrounded by the culture and mythology of the Yoruba, and brought him to law school, to New York and eventually to work on Beyoncé's "Lemonade." He shares what he calls "The Sacred Art of the Ori," art that uses skin as canvas and connects artist and muse through mind, body and soul.
name: Laolu Senbanjo: "The Sacred Art of the Ori"
title_vid: "The Sacred Art of the Ori"

title_talk: How do you save a shark you know nothing about? | Simon Berrow
description: They're the second-largest fish in the world, they're almost extinct, and we know almost nothing about them. In this talk, Simon Berrow describes the fascinating basking shark ("great fish of the sun" in Irish), and the exceptional -- and wonderfully low-tech -- ways he's learning enough to save them.
name: Simon Berrow: How do you save a shark you know nothing about?
title_vid: How do you save a shark you know nothing about?

title_talk: Shape-shifting tech will change work as we know it | Sean Follmer
description: What will the world look like when we move beyond the keyboard and mouse? Interaction designer Sean Follmer is building a future with machines that bring information to life under your fingers as you work with it. In this talk, check out prototypes for a 3D shape-shifting table, a phone that turns into a wristband, a deformable game controller and more that may change the way we live and work.
name: Sean Follmer: Shape-shifting tech will change work as we know it
title_vid: Shape-shifting tech will change work as we know it

title_talk: Are we in control of our decisions? | Dan Ariely
description: Behavioral economist Dan Ariely, the author of Predictably Irrational, uses classic visual illusions and his own counterintuitive (and sometimes shocking) research findings to show how we're not as rational as we think when we make decisions.
name: Dan Ariely: Are we in control of our own decisions?
title_vid: Are we in control of our own decisions?

title_talk: Andrew Stanton: The clues to a great story
description: Filmmaker Andrew Stanton ("Toy Story," "WALL-E") shares what he knows about storytelling -- starting at the end and working back to the beginning. Contains graphic language ... (Note: this talk is not available for download.)
name: Andrew Stanton: The clues to a great story
title_vid: The clues to a great story

title_talk: Chris Anderson (Wired): Technology's Long Tail
description: Chris Anderson, then the editor of Wired, explores the four key stages of any viable technology: setting the right price, gaining market share, displacing an established technology and, finally, becoming ubiquitous.
name: Chris Anderson: Technology's long tail
title_vid: Technology's long tail

title_talk: Ian Goldin: Navigating our global future
description: As globalization and technological advances bring us hurtling towards a new integrated future, Ian Goldin warns that not all people may benefit equally. But, he says, if we can recognize this danger, we might yet realize the possibility of improved life for everyone.
name: Ian Goldin: Navigating our global future
title_vid: Navigating our global future

title_talk: Don't fear superintelligent AI | Grady Booch
description: New tech spawns new anxieties, says scientist and philosopher Grady Booch, but we don't need to be afraid an all-powerful, unfeeling AI. Booch allays our worst (sci-fi induced) fears about superintelligent computers by explaining how we'll teach, not program, them to share our human values. Rather than worry about an unlikely existential threat, he urges us to consider how artificial intelligence will enhance human life.
name: Grady Booch: Don't fear superintelligent AI
title_vid: Don't fear superintelligent AI

title_talk: Marco Tempest: A magical tale (with augmented reality)
description: Marco Tempest spins a beautiful story of what magic is, how it entertains us and how it highlights our humanity -- all while working extraordinary illusions with his hands and an augmented reality machine.
name: Marco Tempest: A magical tale (with augmented reality)
title_vid: A magical tale (with augmented reality)

title_talk: Nancy Etcoff: Happiness and its surprises
description: Cognitive researcher Nancy Etcoff looks at happiness -- the ways we try to achieve and increase it, the way it's untethered to our real circumstances, and its surprising effect on our bodies.
name: Nancy Etcoff: Happiness and its surprises
title_vid: Happiness and its surprises

title_talk: The linguistic genius of babies | Patricia Kuhl
description: Patricia Kuhl shares astonishing findings about how babies learn one language over another -- by listening to the humans around them and "taking statistics" on the sounds they need to know. Clever lab experiments (and brain scans) show how 6-month-old babies use sophisticated reasoning to understand their world.
name: Patricia Kuhl: The linguistic genius of babies
title_vid: The linguistic genius of babies

title_talk: The surprising way groups like ISIS stay in power | Benedetta Berti
description: ISIS, Hezbollah, Hamas. These three very different groups are known for violence — but that’s only a portion of what they do, says policy analyst Benedetta Berti. They also attempt to win over populations with social work: setting up schools and hospitals, offering safety and security, and filling the gaps left by weak governments. Understanding the broader work of these groups suggests new strategies for ending the violence.
name: Benedetta Berti: The surprising way groups like ISIS stay in power
title_vid: The surprising way groups like ISIS stay in power

title_talk: Bandi Mbubi: Demand a fair trade cell phone
description: Your mobile phone, computer and game console have a bloody past — tied to tantalum mining, which funds the war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Drawing on his personal story, activist and refugee Bandi Mbubi gives a stirring call to action.
name: Bandi Mbubi: Demand a fair trade cell phone
title_vid: Demand a fair trade cell phone

title_talk: The real harm of the global arms trade | Samantha Nutt
description: In some parts of the world, it's easier to get an automatic rifle than a glass of clean drinking water. Is this just the way it is? Samantha Nutt, doctor and founder of the international humanitarian organization War Child, explores the global arms trade -- and suggests a bold, common sense solution for ending the cycle of violence. "War is ours," she says. "We buy it, sell it, spread it and wage it. We are therefore not powerless to solve it."
name: Samantha Nutt: The real harm of the global arms trade
title_vid: The real harm of the global arms trade

title_talk: Leonard Susskind: My friend Richard Feynman
description: What's it like to be pals with a genius? Physicist Leonard Susskind spins a few stories about his friendship with the legendary Richard Feynman, discussing his unconventional approach to problems both serious and ... less so.
name: Leonard Susskind: My friend Richard Feynman
title_vid: My friend Richard Feynman

title_talk: Amy Smith: Simple designs that could save millions of childrens' lives
description: Fumes from indoor cooking fires kill more than 2 million children a year in the developing world. MIT engineer Amy Smith details an exciting but simple solution: a tool for turning farm waste into clean-burning charcoal.
name: Amy Smith: Simple designs to save a life
title_vid: Simple designs to save a life

title_talk: The revolutionary power of diverse thought | Elif Shafak
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Paola Antonelli: Treating design as art
description: Paola Antonelli, design curator at New York's Museum of Modern Art, wants to spread her appreciation of design -- in all shapes and forms -- around the world.
name: Paola Antonelli: Treat design as art
title_vid: Treat design as art

title_talk: Edward Burtynsky photographs the landscape of oil
description: In stunning large-format photographs, Edward Burtynsky follows the path of oil through modern society, from wellhead to pipeline to car engine -- and then beyond to the projected peak-oil endgame.
name: Edward Burtynsky: Photographing the landscape of oil
title_vid: Photographing the landscape of oil

title_talk: Jennifer Pahlka: Coding a better government
description: Can government be run like the Internet, permissionless and open? Coder and activist Jennifer Pahlka believes it can -- and that apps, built quickly and cheaply, are a powerful new way to connect citizens to their governments -- and their neighbors.
name: Jennifer Pahlka: Coding a better government
title_vid: Coding a better government

title_talk: Love -- you're doing it wrong | Yann Dall'Aglio
description: In this delightful talk, philosopher Yann Dall'Aglio explores the universal search for tenderness and connection in a world that's ever more focused on the individual. As it turns out, it's easier than you think. A wise and witty reflection on the state of love in the modern age. In French with subtitles.
name: Yann Dall'Aglio: Love -- you're doing it wrong
title_vid: Love -- you're doing it wrong

title_talk: Alice Goffman: How we're priming some kids for college — and others for prison
description: In the United States, two institutions guide teenagers on the journey to adulthood: college and prison. Sociologist Alice Goffman spent six years in a troubled Philadelphia neighborhood and saw first-hand how teenagers of African-American and Latino backgrounds are funneled down the path to prison — sometimes starting with relatively minor infractions. In an impassioned talk she asks, "Why are we offering only handcuffs and jail time?"
name: Alice Goffman: How we're priming some kids for college — and others for prison
title_vid: How we're priming some kids for college — and others for prison

title_talk: John Hardy: My green school dream
description: Join John Hardy on a tour of the Green School, his off-the-grid school in Bali that teaches kids how to build, garden, create (and get into college). The centerpiece of campus is the spiraling Heart of School, perhaps the world's largest freestanding bamboo building.
name: John Hardy: My green school dream
title_vid: My green school dream

title_talk: Timothy Bartik: The economic case for preschool
description: In this well-argued talk, Timothy Bartik makes the macro-economic case for preschool education -- and explains why you should be happy to invest in it, even if you don't have kids that age (or kids at all). The economic benefits of well-educated kids, it turns out, go well beyond the altruistic.
name: Timothy Bartik: The economic case for preschool
title_vid: The economic case for preschool

title_talk: Mother and daughter doctor-heroes: Hawa Abdi + Deqo Mohamed
description: They've been called the "saints of Somalia." Doctor Hawa Abdi and her daughter Deqo Mohamed discuss their medical clinic in Somalia, where -- in the face of civil war and open oppression of women -- they've built a hospital, a school and a community of peace.
name: Hawa Abdi + Deqo Mohamed: Mother and daughter doctor-heroes
speaker_occupation: Somali doctors who treat women refugees
title_vid: Mother and daughter doctor-heroes

title_talk: Rose George: Inside the secret shipping industry
description: Almost everything we own and use, at some point, travels to us by container ship, through a vast network of ocean routes and ports that most of us know almost nothing about. Journalist Rose George tours us through the world of shipping, the underpinning of consumer civilization.
name: Rose George: Inside the secret shipping industry
title_vid: Inside the secret shipping industry

title_talk: Edi Rama: Take back your city with paint
description: Make a city beautiful, curb corruption. Edi Rama took this deceptively simple path as mayor of Tirana, Albania, where he instilled pride in his citizens by transforming public spaces with colorful designs.
name: Edi Rama: Take back your city with paint
title_vid: Take back your city with paint

title_talk: Barry Schwartz: Our loss of wisdom
description: Barry Schwartz makes a passionate call for "practical wisdom" as an antidote to a society gone mad with bureaucracy. He argues powerfully that rules often fail us, incentives often backfire, and practical, everyday wisdom will help rebuild our world.
name: Barry Schwartz: Our loss of wisdom
title_vid: Our loss of wisdom

title_talk: The single biggest reason why startups succeed | Bill Gross
description: Bill Gross has founded a lot of startups, and incubated many others -- and he got curious about why some succeeded and others failed. So he gathered data from hundreds of companies, his own and other people's, and ranked each company on five key factors. He found one factor that stands out from the others -- and surprised even him.
name: Bill Gross: The single biggest reason why startups succeed
title_vid: The single biggest reason why startups succeed

title_talk: Charmian Gooch: Meet global corruption's hidden players
description: When the son of the president of a desperately poor country starts buying mansions and sportscars on an official monthly salary of $7,000, Charmian Gooch suggests, corruption is probably somewhere in the picture. In a blistering, eye-opening talk (with several specific examples), she details how global corruption trackers follow the money -- to some surprisingly familiar faces.
name: Charmian Gooch: Meet global corruption's hidden players
title_vid: Meet global corruption's hidden players

title_talk: David Hoffman: Catch Sputnik mania!
description: Filmmaker David Hoffman shares footage from his feature-length documentary Sputnik Mania, which shows how the Soviet Union's launch of Sputnik in 1957 led to both the space race and the arms race -- and jump-started science and math education around the world.
name: David Hoffman: Sputnik mania
title_vid: Sputnik mania

title_talk: Topher White: What can save the rainforest? Your used cell phone
description: The sounds of the rainforest include: the chirps of birds, the buzz of cicadas, the banter of gibbons. But in the background is the almost-always present sound of a chainsaw, from illegal loggers. Engineer Topher White shares a simple, scalable way to stop this brutal deforestation — that starts with your old cell phone.
name: Topher White: What can save the rainforest? Your used cell phone
title_vid: What can save the rainforest? Your used cell phone

title_talk: Sangu Delle: In praise of macro -- yes, macro -- finance in Africa
description: In this short, provocative talk, financier Sangu Delle questions whether microfinance — small loans to small entrepreneurs -- is the best way to drive growth in developing countries. "We seem to be fixated on this romanticized idea that every poor person in Africa is an entrepreneur,” he says. "Yet, my work has taught me that most people want jobs.” Delle, a TED Fellow, makes the case for supporting large companies and factories — and clearing away the obstacles to pan-African trade.
name: Sangu Delle: In praise of macro -- yes, macro -- finance in Africa
title_vid: In praise of macro -- yes, macro -- finance in Africa

title_talk: Jay Walker on the world's English mania
description: Jay Walker explains why two billion people around the world are trying to learn English. He shares photos and spine-tingling audio of Chinese students rehearsing English -- "the world's second language" -- by the thousands.
name: Jay Walker: The world's English mania
title_vid: The world's English mania

title_talk: Ben Kacyra: Ancient wonders captured in 3D
description: Ancient monuments give us clues to astonishing past civilizations -- but they're under threat from pollution, war, neglect. Ben Kacyra, who invented a groundbreaking 3D scanning system, is using his invention to scan and preserve the world's heritage in archival detail. (Watch to the end for a little demo.)
name: Ben Kacyra: Ancient wonders captured in 3D
title_vid: Ancient wonders captured in 3D

title_talk: Erik Schlangen: A "self-healing" asphalt
description: Paved roads are nice to look at, but they're easily damaged and costly to repair. Erik Schlangen demos a new type of porous asphalt made of simple materials with an astonishing feature: When cracked, it can be "healed" by induction heating.
name: Erik Schlangen: A "self-healing" asphalt
title_vid: A "self-healing" asphalt

title_talk: Dr. Dean Ornish: Your genes are not your fate
description: Dean Ornish shares new research that shows how adopting healthy lifestyle habits can affect a person at a genetic level. For instance, he says, when you live healthier, eat better, exercise, and love more, your brain cells actually increase.
name: Dean Ornish: Your genes are not your fate
title_vid: Your genes are not your fate

title_talk: When we design for disability, we all benefit | Elise Roy
description: "I believe that losing my hearing was one of the greatest gifts I've ever received," says Elise Roy. As a disability rights lawyer and design thinker, she knows that being Deaf gives her a unique way of experiencing and reframing the world -- a perspective that could solve some of our largest problems. As she says: "When we design for disability first, you often stumble upon solutions that are better than those when we design for the norm."
name: Elise Roy: When we design for disability, we all benefit
title_vid: When we design for disability, we all benefit

title_talk: Depression, the secret we share | Andrew Solomon
description: "The opposite of depression is not happiness, but vitality, and it was vitality that seemed to seep away from me in that moment." In a talk equal parts eloquent and devastating, writer Andrew Solomon takes you to the darkest corners of his mind during the years he battled depression. That led him to an eye-opening journey across the world to interview others with depression -- only to discover that, to his surprise, the more he talked, the more people wanted to tell their own stories.
name: Andrew Solomon: Depression, the secret we share
title_vid: Depression, the secret we share

title_talk: Anne Milgram: Why smart statistics are the key to fighting crime
description: When she became the attorney general of New Jersey in 2007, Anne Milgram quickly discovered a few startling facts: not only did her team not really know who they were putting in jail, but they had no way of understanding if their decisions were actually making the public safer. And so began her ongoing, inspirational quest to bring data analytics and statistical analysis to the US criminal justice system.
name: Anne Milgram: Why smart statistics are the key to fighting crime
title_vid: Why smart statistics are the key to fighting crime

title_talk: Ray Zahab treks to the South Pole
description: Extreme runner Ray Zahab shares an enthusiastic account of his record-breaking trek on foot to the South Pole -- a 33-day sprint through the snow.
name: Ray Zahab: My trek to the South Pole
title_vid: My trek to the South Pole

title_talk: Jay Silver: Hack a banana, make a keyboard!
description: Why can't two slices of pizza be used as a slide clicker? Why shouldn't you make music with ketchup? In this charming talk, inventor Jay Silver talks about the urge to play with the world around you. He shares some of his messiest inventions, and demos MaKey MaKey, a kit for hacking everyday objects.
name: Jay Silver: Hack a banana, make a keyboard!
title_vid: Hack a banana, make a keyboard!

title_talk: A hilarious celebration of lifelong female friendship | Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin
description: Legendary duo Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin have been friends for decades. In a raw, tender and wide-ranging conversation hosted by Pat Mitchell, the three discuss longevity, feminism, the differences between male and female friendship, what it means to live well and women's role in future of our planet. "I don't even know what I would do without my women friends," Fonda says. "I exist because I have my women friends."
name: Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin: A hilarious celebration of lifelong female friendship
