In an eloquent meditation she scours pages from literature to show how jealousy is not so different from a quest for knowledge.
name: Parul Sehgal: An ode to envy
title_vid: An ode to envy

title_talk: Bruce Feiler: Agile programming -- for your family
description: Bruce Feiler has a radical idea: To deal with the stress of modern family life, go agile. Inspired by agile software programming, Feiler introduces family practices which encourage flexibility, bottom-up idea flow, constant feedback and accountability. One surprising feature: Kids pick their own punishments.
name: Bruce Feiler: Agile programming -- for your family
title_vid: Agile programming -- for your family

title_talk: How do you build a sacred space? | Siamak Hariri
description: To design the Bahá'í Temple of South America, architect Siamak Hariri focused on illumination -- from the temple's form, which captures the movement of the sun throughout the day, to the iridescent, luminous stone and glass used to construct it. Join Hariri for a journey through the creative process, as he explores what makes for a sacred experience in a secular world.
name: Siamak Hariri: How do you build a sacred space?
title_vid: How do you build a sacred space?

title_talk: Uber's plan to get more people into fewer cars | Travis Kalanick
description: Uber didn't start out with grand ambitions to cut congestion and pollution. But as the company took off, co-founder Travis Kalanick wondered if there was a way to get people using Uber along the same routes to share rides, reducing costs and carbon footprint along the way. The result: uberPOOL, the company's carpooling service, which in its first eight months took 7.9 million miles off the roads and 1,400 metric tons of carbon dioxide out of the air in Los Angeles. Now, Kalanick says carpooling could work for commuters in the suburbs, too. "With the technology in our pockets today, and a little smart regulation," he says, "we can turn every car into a shared car, and we can reclaim our cities starting today."
name: Travis Kalanick: Uber's plan to get more people into fewer cars
title_vid: Uber's plan to get more people into fewer cars

title_talk: Roz Savage: Why I'm rowing across the Pacific
description: Five years ago, Roz Savage quit her high-powered London job to become an ocean rower. She's crossed the Atlantic solo, and just started the third leg of a Pacific solo row, the first for a woman. Why does she do it? Hear her reasons, both deeply personal and urgently activist.
name: Roz Savage: Why I'm rowing across the Pacific
title_vid: Why I'm rowing across the Pacific

title_talk: Jackie Tabick: The balancing act of compassion
description: While we all agree that compassion is a great idea, Rabbi Tabick acknowledges there are challenges to its execution. She explains how a careful balance of compassion and justice allows us to do good deeds, and keep our sanity.
name: Jackie Tabick: The balancing act of compassion
title_vid: The balancing act of compassion

title_talk: Bart Knols: Cheese, dogs and a pill to kill mosquitoes and end malaria
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Beverly + Dereck Joubert: Life lessons from big cats
description: Beverly + Dereck Joubert live in the bush, filming and photographing lions and leopards in their natural habitat. With stunning footage (some never before seen), they discuss their personal relationships with these majestic animals -- and their quest to save the big cats from human threats.
name: Beverly + Dereck Joubert: Life lessons from big cats
title_vid: Life lessons from big cats

title_talk: New experiments in self-teaching | Sugata Mitra
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: How frustration can make us more creative | Tim Harford
description: Challenges and problems can derail your creative process ... or they can make you more creative than ever. In the surprising story behind the best-selling solo piano album of all time, Tim Harford may just convince you of the advantages of having to work with a little mess.
name: Tim Harford: How frustration can make us more creative
title_vid: How frustration can make us more creative

title_talk: These Robots Come to the Rescue after a Disaster | Robin Murphy | TED Talks
description: When disaster strikes, who's first on the scene? More and more, it’s a robot. In her lab, Robin Murphy builds robots that fly, tunnel, swim and crawl through disaster scenes, helping firefighters and rescue workers save more lives safely -- and help communities return to normal up to three years faster.
name: Robin Murphy: These robots come to the rescue after a disaster
title_vid: These robots come to the rescue after a disaster

title_talk: Depressed dogs, cats with OCD -- what animal madness means for us humans | Laurel Braitman
description: Behind those funny animal videos, sometimes, are oddly human-like problems. Laurel Braitman studies non-human animals who exhibit signs of mental health issues -- from compulsive bears to self-destructive rats to monkeys with unlikely friends. Braitman asks what we as humans can learn from watching animals cope with depression, sadness and other all-too-human problems.
name: Laurel Braitman: Depressed dogs, cats with OCD — what animal madness means for us humans
title_vid: Depressed dogs, cats with OCD — what animal madness means for us humans

title_talk: Would you live in a floating city in the sky? (with English subtitles) | Tomás Saraceno
description: In a mind-bending talk that blurs the line between science and art, Tomás Saraceno exhibits a series of air-inspired sculptures and installations designed to usher in a new era of sustainability, the "Aerocene." From giant, cloud-like playgrounds suspended 22 meters in the air to a balloon sculpture that travels the world without burning a single drop of fossil fuel, Saraceno's work invites us to explore the bounds of our fragile human and terrestrial ecosystems. (In Spanish with English subtitles.)
name: Tomás Saraceno: Would you live in a floating city in the sky?
title_vid: Would you live in a floating city in the sky?

title_talk: A guerilla gardener in South Central LA | Ron Finley
description: Ron Finley plants vegetable gardens in South Central LA -- in abandoned lots, traffic medians, along the curbs. Why? For fun, for defiance, for beauty and to offer some alternative to fast food in a community where "the drive-thrus are killing more people than the drive-bys."
name: Ron Finley: A guerilla gardener in South Central LA
title_vid: A guerilla gardener in South Central LA

title_talk: How the US should use its superpower status | Ian Bremmer
description: Americanization and globalization have basically been the same thing for the last several generations. But the US's view of the world -- and the world's view of the US -- is changing. In a fast-paced tour of the current state of international politics, Ian Bremmer discusses the challenges of a world where no single country or alliance can meet the challenges of global leadership and asks if the US is ready to lead by example, not by force.
name: Ian Bremmer: How the US should use its superpower status
title_vid: How the US should use its superpower status

title_talk: Elizabeth Murchison: Fighting a contagious cancer
description: What is killing the Tasmanian devil? A virulent cancer is infecting them by the thousands  -- and unlike most cancers, it's contagious. Researcher Elizabeth Murchison tells us how she's fighting to save the Taz, and what she's learning about all cancers from this unusual strain. Contains disturbing images of facial cancer.
name: Elizabeth Murchison: Fighting a contagious cancer
title_vid: Fighting a contagious cancer

title_talk: What will future jobs look like? | Andrew McAfee
description: Economist Andrew McAfee suggests that, yes, probably, droids will take our jobs -- or at least the kinds of jobs we know now. In this far-seeing talk, he thinks through what future jobs might look like, and how to educate coming generations to hold them.
name: Andrew McAfee: What will future jobs look like?
title_vid: What will future jobs look like?

title_talk: The emergence of "4D printing" | Skylar Tibbits
description: 3D printing has grown in sophistication since the late 1970s; TED Fellow Skylar Tibbits is shaping the next development, which he calls 4D printing, where the fourth dimension is time. This emerging technology will allow us to print objects that then reshape themselves or self-assemble over time. Think: a printed cube that folds before your eyes, or a printed pipe able to sense the need to expand or contract.
name: Skylar Tibbits: The emergence of "4D printing"
title_vid: The emergence of "4D printing"

title_talk: Mark Shaw: One very dry demo
description: Mark Shaw demos Ultra-Ever Dry, a liquid-repellent coating that acts as an astonishingly powerful shield against water and water-based materials. At the nano level, the spray covers a surface with an umbrella of air so that water bounces right off. Watch for an exciting two-minute kicker.
name: Mark Shaw: One very dry demo
title_vid: One very dry demo

title_talk: All it takes is 10 mindful minutes | Andy Puddicombe
description: When is the last time you did absolutely nothing for 10 whole minutes? Not texting, talking or even thinking? Mindfulness expert Andy Puddicombe describes the transformative power of doing just that: Refreshing your mind for 10 minutes a day, simply by being mindful and experiencing the present moment. (No need for incense or sitting in uncomfortable positions.)
name: Andy Puddicombe: All it takes is 10 mindful minutes
title_vid: All it takes is 10 mindful minutes

title_talk: What we learned from 5 million books
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: How to rob a bank (from the inside, that is) | William Black
description: William Black is a former bank regulator who’s seen firsthand how banking systems can be used to commit fraud — and how “liar's loans” and other tricky tactics led to the 2008 US banking crisis that threatened the international economy. In this engaging talk, Black, now an academic, reveals the best way to rob a bank — from the inside.
name: William Black: How to rob a bank (from the inside, that is)
title_vid: How to rob a bank (from the inside, that is)

title_talk: The puzzle of motivation | Dan Pink
description: Career analyst Dan Pink examines the puzzle of motivation, starting with a fact that social scientists know but most managers don't: Traditional rewards aren't always as effective as we think. Listen for illuminating stories -- and maybe, a way forward.
name: Dan Pink: The puzzle of motivation
title_vid: The puzzle of motivation

title_talk: John Doerr: Seeking salvation and profit in greentech
description: "I don't think we're going to make it," John Doerr says in an emotional talk about climate change and investment. To create a world fit for his daughter to live in, he says, we need to invest now in clean, green energy.
name: John Doerr: Salvation (and profit) in greentech
title_vid: Salvation (and profit) in greentech

title_talk: Euvin Naidoo: Africa as an investment
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The Enchanting Music of Sign Language | Christine Sun Kim | TED Talks
description: Artist and TED Fellow Christine Sun Kim was born deaf, and she was taught to believe that sound wasn't a part of her life, that it was a hearing person's thing. Through her art, she discovered similarities between American Sign Language and music, and she realized that sound doesn't have to be known solely through the ears -- it can be felt, seen and experienced as an idea. In this endearing talk, she invites us to open our eyes and ears and participate in the rich treasure of visual language.
name: Christine Sun Kim: The enchanting music of sign language
title_vid: The enchanting music of sign language

title_talk: How the US government spies on people who protest -- including you | Jennifer Granick
description: What's stopping the American government from recording your phone calls, reading your emails and monitoring your location? Very little, says surveillance and cybersecurity counsel Jennifer Granick. The government collects all kinds of information about you easily, cheaply and without a warrant -- and if you've ever participated in a protest or attended a gun show, you're likely a person of interest. Learn more about your rights, your risks and how to protect yourself in the golden age of surveillance.
name: Jennifer Granick: How the US government spies on people who protest -- including you
title_vid: How the US government spies on people who protest -- including you

title_talk: When Black women walk, things change | T. Morgan Dixon and Vanessa Garrison
description: T. Morgan Dixon and Vanessa Garrison, founders of the health nonprofit GirlTrek, are on a mission to reduce the leading causes of preventable death among Black women -- and build communities in the process. How? By getting one million women and girls to prioritize their self-care, lacing up their shoes and walking in the direction of their healthiest, most fulfilled lives.
main_speaker: T. Morgan Dixon and Vanessa Garrison
name: T. Morgan Dixon and Vanessa Garrison: When Black women walk, things change
title_vid: When Black women walk, things change

title_talk: How a handful of tech companies control billions of minds every day | Tristan Harris
description: A handful of people working at a handful of tech companies steer the thoughts of billions of people every day, says design thinker Tristan Harris. From Facebook notifications to Snapstreaks to YouTube autoplays, they're all competing for one thing: your attention. Harris shares how these companies prey on our psychology for their own profit and calls for a design renaissance in which our tech instead encourages us to live out the timeline we want.
name: Tristan Harris: How a handful of tech companies control billions of minds every day
title_vid: How a handful of tech companies control billions of minds every day

title_talk: Bill Ford: A future beyond traffic gridlock
description: Bill Ford is a car guy -- his great-grandfather was Henry Ford, and he grew up inside the massive Ford Motor Co. So when he worries about cars' impact on the environment, and about our growing global gridlock problem, it's worth a listen. His vision for the future of mobility includes "smart roads," even smarter public transport and going green like never before.
name: Bill Ford: A future beyond traffic gridlock
title_vid: A future beyond traffic gridlock

title_talk: Halla Tomasdottir: A feminine response to Iceland's financial crash
description: Halla Tómasdóttir managed to take her company Audur Capital through the eye of the financial storm in Iceland by applying 5 traditionally "feminine" values to financial services. At TEDWomen, she talks about these values and the importance of balance.
name: Halla Tómasdóttir: A feminine response to Iceland's financial crash
title_vid: A feminine response to Iceland's financial crash

title_talk: Why videos go viral | Kevin Allocca
description: Kevin Allocca is YouTube's trends manager, and he has deep thoughts about silly web video. In this talk from TEDYouth, he shares the 4 reasons a video goes viral.
name: Kevin Allocca: Why videos go viral
title_vid: Why videos go viral

title_talk: What a planet needs to sustain life | Dave Brain
description: "Venus is too hot, Mars is too cold, and Earth is just right," says planetary scientist Dave Brain. But why? In this pleasantly humorous talk, Brain explores the fascinating science behind what it takes for a planet to host life -- and why humanity may just be in the right place at the right time when it comes to the timeline of life-sustaining planets.
name: Dave Brain: What a planet needs to sustain life
title_vid: What a planet needs to sustain life

title_talk: Our failing schools. Enough is enough! | Geoffrey Canada
description: Why, why, why does our education system look so similar to the way it did 50 years ago? Millions of students were failing then, as they are now -- and it’s because we’re clinging to a business model that clearly doesn’t work. Education advocate Geoffrey Canada dares the system to look at the data, think about the customers and make systematic shifts in order to help greater numbers of kids excel.
name: Geoffrey Canada: Our failing schools. Enough is enough!
title_vid: Our failing schools. Enough is enough!

title_talk: New nanotech to detect cancer early | Joshua Smith
description: What if every home had an early-warning cancer detection system? Researcher Joshua Smith is developing a nanobiotechnology "cancer alarm" that scans for traces of disease in the form of special biomarkers called exosomes. In this forward-thinking talk, he shares his dream for how we might revolutionize cancer detection and, ultimately, save lives.
name: Joshua Smith: New nanotech to detect cancer early
title_vid: New nanotech to detect cancer early

title_talk: Ryan Lobo: Photographing the hidden story
description: Ryan Lobo has traveled the world, taking photographs that tell stories of unusual human lives. In this haunting talk, he reframes controversial subjects with empathy, so that we see the pain of a Liberian war criminal, the quiet strength of UN women peacekeepers and the perseverance of Delhi's underappreciated firefighters.
name: Ryan Lobo: Photographing the hidden story
title_vid: Photographing the hidden story

title_talk: What time is it on Mars? | Nagin Cox
description: Nagin Cox is a first-generation Martian. As a spacecraft engineer at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Cox works on the team that manages the United States' rovers on Mars. But working a 9-to-5 on another planet -- whose day is 40 minutes longer than Earth's -- has particular, often comical challenges.
name: Nagin Cox: What time is it on Mars?
title_vid: What time is it on Mars?

title_talk: How to make a profit while making a difference | Audrey Choi
description: Can global capital markets become catalysts for social change? According to investment expert Audrey Choi, individuals own almost half of all global capital, giving them (us!) the power to make a difference by investing in companies that champion social values and sustainability. "We have more opportunity today than ever before to make choices," she says. "So change your perspective. Invest in the change you want to see in the world."
name: Audrey Choi: How to make a profit while making a difference
title_vid: How to make a profit while making a difference

title_talk: Maajid Nawaz: A global culture to fight extremism
description: Why do transnational extremist organizations succeed where democratic movements have a harder time taking hold? Maajid Nawaz, a former Islamist extremist, asks for new grassroots stories and global social activism to spread democracy in the face of nationalism and xenophobia.
name: Maajid Nawaz: A global culture to fight extremism
title_vid: A global culture to fight extremism

title_talk: My Inner Life with Asperger's | Alix Generous | TED Talks
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Stew: "Black Men Ski"
description: What happens when a black man visits Aspen? Singer/songwriter Stew and his band are about to let you know.
name: Stew: "Black Men Ski"
title_vid: "Black Men Ski"

title_talk: Jose Miguel Sokoloff: How we used Christmas lights to fight a war
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Success, failure and the drive to keep creating | Elizabeth Gilbert
description: Elizabeth Gilbert was once an "unpublished diner waitress," devastated by rejection letters. And yet, in the wake of the success of 'Eat, Pray, Love,' she found herself identifying strongly with her former self. With beautiful insight, Gilbert reflects on why success can be as disorienting as failure and offers a simple -- though hard -- way to carry on, regardless of outcomes.
name: Elizabeth Gilbert: Success, failure and the drive to keep creating
title_vid: Success, failure and the drive to keep creating

title_talk: R.A. Mashelkar: Breakthrough designs for ultra-low-cost products
description: Engineer RA Mashelkar shares three stories of ultra-low-cost design from India that use bottom-up rethinking, and some clever engineering, to bring expensive products (cars, prosthetics) into the realm of the possible for everyone.
name: R.A. Mashelkar: Breakthrough designs for ultra-low-cost products
title_vid: Breakthrough designs for ultra-low-cost products

title_talk: Greening the ghetto | Majora Carter
description: In an emotionally charged talk, MacArthur-winning activist Majora Carter details her fight for environmental justice in the South Bronx -- and shows how minority neighborhoods suffer most from flawed urban policy.
name: Majora Carter: Greening the ghetto
title_vid: Greening the ghetto

title_talk: Peter Diamandis: Taking the next giant leap in space
description: Peter Diamandis says it's our moral imperative to keep exploring space -- and he talks about how, with the X Prize and other incentives, we're going to do just that.
name: Peter Diamandis: Our next giant leap
title_vid: Our next giant leap

title_talk: Chris McKnett: The investment logic for sustainability
description: Sustainability is pretty clearly one of the world's most important goals; but what groups can really make environmental progress in leaps and bounds? Chris McKnett makes the case that it's large institutional investors. He shows how strong financial data isn't enough, and reveals why investors need to look at a company's environmental, social and governance structures, too.
name: Chris McKnett: The investment logic for sustainability
title_vid: The investment logic for sustainability

title_talk: Sean Gourley on the mathematics of war
description: By analyzing raw data on violent incidents in the Iraq war and others, Sean Gourley and his team claim to have found a surprisingly strong mathematical relationship linking the fatality and frequency of attacks.
name: Sean Gourley: The mathematics of war
title_vid: The mathematics of war

title_talk: The unheard story of David and Goliath | Malcolm Gladwell
description: It's a classic underdog tale: David, a young shepherd armed only with a sling, beats Goliath, the mighty warrior. The story has transcended its biblical origins to become a common shorthand for unlikely victory. But, asks Malcolm Gladwell, is that really what the David and Goliath story is about?
name: Malcolm Gladwell: The unheard story of David and Goliath
title_vid: The unheard story of David and Goliath

title_talk: The hidden power of smiling | Ron Gutman
description: Ron Gutman reviews a raft of studies about smiling, and reveals some surprising results. Did you know your smile can be a predictor of how long you'll live -- and that a simple smile has a measurable effect on your overall well-being? Prepare to flex a few facial muscles as you learn more about this evolutionarily contagious behavior.
name: Ron Gutman: The hidden power of smiling
title_vid: The hidden power of smiling

title_talk: Nina Tandon: Could tissue engineering mean personalized medicine?
description: Each of our bodies is utterly unique, which is a lovely thought until it comes to treating an illness -- when every body reacts differently, often unpredictably, to standard treatment. Tissue engineer Nina Tandon talks about a possible solution: Using pluripotent stem cells to make personalized models of organs on which to test new drugs and treatments, and storing them on computer chips. (Call it extremely personalized medicine.)
name: Nina Tandon: Could tissue engineering mean personalized medicine?
title_vid: Could tissue engineering mean personalized medicine?

title_talk: David Brooks: Should you live for your résumé ... or your eulogy?
description: Within each of us are two selves, suggests David Brooks in this meditative short talk: the self who craves success, who builds a résumé, and the self who seeks connection, community, love -- the values that make for a great eulogy. (Joseph Soloveitchik has called these selves "Adam I" and "Adam II.") Brooks asks: Can we balance these two selves?
name: David Brooks: Should you live for your résumé ... or your eulogy?
title_vid: Should you live for your résumé ... or your eulogy?

title_talk: Erin McKean: The joy of lexicography
description: Is the beloved paper dictionary doomed to extinction? In this infectiously exuberant talk, leading lexicographer Erin McKean looks at the many ways today's print dictionary is poised for transformation.
name: Erin McKean: The joy of lexicography
title_vid: The joy of lexicography

title_talk: Ash Beckham: We're all hiding something. Let's find the courage to open up
description: In this touching talk, Ash Beckham offers a fresh approach to empathy and openness. It starts with understanding that everyone, at some point in their life, has experienced hardship. The only way out, says Beckham, is to open the door and step out of your closet.
name: Ash Beckham: We're all hiding something. Let's find the courage to open up
title_vid: We're all hiding something. Let's find the courage to open up

title_talk: Jamais Cascio: Tools for building a better world
description: We all want to make the world better -- but how? Jamais Cascio looks at some specific tools and techniques that can make a difference. It's a fascinating talk that might just inspire you to act.
name: Jamais Cascio: Tools for a better world
title_vid: Tools for a better world

title_talk: Jessa Gamble: Our natural sleep cycle
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Marc Koska: 1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe
description: Reuse of syringes, all too common in under-funded clinics, kills 1.3 million each year. Marc Koska clues us in to this devastating global problem with facts, photos and hidden-camera footage. He shares his solution: a low-cost syringe that can't be used twice.
name: Marc Koska: 1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe
title_vid: 1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe

title_talk: Sarah Jones: What does the future hold? 11 characters offer quirky answers
description: Sarah Jones changes personas with the simplest of wardrobe swaps. In a laugh-out-loud improvisation, she invites 11 "friends" from the future on stage—from a fast-talking Latina to an outspoken police officer—to ask them questions supplied by the TED2014 audience.
name: Sarah Jones: What does the future hold? 11 characters offer quirky answers
title_vid: What does the future hold? 11 characters offer quirky answers

title_talk: Caroline Phillips: Hurdy-gurdy for beginners
description: Caroline Phillips cranks out tunes on a seldom-heard folk instrument: the hurdy-gurdy, a.k.a. the wheel fiddle. A searching, Basque melody follows her fun lesson on its unique anatomy and 1,000-year history.
name: Caroline Phillips: Hurdy-gurdy for beginners
title_vid: Hurdy-gurdy for beginners

title_talk: David Bismark: E-voting without fraud
description: David Bismark demos a new system for voting that contains a simple, verifiable way to prevent fraud and miscounting -- while keeping each person's vote secret.
name: David Bismark: E-voting without fraud
title_vid: E-voting without fraud

title_talk: James Lyne: Everyday cybercrime -- and what you can do about it
description: How do you pick up a malicious online virus, the kind of malware that snoops on your data and taps your bank account? Often, it's through simple things you do each day without thinking twice. James Lyne reminds us that it's not only the NSA that's watching us, but ever-more-sophisticated cybercriminals, who exploit both weak code and trusting human nature.
name: James Lyne: Everyday cybercrime -- and what you can do about it
title_vid: Everyday cybercrime -- and what you can do about it

title_talk: How autism freed me to be myself | Rosie King
description: “People are so afraid of variety that they try to fit everything into a tiny little box with a specific label,” says 16-year-old Rosie King, who is bold, brash and autistic. She wants to know: Why is everyone so worried about being normal? She sounds a clarion call for every kid, parent, teacher and person to celebrate uniqueness. It’s a soaring testament to the potential of human diversity.
name: Rosie King: How autism freed me to be myself
title_vid: How autism freed me to be myself

title_talk: Ludwick Marishane: A bath without water
description: If you had to walk a mile for a jug of water every day, as millions of people do, it's unlikely you'd use that precious water to bathe. Young entrepreneur Ludwick Marishane tells the amazing, funny story of how he invented a cheap, clean and convenient solution: DryBath, the world's first bath-substituting lotion.
name: Ludwick Marishane: A bath without water
title_vid: A bath without water

title_talk: Aimee Mullins: Changing my legs - and my mindset
description: In this TED archive video from 1998, paralympic sprinter Aimee Mullins talks about her record-setting career as a runner, and about the amazing carbon-fiber prosthetic legs (then a prototype) that helped her cross the finish line.
name: Aimee Mullins: Changing my legs - and my mindset
title_vid: Changing my legs - and my mindset

title_talk: A forgotten Space Age technology could change how we grow food | Lisa Dyson
description: We're heading for a world population of 10 billion people -- but what will we all eat? Lisa Dyson rediscovered an idea developed by NASA in the 1960s for deep-space travel, and it could be a key to reinventing how we grow food.
name: Lisa Dyson: A forgotten Space Age technology could change how we grow food
title_vid: A forgotten Space Age technology could change how we grow food

title_talk: Charles Leadbeater: Education innovation in the slums
description: Charles Leadbeater went looking for radical new forms of education -- and found them in the slums of Rio and Kibera, where some of the world's poorest kids are finding transformative new ways to learn. And this informal, disruptive new kind of school, he says, is what all schools need to become.
name: Charles Leadbeater: Education innovation in the slums
title_vid: Education innovation in the slums

title_talk: Nick Veasey: Exposing the invisible
description: Nick Veasey shows outsized X-ray images that reveal the otherworldly inner workings of familiar objects -- from the geometry of a wildflower to the anatomy of a Boeing 747. Producing these photos is dangerous and painstaking, but the reward is a superpower: looking at what the human eye can't see.
name: Nick Veasey: Exposing the invisible
title_vid: Exposing the invisible

title_talk: Wisdom from great writers on every year of life | Joshua Prager
description: As different as we humans are from one another, we all age along the same great sequence, and the shared patterns of our lives pass into the pages of the books we love. In this moving talk, journalist Joshua Prager explores the stages of life through quotations from Norman Mailer, Joyce Carol Oates, William Trevor and other great writers, set to visualizations by graphic designer Milton Glaser. "Books tell us who we've been, who we are, who we will be, too," Prager says.
name: Joshua Prager: Wisdom from great writers on every year of life
title_vid: Wisdom from great writers on every year of life

title_talk: Innovating to zero! | Bill Gates
description: At TED2010, Bill Gates unveils his vision for the world's energy future, describing the need for "miracles" to avoid planetary catastrophe and explaining why he's backing a dramatically different type of nuclear reactor. The necessary goal? Zero carbon emissions globally by 2050.
name: Bill Gates: Innovating to zero!
title_vid: Innovating to zero!

title_talk: Steven Strogatz: How things in nature tend to sync up
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Laws that choke creativity | Larry Lessig
description: Lawrence Lessig, the Net’s most celebrated lawyer, cites John Philip Sousa, celestial copyrights and the "ASCAP cartel" in his argument for reviving our creative culture.
name: Lawrence Lessig: Laws that choke creativity
title_vid: Laws that choke creativity

title_talk: George Dyson: Let's take a nuclear-powered rocket to Saturn
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Gayle Tzemach Lemmon: Meet the first women to fight on the front lines of an American war
description: In 2011, the US Armed Forces still had a ban on women in combat -- but in that year, a Special Operations team of women was sent to Afghanistan to serve on the front lines, to build rapport with locals and try to help bring an end to the war. Reporter Gayle Tzemach Lemmon tells the story of this "band of sisters," an extraordinary group of women warriors who helped break a long-standing barrier to serve.
name: Gayle Tzemach Lemmon: Meet the women fighting on the front lines of an American war
title_vid: Meet the women fighting on the front lines of an American war

title_talk: How do you explain consciousness? | David Chalmers
description: Our consciousness is a fundamental aspect of our existence, says philosopher David Chalmers: “There’s nothing we know about more directly…. but at the same time it’s the most mysterious phenomenon in the universe.” He shares some ways to think about the movie playing in our heads.
name: David Chalmers: How do you explain consciousness?
title_vid: How do you explain consciousness?

title_talk: Choice, happiness and spaghetti sauce | Malcolm Gladwell
description: "Tipping Point" author Malcolm Gladwell gets inside the food industry's pursuit of the perfect spaghetti sauce -- and makes a larger argument about the nature of choice and happiness.
name: Malcolm Gladwell: Choice, happiness and spaghetti sauce
title_vid: Choice, happiness and spaghetti sauce

title_talk: I love being a police officer, but we need reform | Melvin Russell
description: We've invested so much in police departments as protectors that we have forgotten what it means to serve our communities, says Baltimore Police officer Lt. Colonel Melvin Russell. It's led to coldness and callousness, and it's dehumanized the police force. After taking over as district commander in one of Baltimore's toughest neighborhoods, Russell instituted a series of reforms aimed at winning back the trust of the community and lowering the violent crime rate. "Law enforcement is in a crisis," he says. "But it's not too late for all of us to build our cities and nation to make it great again."
name: Melvin Russell: I love being a police officer, but we need reform
speaker_occupation: Chief of the Community Partnership Division, Baltimore Police Department
title_vid: I love being a police officer, but we need reform

title_talk: The top 10 TED Talks of 2016
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Why great architecture should tell a story | Ole Scheeren
description: For architect Ole Scheeren, the people who live and work inside a building are as much a part of that building as concrete, steel and glass. He asks: Can architecture be about collaboration and storytelling instead of the isolation and hierarchy of a typical skyscraper? Visit five of Scheeren's buildings -- from a twisted tower in China to a floating cinema in the ocean in Thailand -- and learn the stories behind them.
name: Ole Scheeren: Why great architecture should tell a story
title_vid: Why great architecture should tell a story

title_talk: Eddi Reader & Thomas Dolby: "What You Do With What You've Got"
description: Singer/songwriter Eddi Reader performs "What You Do With What You've Got," a meditation on a very TED theme: how to use your gifts and talents to make a difference. With Thomas Dolby on piano.
name: Eddi Reader: "What You've Got"
title_vid: "What You've Got"

title_talk: Mosquitos, malaria and education | Bill Gates
description: Bill Gates hopes to solve some of the world's biggest problems using a new kind of philanthropy. In a passionate and, yes, funny 18 minutes, he asks us to consider two big questions and how we might answer them. (And see the Q&A on the TED Blog.)
name: Bill Gates: Mosquitos, malaria and education
title_vid: Mosquitos, malaria and education

title_talk: The agony of trying to unsubscribe | James Veitch
description: It happens to all of us: you unsubscribe from an unwanted marketing email, and a few days later another message from the same company pops up in your inbox. Comedian James Veitch turned this frustration into whimsy when a local supermarket refused to take no for an answer. Hijinks ensued.
name: James Veitch: The agony of trying to unsubscribe
title_vid: The agony of trying to unsubscribe

title_talk: It's time for women to run for office | Halla Tómasdóttir
description: With warmth and wit, Halla Tómasdóttir shares how she overcame media bias, changed the tone of the political debate and surprised her entire nation when she ran for president of Iceland -- inspiring the next generation of leaders along the way. "What we see, we can be," she says. "It matters that women run."
name: Halla Tómasdóttir: It's time for women to run for office
title_vid: It's time for women to run for office

title_talk: Moshe Safdie: How to reinvent the apartment building
description: In 1967, Moshe Safdie reimagined the monolithic apartment building, creating “Habitat ’67,” which gave each unit an unprecedented sense of openness. Nearly 50 years later, he believes the need for this type of building is greater than ever. In this short talk, Safdie surveys a range of projects that do away with the high-rise and let light permeate into densely-packed cities.
name: Moshe Safdie: How to reinvent the apartment building
title_vid: How to reinvent the apartment building

title_talk: Nizar Ibrahim: How we unearthed the spinosaurus
description: A 50-foot-long carnivore who hunted its prey in rivers 97 million years ago, the Spinosaurus is a "dragon from deep time." Paleontologist Nizar Ibrahim and his crew found new fossils, hidden in cliffs of the Moroccan Sahara desert, that are helping us learn more about the first swimming dinosaur -- who might also be the largest carnivorous dinosaur of all.
name: Nizar Ibrahim: How we unearthed the Spinosaurus
title_vid: How we unearthed the Spinosaurus

title_talk: Tim Berners-Lee: The year open data went worldwide
description: At TED2009, Tim Berners-Lee called for "raw data now" -- for governments, scientists and institutions to make their data openly available on the web. At TED University in 2010, he shows a few of the interesting results when the data gets linked up.
name: Tim Berners-Lee: The year open data went worldwide
title_vid: The year open data went worldwide

title_talk: Marcus du Sautoy: Symmetry, reality's riddle
description: The world turns on symmetry -- from the spin of subatomic particles to the dizzying beauty of an arabesque. But there's more to it than meets the eye. Here, Oxford mathematician Marcus du Sautoy offers a glimpse of the invisible numbers that marry all symmetrical objects.
name: Marcus du Sautoy: Symmetry, reality's riddle
title_vid: Symmetry, reality's riddle

title_talk: How jails extort the poor | Salil Dudani
description: Why do we jail people for being poor? Today, half a million Americans are in jail only because they can't afford to post bail, and still more are locked up because they can't pay their debt to the court, sometimes for things as minor as unpaid parking tickets. Salil Dudani shares stories from individuals who have experienced debtors' prison in Ferguson, Missouri, challenging us to think differently about how we punish the poor and marginalized.
name: Salil Dudani: How jails extort the poor
title_vid: How jails extort the poor

title_talk: Stefan Sagmeister: Designing with slogans
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Robert Thurman: Expanding your circle of compassion
description: It's hard to always show compassion -- even to the people we love, but Robert Thurman asks that we develop compassion for our enemies. He prescribes a seven-step meditation exercise to extend compassion beyond our inner circle.
name: Robert Thurman: Expanding your circle of compassion
title_vid: Expanding your circle of compassion

title_talk: Geoffrey West: The surprising math of cities and corporations
description: Physicist Geoffrey West has found that simple, mathematical laws govern the properties of cities -- that wealth, crime rate, walking speed and many other aspects of a city can be deduced from a single number: the city's population. In this mind-bending talk from TEDGlobal he shows how it works and how similar laws hold for organisms and corporations.
name: Geoffrey West: The surprising math of cities and corporations
title_vid: The surprising math of cities and corporations

title_talk: Marc Pachter: The art of the interview
description: Marc Pachter has conducted live interviews with some of the most intriguing characters in recent American history as part of a remarkable series created for the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery. He reveals the secret to a great interview and shares extraordinary stories of talking with Steve Martin, Clare Booth Luce and more.
name: Marc Pachter: The art of the interview
title_vid: The art of the interview

title_talk: Yasheng Huang: Does democracy stifle economic growth?
description: Economist Yasheng Huang compares China to India, and asks how China's authoritarian rule contributed to its astonishing economic growth -- leading to a big question: Is democracy actually holding India back? Huang's answer may surprise you.
name: Yasheng Huang: Does democracy stifle economic growth?
title_vid: Does democracy stifle economic growth?

title_talk: David S. Rose: 10 things to know before you pitch a VC for
description: Thinking startup? David S. Rose's rapid-fire TED U talk on pitching to a venture capitalist tells you the 10 things you need to know about yourself -- and prove to a VC -- before you fire up your slideshow.
name: David S. Rose: How to pitch to a VC
title_vid: How to pitch to a VC

title_talk: This is what it's like to go undercover in North Korea | Suki Kim
description: For six months, Suki Kim worked as an English teacher at an elite school for North Korea's future leaders -- while writing a book on one of the world's most repressive regimes. As she helped her students grapple with concepts like "truth" and "critical thinking," she came to wonder: Was teaching these students to seek the truth putting them in peril? (This talk was part of a session at TED2015 guest-curated by Pop-Up Magazine: popupmagazine.com or @popupmag on Twitter.)
name: Suki Kim: This is what it's like to go undercover in North Korea
title_vid: This is what it's like to go undercover in North Korea

title_talk: Robert Wright: The evolution of compassion
description: Robert Wright uses evolutionary biology and game theory to explain why we appreciate the Golden Rule ("Do unto others..."), why we sometimes ignore it and why there’s hope that, in the near future, we might all have the compassion to follow it.
name: Robert Wright: The evolution of compassion
title_vid: The evolution of compassion

title_talk: Pam Warhurst: How we can eat our landscapes
description: What should a community do with its unused land? Plant food, of course. With energy and humor, Pam Warhurst tells at the TEDSalon the story of how she and a growing team of volunteers came together to turn plots of unused land into communal vegetable gardens, and to change the narrative of food in their community.
name: Pam Warhurst: How we can eat our landscapes
title_vid: How we can eat our landscapes

title_talk: What Islam really says about women | Alaa Murabit
description: Strong faith is a core part of Alaa Murabit's identity -- but when she moved from Canada to Libya as a young woman, she was surprised how the tenets of Islam were used to severely limit women's rights, independence and ability to lead. She wondered: Was this really religious doctrine? With humor, passion and a refreshingly rebellious spirt, she shares how she found examples of female leaders across the history of her faith — and how she speaks up for women using verses from the Koran.
name: Alaa Murabit: What my religion really says about women
title_vid: What my religion really says about women

title_talk: Thoughts on humanity, fame and love | Shah Rukh Khan
description: "I sell dreams, and I peddle love to millions of people," says Shah Rukh Khan, Bollywood's biggest star. In this charming, funny talk, Khan traces the arc of his life, showcases a few of his famous dance moves and shares hard-earned wisdom from a life spent in the spotlight.
name: Shah Rukh Khan: Thoughts on humanity, fame and love
title_vid: Thoughts on humanity, fame and love

title_talk: Julian Treasure: Shh! Sound health in 8 steps
description: Julian Treasure says our increasingly noisy world is gnawing away at our mental health -- even costing lives. He lays out an 8-step plan to soften this sonic assault (starting with those cheap earbuds) and restore our relationship with sound.
name: Julian Treasure: Shh! Sound health in 8 steps
title_vid: Shh! Sound health in 8 steps

title_talk: The fascinating physics of everyday life | Helen Czerski
description: Physics doesn't just happen in a fancy lab -- it happens when you push a piece of buttered toast off the table or drop a couple of raisins in a fizzy drink or watch a coffee spill dry. Become a more interesting dinner guest as physicist Helen Czerski presents various concepts in physics you can become familiar with using everyday things found in your kitchen.
name: Helen Czerski: The fascinating physics of everyday life
title_vid: The fascinating physics of everyday life

title_talk: Smelfies, and other experiments in synthetic biology | Ani Liu
description: What if you could take a smell selfie, a smelfie? What if you had a lipstick that caused plants to grow where you kiss? Ani Liu explores the intersection of technology and sensory perception, and her work is wedged somewhere between science, design and art. In this swift, smart talk, she shares dreams, wonderings and experiments, asking: What happens when science fiction becomes science fact?
name: Ani Liu: Smelfies, and other experiments in synthetic biology
title_vid: Smelfies, and other experiments in synthetic biology

title_talk: The incredible inventions of intuitive AI | Maurice Conti
description: What do you get when you give a design tool a digital nervous system? Computers that improve our ability to think and imagine, and robotic systems that come up with (and build) radical new designs for bridges, cars, drones and much more -- all by themselves. Take a tour of the Augmented Age with futurist Maurice Conti and preview a time when robots and humans will work side-by-side to accomplish things neither could do alone.
name: Maurice Conti: The incredible inventions of intuitive AI
title_vid: The incredible inventions of intuitive AI

title_talk: Corneille Ewango: A hero of the Congo Basin forest
description: Botanist Corneille Ewango talks about his work at the Okapi Faunal Reserve in the Congo Basin -- and his heroic work protecting it from poachers, miners and raging civil wars.
name: Corneille Ewango: A hero of the Congo forest
title_vid: A hero of the Congo forest

title_talk: This app makes it fun to pick up litter | Jeff Kirschner
description: The earth is a big place to keep clean. With Litterati -- an app for users to identify, collect and geotag the world's litter -- TED Resident Jeff Kirschner has created a community that's crowdsource-cleaning the planet. After tracking trash in more than 100 countries, Kirschner hopes to use the data he's collected to work with brands and organizations to stop litter before it reaches the ground.
name: Jeff Kirschner: This app makes it fun to pick up litter
title_vid: This app makes it fun to pick up litter

title_talk: For more tolerance, we need more ... tourism? | Aziz Abu Sarah
description: Aziz Abu Sarah is a Palestinian activist with an unusual approach to peace-keeping: Be a tourist. The TED Fellow shows how simple interactions with people in different cultures can erode decades of hate. He starts with Palestinians visiting Israelis and moves beyond ...
name: Aziz Abu Sarah: For more tolerance, we need more ... tourism?
title_vid: For more tolerance, we need more ... tourism?

title_talk: Say your truths and seek them in others | Elizabeth Lesser
description: In a lyrical, unexpectedly funny talk about heavy topics such as frayed relationships and the death of a loved one, Elizabeth Lesser describes the healing process of putting aside pride and defensiveness to make way for soul-baring and truth-telling. "You don't have to wait for a life-or-death situation to clean up the relationships that matter to you," she says. "Be like a new kind of first responder ... the one to take the first courageous step toward the other."
name: Elizabeth Lesser: Say your truths and seek them in others
title_vid: Say your truths and seek them in others

title_talk: Nilofer Merchant: Got a meeting? Take a walk
description: Nilofer Merchant suggests a small idea that just might have a big impact on your life and health: Next time you have a one-on-one meeting, make it into a "walking meeting" -- and let ideas flow while you walk and talk.
name: Nilofer Merchant: Got a meeting? Take a walk
title_vid: Got a meeting? Take a walk

title_talk: What will a future without secrets look like? | Alessandro Acquisti
description: The line between public and private has blurred in the past decade, both online and in real life, and Alessandro Acquisti is here to explain what this means and why it matters. In this thought-provoking, slightly chilling talk, he shares details of recent and ongoing research -- including a project that shows how easy it is to match a photograph of a stranger with their sensitive personal information.
name: Alessandro Acquisti: What will a future without secrets look like?
title_vid: What will a future without secrets look like?

title_talk: Fabian Hemmert: The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone
description: In this short, amazing demo, Fabian Hemmert imagines one future of the mobile phone -- a shape-shifting and weight-shifting handset that "displays" information nonvisually. It's a delightfully intuitive way to communicate.
name: Fabian Hemmert: The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone
title_vid: The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone

title_talk: Ed Yong: Suicidal wasps, zombie roaches and other parasite tales
description: In this fascinating, hilarious and ever-so-slightly creepy talk, science writer Ed Yong tells the story of his favorite parasites -- animals and organisms that live on the bodies (and brains!) of other organisms, causing them to do their bidding. Do humans have them too? Maybe ...
name: Ed Yong: Zombie roaches and other parasite tales
title_vid: Zombie roaches and other parasite tales

title_talk: Mental Health for All by Involving All | Vikram Patel | TED Talks
description: Nearly 450 million people are affected by mental illness worldwide. In wealthy nations, just half receive appropriate care, but in developing countries, close to 90 percent go untreated because psychiatrists are in such short supply. Vikram Patel outlines a highly promising approach -- training members of communities to give mental health interventions, empowering ordinary people to care for others.
name: Vikram Patel: Mental health for all by involving all
title_vid: Mental health for all by involving all

title_talk: Chris Bliss: Comedy is translation
description: Every act of communication is, in some way, an act of translation. Writer Chris Bliss talks about the way that great comedy can translate deep truths for a mass audience.
name: Chris Bliss: Comedy is translation
title_vid: Comedy is translation

title_talk: Holly Morris: Why stay in Chernobyl? Because it's home.
description: Chernobyl was the site of the world's worst nuclear accident and, for the past 27 years, the area around the plant has been known as the Exclusion Zone. And yet, a community of about 200 people live there -- almost all of them elderly women. These proud grandmas defied orders to relocate because their connection to their homeland and to their community are "forces that rival even radiation."
name: Holly Morris: Why stay in Chernobyl? Because it's home.
title_vid: Why stay in Chernobyl? Because it's home.

title_talk: Finding planets around other stars | Lucianne Walkowicz
description: How do we find planets -- even habitable planets -- around other stars? By looking for tiny dimming as a planet passes in front of its sun, TED Fellow Lucianne Walkowicz and the Kepler mission have found some 1,200 potential new planetary systems. With new techniques, they may even find ones with the right conditions for life.
name: Lucianne Walkowicz: Finding planets around other stars
title_vid: Finding planets around other stars

title_talk: Sirena Huang: An 11-year-old's magical violin
description: Violinist Sirena Huang gives a technically brilliant and emotionally nuanced performance. In a charming interlude, the 11-year-old praises the timeless design of her instrument.
name: Sirena Huang: An 11-year-old's magical violin
title_vid: An 11-year-old's magical violin

title_talk: Damian Palin: Mining minerals from seawater
description: The world needs clean water, and more and more, we're pulling it from the oceans, desalinating it, and drinking it. But what to do with the salty brine left behind? In this intriguing short talk, TED Fellow Damian Palin proposes an idea: Mine it for other minerals we need, with the help of some collaborative metal-munching bacteria.
name: Damian Palin: Mining minerals from seawater
title_vid: Mining minerals from seawater

title_talk: The new American Dream | Courtney Martin
description: For the first time in history, the majority of American parents don't think their kids will be better off than they were. This shouldn't be a cause for alarm, says journalist Courtney E. Martin. Rather, it's an opportunity to define a new approach to work and family that emphasizes community and creativity. "The biggest danger is not failing to achieve the American Dream," she says in a talk that will resonate far beyond the US. "The biggest danger is achieving a dream that you don't actually believe in."
name: Courtney E. Martin: The new American Dream
title_vid: The new American Dream

title_talk: AnnMarie Thomas: Hands-on science with squishy circuits
description: In a zippy demo at TED U, AnnMarie Thomas shows how two different kinds of homemade play dough can be used to demonstrate electrical properties -- by lighting up LEDs, spinning motors, and turning little kids into circuit designers.
name: AnnMarie Thomas: Hands-on science with squishy circuits
title_vid: Hands-on science with squishy circuits

title_talk: Stephen Petranek: 10 ways the world could end
description: How might the human race end? Stephen Petranek lays out 10 terrible options and the science behind them. Will we be wiped out by an asteroid? Eco-collapse? How about a particle collider gone wild?
name: Stephen Petranek: 10 ways the world could end
title_vid: 10 ways the world could end

title_talk: Mitch Resnick: Let's teach kids to code
description: Coding isn't just for computer whizzes, says Mitch Resnick of MIT Media Lab -- it's for everyone. In a fun, demo-filled talk Resnick outlines the benefits of teaching kids to code, so they can do more than just use new tech toys but also create them.
name: Mitch Resnick: Let's teach kids to code
title_vid: Let's teach kids to code

title_talk: Lakshmi Pratury: The lost art of letter-writing
description: Lakshmi Pratury remembers the lost art of letter-writing and shares a series of notes her father wrote to her before he died. Her short but heartfelt talk may inspire you to set pen to paper, too.
name: Lakshmi Pratury: The lost art of letter-writing
title_vid: The lost art of letter-writing

title_talk: The spellbinding art of human anatomy | Vanessa Ruiz
description: Vanessa Ruiz takes us on an illustrated journey of human anatomical art over the centuries, sharing captivating images that bring this visual science -- and the contemporary artists inspired by it -- to life. "Anatomical art has the power to reach far beyond the pages of a medical textbook," she says, "connecting our innermost selves with our bodies through art."
name: Vanessa Ruiz: The spellbinding art of human anatomy
title_vid: The spellbinding art of human anatomy

title_talk: Alex Laskey: How behavioral science can lower your energy bill
description: What's a proven way to lower your energy costs? Would you believe: learning what your neighbor pays. Alex Laskey shows how a quirk of human behavior can make us all better, wiser energy users, with lower bills to prove it.
name: Alex Laskey: How behavioral science can lower your energy bill
title_vid: How behavioral science can lower your energy bill

title_talk: Camille Seaman: Haunting photos of polar ice
description: Photographer Camille Seaman shoots icebergs, showing the world the complex beauty of these massive, ancient chunks of ice. Dive in to her photo slideshow, "The Last Iceberg."
name: Camille Seaman: Haunting photos of polar ice
title_vid: Haunting photos of polar ice

title_talk: Why good leaders make you feel safe | Simon Sinek
description: What makes a great leader? Management theorist Simon Sinek suggests, it’s someone who makes their employees feel secure, who draws staffers into a circle of trust. But creating trust and safety — especially in an uneven economy — means taking on big responsibility.
name: Simon Sinek: Why good leaders make you feel safe
title_vid: Why good leaders make you feel safe

title_talk: Bill Gates: Teachers need real feedback
description: Until recently, many teachers only got one word of feedback a year: "satisfactory." And with no feedback, no coaching, there's just no way to improve. Bill Gates suggests that even great teachers can get better with smart feedback -- and lays out a program from his foundation to bring it to every classroom.
name: Bill Gates: Teachers need real feedback
title_vid: Teachers need real feedback

title_talk: Gabby Giffords and Mark Kelly: Be passionate. Be courageous. Be your best.
description: On January 8, 2011, Congresswoman Gabby Giffords was shot in the head while meeting constituents in her home town of Tucson, Arizona. Her husband, the astronaut Mark Kelly, immediately flew to be by her side. In this emotional conversation with Pat Mitchell, the pair describe their lives both before and after the accident -- and describe their views on responsible gun ownership.
name: Gabby Giffords and Mark Kelly: Be passionate. Be courageous. Be your best.
speaker_occupation: Former U.S. Representative and NASA astronaut; survivors
title_vid: Be passionate. Be courageous. Be your best.

title_talk: Olafur Eliasson: Playing with space and light
description: In the spectacular large-scale projects he's famous for (such as "Waterfalls" in New York harbor), Olafur Eliasson creates art from a palette of space, distance, color and light. This idea-packed talk begins with an experiment in the nature of perception.
name: Olafur Eliasson: Playing with space and light
title_vid: Playing with space and light

title_talk: William Noel: Revealing the lost codex of Archimedes
description: How do you read a two-thousand-year-old manuscript that has been erased, cut up, written on and painted over? With a powerful particle accelerator, of course! Ancient books curator William Noel tells the fascinating story behind the Archimedes palimpsest, a Byzantine prayer book containing previously-unknown original writings from ancient Greek mathematician Archimedes and others.
name: William Noel: Revealing the lost codex of Archimedes
title_vid: Revealing the lost codex of Archimedes

title_talk: 9/11 healing: The mothers who found forgiveness, friendship
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Raghava KK: Shake up your story
description: Artist Raghava KK demos his new children's book for iPad with a fun feature: when you shake it, the story -- and your perspective -- changes. In this charming short talk, he invites all of us to shake up our perspective a little bit.
name: Raghava KK: Shake up your story
title_vid: Shake up your story

title_talk: Geraldine Hamilton: Body parts on a chip
description: It's relatively easy to imagine a new medicine -- the hard part is testing it, and that can delay promising new cures for years. In this well-explained talk, Geraldine Hamilton shows how her lab creates organs and body parts on a chip, simple structures with all the pieces essential to testing new medications -- perhaps even custom cures made for one specific person.
name: Geraldine Hamilton: Body parts on a chip
title_vid: Body parts on a chip

title_talk: Sharmeen Obaid Chinoy: Inside a school for suicide bombers
description: Filmmaker Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy takes on a terrifying question: How does the Taliban convince children to become suicide bombers? Propaganda footage from a training camp is intercut with her interviews of young camp graduates. A shocking vision.
name: Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy: Inside a school for suicide bombers
title_vid: Inside a school for suicide bombers

title_talk: Michael Green: Why we should build wooden skyscrapers
description: Building a skyscraper? Forget about steel and concrete, says architect Michael Green, and build it out of … wood. As he details in this intriguing talk, it's not only possible to build safe wooden structures up to 30 stories tall (and, he hopes, higher), it's necessary.
name: Michael Green: Why we should build wooden skyscrapers
title_vid: Why we should build wooden skyscrapers

title_talk: George Whitesides: A lab the size of a postage stamp
description: Traditional lab tests for disease diagnosis can be too expensive and cumbersome for the regions most in need. George Whitesides' ingenious answer is a foolproof tool that can be manufactured at virtually zero cost.
name: George Whitesides: A lab the size of a postage stamp
title_vid: A lab the size of a postage stamp

title_talk: Eddi Reader sings "Kiteflyer's Hill"
description: Singer/songwriter Eddi Reader performs "Kiteflyer's Hill," a tender look back at a lost love. With Thomas Dolby on piano.
name: Eddi Reader: "Kiteflyer's Hill"
title_vid: "Kiteflyer's Hill"

title_talk: Isaac Mizrahi: Fashion, passion, and about a million other
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: How economic inequality harms societies | Richard Wilkinson
description: We feel instinctively that societies with huge income gaps are somehow going wrong. Richard Wilkinson charts the hard data on economic inequality, and shows what gets worse when rich and poor are too far apart: real effects on health, lifespan, even such basic values as trust.
name: Richard Wilkinson: How economic inequality harms societies
title_vid: How economic inequality harms societies

title_talk: Matthew O'Reilly: "Am I dying?" The honest answer.
description: Matthew O’Reilly is a veteran emergency medical technician on Long Island, New York. In this talk, O’Reilly describes what happens next when a gravely hurt patient asks him: “Am I going to die?”
name: Matthew O'Reilly: “Am I dying?” The honest answer.
title_vid: “Am I dying?” The honest answer.

title_talk: Sam Martin: The quirky world of "manspaces"
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Regina Dugan: From mach-20 glider to hummingbird drone
description: "What would you attempt to do if you knew you could not fail?" asks Regina Dugan, then director of DARPA, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. In this breathtaking talk she describes some of the extraordinary projects -- a robotic hummingbird, a prosthetic arm controlled by thought, and, well, the internet -- that her agency has created by not worrying that they might fail. (Followed by a Q&A with TED's Chris Anderson)
name: Regina Dugan: From mach-20 glider to hummingbird drone
title_vid: From mach-20 glider to hummingbird drone

title_talk: Colin Grant: The son of a difficult father
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Lee Hotz: Inside an Antarctic time machine
description: Science columnist Lee Hotz describes a remarkable project at WAIS Divide, Antarctica, where a hardy team are drilling into ten-thousand-year-old ice to extract vital data on our changing climate.
name: Lee Hotz: Inside an Antarctic time machine
title_vid: Inside an Antarctic time machine

title_talk: Ed Gavagan: A story about knots and surgeons
description: One day, Ed Gavagan was sitting on the subway, watching two young med students practicing their knots. And a powerful memory washed over him -- of one shocking moment that changed his life forever. An unforgettable story of crime, skill and gratitude.
name: Ed Gavagan: A story about knots and surgeons
title_vid: A story about knots and surgeons

title_talk: Shlomo Benartzi: Saving for tomorrow, tomorrow
description: It's easy to imagine saving money next week, but how about right now? Generally, we want to spend it. Economist Shlomo Benartzi says this is one of the biggest obstacles to saving enough for retirement, and asks: How do we turn this behavioral challenge into a behavioral solution?
name: Shlomo Benartzi: Saving for tomorrow, tomorrow
title_vid: Saving for tomorrow, tomorrow

title_talk: Jonathan Haidt: The moral roots of liberals and conservatives
description: Psychologist Jonathan Haidt studies the five moral values that form the basis of our political choices, whether we're left, right or center. In this eye-opening talk, he pinpoints the moral values that liberals and conservatives tend to honor most.
name: Jonathan Haidt: The moral roots of liberals and conservatives
title_vid: The moral roots of liberals and conservatives

title_talk: Barbara Natterson-Horowitz: What veterinarians know that doctors don't
description: What do you call a veterinarian who can only take care of one species? A physician. In a fascinating talk, Barbara Natterson-Horowitz shares how a species-spanning approach to health can improve medical care of the human animal -- particularly when it comes to mental health.
name: Barbara Natterson-Horowitz: What veterinarians know that physicians don't
title_vid: What veterinarians know that physicians don't

title_talk: Garik Israelian: What's inside a star?
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Nancy Lublin: Texting that saves lives
description: When Nancy Lublin started texting teenagers to help with her social advocacy organization, what she found was shocking -- they started texting back about their own problems, from bullying to depression to abuse. So she's setting up a text-only crisis line, and the results might be even more important than she expected.
name: Nancy Lublin: Texting that saves lives
title_vid: Texting that saves lives

title_talk: Liza Donnelly: Drawing upon humor for change
description: New Yorker cartoonist Liza Donnelly shares a portfolio of her wise and funny cartoons about modern life -- and talks about how humor can empower women to change the rules.
name: Liza Donnelly: Drawing on humor for change
title_vid: Drawing on humor for change

title_talk: Paul Rothemund: The astonishing promise of DNA folding
description: In 2007, Paul Rothemund gave TED a short summary of his specialty, DNA folding. Now he lays out in clear, abundant detail the immense promise of this field -- to create tiny machines that assemble themselves.
name: Paul Rothemund: DNA folding, in detail
title_vid: DNA folding, in detail

title_talk: Meet the dazzling flying machines of the future | Raffaello D'Andrea
description: When you hear the word "drone," you probably think of something either very useful or very scary. But could they have aesthetic value? Autonomous systems expert Raffaello D'Andrea develops flying machines, and his latest projects are pushing the boundaries of autonomous flight -- from a flying wing that can hover and recover from disturbance to an eight-propeller craft that's ambivalent to orientation ... to a swarm of tiny coordinated micro-quadcopters. Prepare to be dazzled by a dreamy, swirling array of flying machines as they dance like fireflies above the TED stage.
name: Raffaello D'Andrea: Meet the dazzling flying machines of the future
title_vid: Meet the dazzling flying machines of the future

title_talk: The genius puppetry behind War Horse | Handspring Puppet Company
description: "Puppets always have to try to be alive," says Adrian Kohler of the Handspring Puppet Company, a gloriously ambitious troupe of human and wooden actors. Beginning with the tale of a hyena's subtle paw, puppeteers Kohler and Basil Jones build to the story of their latest astonishment: the wonderfully life-like Joey, the War Horse, who trots (and gallops) convincingly onto the TED stage.
name: Handspring Puppet Co.: The genius puppetry behind War Horse
title_vid: The genius puppetry behind War Horse

title_talk: Jacqueline Novogratz: Tackling poverty with "patient capita
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Nathan Myhrvold: A life of fascinations
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Emily Oster: What do we really know about the spread of AIDS?
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Rachel Botsman: The case for collaborative consumption
description: In her talk, Rachel Botsman says we're "wired to share" -- and shows how websites like Zipcar and Swaptree are changing the rules of human behavior.
name: Rachel Botsman: The case for collaborative consumption
title_vid: The case for collaborative consumption

title_talk: Chris Abani on the stories of Africa
description: In this deeply personal talk, Nigerian writer Chris Abani says that "what we know about how to be who we are" comes from stories. He searches for the heart of Africa through its poems and narrative, including his own.
name: Chris Abani: Telling stories from Africa
title_vid: Telling stories from Africa

title_talk: Why societies collapse | Jared Diamond
description: Why do societies fail? With lessons from the Norse of Iron Age Greenland, deforested Easter Island and present-day Montana, Jared Diamond talks about the signs that collapse is near, and how -- if we see it in time -- we can prevent it.
name: Jared Diamond: Why do societies collapse?
title_vid: Why do societies collapse?

title_talk: Thomas Dolby: "Love Is a Loaded Pistol"
description: To write his first studio album in decades, "A Map of the Floating City," Thomas Dolby has been working in the inspirational setting of a restored lifeboat. At TED2010 he premieres a gorgeous, evocative song from that album -- about one night with a legend. He's backed by members of the modern string quartet Ethel.
name: Thomas Dolby: "Love Is a Loaded Pistol"
title_vid: "Love Is a Loaded Pistol"

title_talk: Pico Iyer: Where is home?
description: More and more people worldwide are living in countries not considered their own. Writer Pico Iyer  -- who himself has three or four “origins” -- meditates on the meaning of home, the joy of traveling and the serenity of standing still.
name: Pico Iyer: Where is home?
title_vid: Where is home?

title_talk: John Maeda: My journey in design, from tofu to RISD
description: Designer John Maeda talks about his path from a Seattle tofu factory to the Rhode Island School of Design, where he became president in 2008. Maeda, a tireless experimenter and a witty observer, explores the crucial moment when design met computers.
name: John Maeda: My journey in design
title_vid: My journey in design

title_talk: John Hodgman: Design, explained.
description: John Hodgman, comedian and resident expert, "explains" the design of three iconic modern objects. (From The Design Studio session at TED2012, guest-curated by Chee Pearlman and David Rockwell.)
name: John Hodgman: Design, explained.
title_vid: Design, explained.

title_talk: What's wrong with what we eat | Mark Bittman
description: In this fiery and funny talk, New York Times food writer Mark Bittman weighs in on what's wrong with the way we eat now (too much meat, too few plants; too much fast food, too little home cooking), and why it's putting the entire planet at risk.
name: Mark Bittman: What's wrong with what we eat
title_vid: What's wrong with what we eat

title_talk: Catherine Crump: The small and surprisingly dangerous detail the police track about you
description: A very unsexy-sounding piece of technology could mean that the police know where you go, with whom, and when: the automatic license plate reader. These cameras are innocuously placed all across small-town America to catch known criminals, but as lawyer and TED Fellow Catherine Crump shows, the data they collect in aggregate could have disastrous consequences for everyone the world over.
name: Catherine Crump: The small and surprisingly dangerous detail the police track about you
title_vid: The small and surprisingly dangerous detail the police track about you

title_talk: Antonio Donato Nobre: The magic of the Amazon: A river that flows invisibly all around us
description: The Amazon River is like a heart, pumping water from the seas through it, and up into the atmosphere through 600 billion trees, which act like lungs. Clouds form, rain falls and the forest thrives. In a lyrical talk, Antonio Donato Nobre talks us through the interconnected systems of this region, and how they provide environmental services to the entire world. A parable for the extraordinary symphony that is nature.
name: Antonio Donato Nobre: The magic of the Amazon: A river that flows invisibly all around us
title_vid: The magic of the Amazon: A river that flows invisibly all around us

title_talk: Math is the hidden secret to understanding the world | Roger Antonsen
description: Unlock the mysteries and inner workings of the world through one of the most imaginative art forms ever -- mathematics -- with Roger Antonsen, as he explains how a slight change in perspective can reveal patterns, numbers and formulas as the gateways to empathy and understanding.
name: Roger Antonsen: Math is the hidden secret to understanding the world
title_vid: Math is the hidden secret to understanding the world

title_talk: Larry Smith: Why you will fail to have a great career
description: In this funny and blunt talk, Larry Smith pulls no punches when he calls out the absurd excuses people invent when they fail to pursue their passions.
name: Larry Smith: Why you will fail to have a great career
speaker_occupation: Professor of Economics, University of Waterloo
title_vid: Why you will fail to have a great career

title_talk: Michael Green: What the Social Progress Index can reveal about your country
description: The term Gross Domestic Product is often talked about as if it were “handed down from god on tablets of stone.” But this concept was invented by an economist in the 1930s. We need a more effective measurement tool to match 21st century needs, says Michael Green: the Social Progress Index. With charm and wit, he shows how this tool measures societies across the three dimensions that actually matter. And reveals the dramatic reordering of nations that occurs when you use it.
name: Michael Green: What the Social Progress Index can reveal about your country
title_vid: What the Social Progress Index can reveal about your country

title_talk: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi: Flow, the secret to happiness
description: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi asks, "What makes a life worth living?" Noting that money cannot make us happy, he looks to those who find pleasure and lasting satisfaction in activities that bring about a state of "flow."
name: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi: Flow, the secret to happiness
title_vid: Flow, the secret to happiness

title_talk: Kate Stone: DJ decks made of... paper
description: "I love paper, and I love technology," says physicist and former sheep herder Kate Stone, who's spent the past decade working to unite the two. Her experiments combine regular paper with conductive inks and tiny circuit boards to offer a unique, magical experience. To date, applications include a newspaper embedded with audio and video, posters that display energy usage in real time, and the extremely nifty paper drumkit and set of DJ decks she demonstrates onstage.
name: Kate Stone: DJ decks made of ... paper
title_vid: DJ decks made of ... paper

title_talk: Bill T. Jones: The dancer, the singer, the cellist ... and a moment of creative magic
description: Legendary dance choreographer Bill T. Jones and TED Fellows Joshua Roman and Somi didn't know exactly what was going to happen when they took the stage at TED2015. They just knew they wanted to offer the audience an opportunity to witness creative collaboration in action. The result: An improvised piece they call "The Red Circle and the Blue Curtain," so extraordinary it had to be shared ...
name: Bill T. Jones: The dancer, the singer, the cellist ... and a moment of creative magic
title_vid: The dancer, the singer, the cellist ... and a moment of creative magic

title_talk: A smart new business loan for people with no credit | Shivani Siroya
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: An artist's unflinching look at racial violence | Sanford Biggers
description: Conceptual artist and TED Fellow Sanford Biggers uses painting, sculpture, video and performance to spark challenging conversations about the history and trauma of black America. Join him as he details two compelling works and shares the motivation behind his art. "Only through more thoughtful dialogue about history and race can we evolve as individuals and society," Biggers says.
name: Sanford Biggers: An artist's unflinching look at racial violence
title_vid: An artist's unflinching look at racial violence

title_talk: Iwan Baan: Ingenious homes in unexpected places
description: In the center of Caracas, Venezuela, stands the 45-story "Tower of David," an unfinished, abandoned skyscraper. But about eight years ago, people started moving in. Photographer Iwan Baan shows how people build homes in unlikely places, touring us through the family apartments of Torre David, a city on the water in Nigeria, and an underground village in China. Glorious images celebrate humanity's ability to survive and make a home -- anywhere.
name: Iwan Baan: Ingenious homes in unexpected places
title_vid: Ingenious homes in unexpected places

title_talk: How to control someone else's arm with your brain | Greg Gage
description: Greg Gage is on a mission to make brain science accessible to all. In this fun, kind of creepy demo, the neuroscientist and TED Senior Fellow uses a simple, inexpensive DIY kit to take away the free will of an audience member. It's not a parlor trick; it actually works. You have to see it to believe it.
name: Greg Gage: How to control someone else's arm with your brain
title_vid: How to control someone else's arm with your brain

title_talk: The next manufacturing revolution is here | Olivier Scalabre
description: Economic growth has been slowing for the past 50 years, but relief might come from an unexpected place -- a new form of manufacturing that is neither what you thought it was nor where you thought it was. Industrial systems thinker Olivier Scalabre details how a fourth manufacturing revolution will produce a macroeconomic shift and boost employment, productivity and growth.
name: Olivier Scalabre: The next manufacturing revolution is here
title_vid: The next manufacturing revolution is here

title_talk: Why Africa must become a center of knowledge again | Olúfẹ́mi Táíwò
