description: Kevin Surace suggests we rethink basic construction materials -- such as the familiar wallboard -- to reduce the huge carbon footprint generated by the manufacturing and construction of our buildings. He introduces EcoRock, a clean, recyclable and energy-efficient drywall created by his team at Serious Materials.
name: Kevin Surace: Eco-friendly drywall
title_vid: Eco-friendly drywall

title_talk: Why Climate Change Is a Threat to Human Rights | Mary Robinson | TED Talks
description: Climate change is unfair. While rich countries can fight against rising oceans and dying farm fields, poor people around the world are already having their lives upended -- and their human rights threatened -- by killer storms, starvation and the loss of their own lands. Mary Robinson asks us to join the movement for worldwide climate justice.
name: Mary Robinson: Why climate change is a threat to human rights
title_vid: Why climate change is a threat to human rights

title_talk: The paradox of choice | Barry Schwartz
description: Psychologist Barry Schwartz takes aim at a central tenet of western societies: freedom of choice. In Schwartz's estimation, choice has made us not freer but more paralyzed, not happier but more dissatisfied.
name: Barry Schwartz: The paradox of choice
title_vid: The paradox of choice

title_talk: Dan Cobley: What physics taught me about marketing
description: Physics and marketing don't seem to have much in common, but Dan Cobley is passionate about both. He brings these unlikely bedfellows together using Newton's second law, Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, the scientific method and the second law of thermodynamics to explain the fundamental theories of branding.
name: Dan Cobley: What physics taught me about marketing
title_vid: What physics taught me about marketing

title_talk: Pankaj Ghemawat: Actually, the world isn't flat
description: It may seem that we're living in a borderless world where ideas, goods and people flow freely from nation to nation. We're not even close, says Pankaj Ghemawat. With great data (and an eye-opening survey), he argues that there's a delta between perception and reality in a world that's maybe not so hyperconnected after all.
name: Pankaj Ghemawat: Actually, the world isn't flat
title_vid: Actually, the world isn't flat

title_talk: Can we create new senses for humans? | David Eagleman
description: As humans, we can perceive less than a ten-trillionth of all light waves. "Our experience of reality," says neuroscientist David Eagleman, "is constrained by our biology." He wants to change that. His research into our brain processes has led him to create new interfaces -- such as a sensory vest -- to take in previously unseen information about the world around us.
name: David Eagleman: Can we create new senses for humans?
title_vid: Can we create new senses for humans?

title_talk: Tristram Wyatt: The smelly mystery of the human pheromone
description: Do our smells make us sexy? Popular science suggests yes — pheromones send chemical signals about sex and attraction from our armpits to potential mates. But, despite what you might have heard, there is no conclusive research confirming that humans have these smell molecules. In this eye-opening talk, zoologist Tristram Wyatt explains the fundamental flaws in current pheromone research, and shares his hope for a future that unlocks the fascinating, potentially life-saving knowledge tied up in our scent.
name: Tristram Wyatt: The smelly mystery of the human pheromone
title_vid: The smelly mystery of the human pheromone

title_talk: Eric Dishman: Take health care off the mainframe
description: At TEDMED, Eric Dishman makes a bold argument: The US health care system is like computing circa 1959, tethered to big, unwieldy central systems: hospitals, doctors, nursing homes. As our aging population booms, it's imperative, he says, to create personal, networked, home-based health care for all.
name: Eric Dishman: Take health care off the mainframe
title_vid: Take health care off the mainframe

title_talk: Danny Hillis: The Internet could crash. We need a Plan B
description: The Internet connects billions of people and machines; it's the backbone of modern life. But tech pioneer Danny Hillis thinks the Internet just wasn't designed to grow this big -- and he fears that one big cyber-attack or glitch could shut it down and take civilization with it. To head off a digital dark age, he sounds a clarion call to develop a Plan B: a parallel system to fall back on if -- or when -- the Internet crashes.
name: Danny Hillis: The Internet could crash. We need a Plan B
title_vid: The Internet could crash. We need a Plan B

title_talk: This is what happens when you reply to spam email | James Veitch
description: Suspicious emails: unclaimed insurance bonds, diamond-encrusted safe deposit boxes, close friends marooned in a foreign country. They pop up in our inboxes, and standard procedure is to delete on sight. But what happens when you reply? Follow along as writer and comedian James Veitch narrates a hilarious, weeks-long exchange with a spammer who offered to cut him in on a hot deal.
name: James Veitch: This is what happens when you reply to spam email
title_vid: This is what happens when you reply to spam email

title_talk: Milton Glaser: How great design makes ideas new
description: From the TED archives: The legendary graphic designer Milton Glaser dives deep into a new painting inspired by Piero della Francesca. From here, he muses on what makes a convincing poster, by breaking down an idea and making it new.
name: Milton Glaser: Using design to make ideas new
title_vid: Using design to make ideas new

title_talk: The pattern behind self-deception | Michael Shermer
description: Michael Shermer says the human tendency to believe strange things -- from alien abductions to dowsing rods -- boils down to two of the brain's most basic, hard-wired survival skills. He explains what they are, and how they get us into trouble.
name: Michael Shermer: The pattern behind self-deception
title_vid: The pattern behind self-deception

title_talk: Raul Midon: "All the Answers" and "Tembererana"
description: Singer/guitarist Raúl Midón performs "All the Answers" in a world premiere at TED2007, followed by the sprightly "Tembererana."
name: Raul Midon: "Tembererana"
title_vid: "Tembererana"

title_talk: James A. White Sr.: The little problem I had renting a house
description: Fifty-three years ago, James A. White Sr. joined the US Air Force. But as an African American man, he had to go to shocking lengths to find a place for his young family to live nearby. He tells this powerful story about the lived experience of "everyday racism" -- and how it echoes today in the way he's had to teach his grandchildren to interact with police.
name: James A. White Sr.: The little problem I had renting a house
title_vid: The little problem I had renting a house

title_talk: Steven Pinker: What our language habits reveal
description: In an exclusive preview of his book The Stuff of Thought, Steven Pinker looks at language and how it expresses what goes on in our minds -- and how the words we choose communicate much more than we realize.
name: Steven Pinker: What our language habits reveal
title_vid: What our language habits reveal

title_talk: The magic of Khmer classical dance | Prumsodun Ok
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: A smarter, more precise way to think about public health | Sue Desmond-Hellmann
description: Sue Desmond-Hellmann is using precision public health -- an approach that incorporates big data, consumer monitoring, gene sequencing and other innovative tools -- to solve the world's most difficult medical problems. It's already helped cut HIV transmission from mothers to babies by nearly half in sub-Saharan Africa, and now it's being used to address alarming infant mortality rates all over the world. The goal: to save lives by bringing the right interventions to the right populations at the right time.
name: Sue Desmond-Hellmann: A smarter, more precise way to think about public health
title_vid: A smarter, more precise way to think about public health

title_talk: A shark-deterrent wetsuit (and it's not what you think) | Hamish Jolly
description: Hamish Jolly, an ocean swimmer in Australia, wanted a wetsuit that would deter a curious shark from mistaking him for a potential source of nourishment. (Which, statistically, is rare, but certainly a fate worth avoiding.) Working with a team of scientists, he and his friends came up with a fresh approach — not a shark cage, not a suit of chain-mail, but a sleek suit that taps our growing understanding of shark vision.
name: Hamish Jolly: A shark-deterrent wetsuit (and it's not what you think)
title_vid: A shark-deterrent wetsuit (and it's not what you think)

title_talk: Dennis Hong: Making a car for blind drivers
description: Using robotics, laser rangefinders, GPS and smart feedback tools, Dennis Hong is building a car for drivers who are blind. It's not a "self-driving" car, he's careful to note, but a car in which a non-sighted driver can determine speed, proximity and route -- and drive independently.
name: Dennis Hong: Making a car for blind drivers
title_vid: Making a car for blind drivers

title_talk: How the mysterious dark net is going mainstream | Jamie Bartlett
description: There’s a parallel Internet you may not have run across yet -- accessed by a special browser and home to a freewheeling collection of sites for everything from anonymous activism to illicit activities. Jamie Bartlett reports from the dark net.
name: Jamie Bartlett: How the mysterious dark net is going mainstream
title_vid: How the mysterious dark net is going mainstream

title_talk: Peter Donnelly: How stats fool juries
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: My love letter to cosplay | Adam Savage
description: Adam Savage makes things and builds experiments, and he uses costumes to add humor, color and clarity to the stories he tells. Tracing his lifelong love of costumes -- from a childhood space helmet made of an ice cream tub to a No-Face costume he wore to Comic-Con -- Savage explores the world of cosplay and the meaning it creates for its community. "We're connecting with something important inside of us," he says. "The costumes are how we reveal ourselves to each other."
name: Adam Savage: My love letter to cosplay
title_vid: My love letter to cosplay

title_talk: How computers are learning to be creative | Blaise Agüera y Arcas
description: We're on the edge of a new frontier in art and creativity -- and it's not human. Blaise Agüera y Arcas, principal scientist at Google, works with deep neural networks for machine perception and distributed learning. In this captivating demo, he shows how neural nets trained to recognize images can be run in reverse, to generate them. The results: spectacular, hallucinatory collages (and poems!) that defy categorization. "Perception and creativity are very intimately connected," Agüera y Arcas says. "Any creature, any being that is able to do perceptual acts is also able to create."
name: Blaise Agüera y Arcas: How computers are learning to be creative
title_vid: How computers are learning to be creative

title_talk: Why is 'x' the unknown? | Terry Moore
description: Why is 'x' the symbol for an unknown? In this short and funny talk, Terry Moore gives the surprising answer.
name: Terry Moore: Why is 'x' the unknown?
title_vid: Why is 'x' the unknown?

title_talk: Jacqueline Novogratz: Inspiring a life of immersion
description: We each want to live a life of purpose, but where to start? In this luminous, wide-ranging talk, Jacqueline Novogratz introduces us to people she's met in her work in "patient capital" -- people who have immersed themselves in a cause, a community, a passion for justice. These human stories carry powerful moments of inspiration.
name: Jacqueline Novogratz: Inspiring a life of immersion
speaker_occupation: Investor and advocate for moral leadership
title_vid: Inspiring a life of immersion

title_talk: LZ Granderson: The myth of the gay agenda
description: In a funny talk with an urgent message, LZ Granderson points out the absurdity in the idea that there's a "gay lifestyle," much less a "gay agenda." What's actually on his agenda? Being a good partner -- and being a good parent.
name: LZ Granderson: The myth of the gay agenda
title_vid: The myth of the gay agenda

title_talk: The psychology of your future self | Dan Gilbert
description: "Human beings are works in progress that mistakenly think they're finished." Dan Gilbert shares recent research on a phenomenon he calls the "end of history illusion," where we somehow imagine that the person we are right now is the person we'll be for the rest of time. Hint: that's not the case.
name: Dan Gilbert: The psychology of your future self
title_vid: The psychology of your future self

title_talk: Freeman Hrabowski: 4 pillars of college success in science
description: At age 12, Freeman Hrabowski marched with Martin Luther King. Now he's president of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC), where he works to create an environment that helps under-represented students -- specifically African-American, Latino and low-income learners -- get degrees in math and science. He shares the four pillars of UMBC's approach.
name: Freeman Hrabowski: 4 pillars of college success in science
title_vid: 4 pillars of college success in science

title_talk: Larry Burns: Reinventing the car
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: A Journey Through the Mind of an Artist | Dustin Yellin | TED Talks
description: Dustin Yellin makes mesmerizing artwork that tells complex, myth-inspired stories. How did he develop his style? In this disarming talk, he shares the journey of an artist -- starting from age 8 -- and his idiosyncratic way of thinking and seeing. Follow the path that leads him up to his latest major work (or two).
name: Dustin Yellin: A journey through the mind of an artist
title_vid: A journey through the mind of an artist

title_talk: Don Tapscott: Four principles for the open world
description: The recent generations have been bathed in connecting technology from birth, says futurist Don Tapscott, and as a result the world is transforming into one that is far more open and transparent. In this inspiring talk, he lists the four core principles that show how this open world can be a far better place.
name: Don Tapscott: Four principles for the open world
title_vid: Four principles for the open world

title_talk: Before Avatar ... a curious boy | James Cameron
description: James Cameron's big-budget (and even bigger-grossing) films create unreal worlds all their own. In this personal talk, he reveals his childhood fascination with the fantastic -- from reading science fiction to deep-sea diving -- and how it ultimately drove the success of his blockbuster hits "Aliens," "The Terminator," "Titanic" and "Avatar."
name: James Cameron: Before Avatar ... a curious boy
title_vid: Before Avatar ... a curious boy

title_talk: Julia Bacha: Pay attention to nonviolence
description: In 2003, the Palestinian village of Budrus mounted a 10-month-long nonviolent protest to stop a barrier being built across their olive groves. Did you hear about it? Didn't think so. Brazilian filmmaker Julia Bacha asks why we only pay attention to violence in the Israel-Palestine conflict -- and not to the nonviolent leaders who may one day bring peace.
name: Julia Bacha: Pay attention to nonviolence
title_vid: Pay attention to nonviolence

title_talk: Paolo Cardini: Forget multitasking, try monotasking
description: People don't just cook anymore -- they're cooking, texting, talking on the phone, watching YouTube and uploading photos of the awesome meal they just made. Designer Paolo Cardini questions the efficiency of our multitasking world and makes the case for -- gasp -- "monotasking."
name: Paolo Cardini: Forget multitasking, try monotasking
title_vid: Forget multitasking, try monotasking

title_talk: New York -- before the City | Eric Sanderson
description: 400 years after Hudson found New York harbor, Eric Sanderson shares how he made a 3D map of Mannahatta's fascinating pre-city ecology of hills, rivers, wildlife -- accurate down to the block -- when Times Square was a wetland and you couldn't get delivery.
name: Eric Sanderson: New York -- before the City
title_vid: New York -- before the City

title_talk: Mark Forsyth: What's a snollygoster? A short lesson in political speak
description: Most politicians choose their words carefully, to shape the reality they hope to create. But does it work? Etymologist Mark Forsyth shares a few entertaining word-origin stories from British and American history (for instance, did you ever wonder how George Washington became "president"?) and draws a surprising conclusion.
name: Mark Forsyth: What's a snollygoster? A short lesson in political speak
title_vid: What's a snollygoster? A short lesson in political speak

title_talk: Chris Jordan: Turning powerful stats into art
description: Artist Chris Jordan shows us an arresting view of what Western culture looks like. His supersized images picture some almost unimaginable statistics -- like the astonishing number of paper cups we use every single day.
name: Chris Jordan: Turning powerful stats into art
title_vid: Turning powerful stats into art

title_talk: Natasha Tsakos' multimedia theatrical adventure
description: Natasha Tsakos presents part of her one-woman, multimedia show, "Upwake." As the character Zero, she blends dream and reality with an inventive virtual world projected around her in 3D animation and electric sound.
name: Natasha Tsakos: A multimedia theatrical adventure
title_vid: A multimedia theatrical adventure

title_talk: The secret to living longer may be your social life | Susan Pinker
description: The Italian island of Sardinia has more than six times as many centenarians as the mainland and ten times as many as North America. Why? According to psychologist Susan Pinker, it's not a sunny disposition or a low-fat, gluten-free diet that keeps the islanders healthy -- it's their emphasis on close personal relationships and face-to-face interactions. Learn more about super longevity as Pinker explains what it takes to live to 100 and beyond.
name: Susan Pinker: The secret to living longer may be your social life
title_vid: The secret to living longer may be your social life

title_talk: How I held my breath for 17 minutes | David Blaine
description: In this highly personal talk from TEDMED, magician and stuntman David Blaine describes what it took to hold his breath underwater for 17 minutes -- a world record (only two minutes shorter than this entire talk!) -- and what his often death-defying work means to him. Warning: do NOT try this at home.
name: David Blaine: How I held my breath for 17 minutes
title_vid: How I held my breath for 17 minutes

title_talk: Dale Dougherty: We are makers
description: America was built by makers -- curious, enthusiastic amateur inventors whose tinkering habit sparked whole new industries. At TED@MotorCity, MAKE magazine publisher Dale Dougherty says we're all makers at heart, and shows cool new tools to tinker with, like Arduinos, affordable 3D printers, even DIY satellites.
name: Dale Dougherty: We are makers
title_vid: We are makers

title_talk: Captain Charles Moore on the seas of plastic
description: Capt. Charles Moore of the Algalita Marine Research Foundation first discovered the Great Pacific Garbage Patch -- an endless floating waste of plastic trash. Now he's drawing attention to the growing, choking problem of plastic debris in our seas.
name: Charles Moore: Seas of plastic
title_vid: Seas of plastic

title_talk: Did you hear the one about the Iranian-American? | Maz Jobrani
description: A founding member of the Axis of Evil Comedy Tour, standup comic Maz Jobrani riffs on the challenges and conflicts of being Iranian-American -- "like, part of me thinks I should have a nuclear program; the other part thinks I can't be trusted ..."
name: Maz Jobrani: Did you hear the one about the Iranian-American?
title_vid: Did you hear the one about the Iranian-American?

title_talk: Alejandro Aravena: My architectural philosophy? Bring the community into the process
description: When asked to build housing for 100 families in Chile ten years ago, Alejandro Aravena looked to an unusual inspiration: the wisdom of favelas and slums. Rather than building a large building with small units, he built flexible half-homes that each family could expand on. It was a complex problem, but with a simple solution — one that he arrived at by working with the families themselves. With a chalkboard and beautiful images of his designs, Aravena walks us through three projects where clever rethinking led to beautiful design with great benefit.
name: Alejandro Aravena: My architectural philosophy? Bring the community into the process
title_vid: My architectural philosophy? Bring the community into the process

title_talk: Rob Forbes: Ways of seeing
description: Rob Forbes, the founder of Design Within Reach, shows a gallery of snapshots that inform his way of seeing the world. Charming juxtapositions, found art, urban patterns -- this slideshow will open your eyes to the world around you.
name: Rob Forbes: Ways of seeing
title_vid: Ways of seeing

title_talk: The mathematics of love | Hannah Fry
description: Finding the right mate is no cakewalk -- but is it even mathematically likely? In a charming talk, mathematician Hannah Fry shows patterns in how we look for love, and gives her top three tips (verified by math!) for finding that special someone.
name: Hannah Fry: The mathematics of love
title_vid: The mathematics of love

title_talk: Avi Rubin: All your devices can be hacked
description: Could someone hack your pacemaker? Avi Rubin shows how hackers are compromising cars, smartphones and medical devices, and warns us about the dangers of an increasingly hack-able world.
name: Avi Rubin: All your devices can be hacked
title_vid: All your devices can be hacked

title_talk: Emma Teeling: The secret of the bat genome
description: In Western society, bats are often characterized as creepy, even evil. Zoologist Emma Teeling encourages us to rethink common attitudes toward bats, whose unique and fascinating biology gives us insight into our own genetic makeup.
name: Emma Teeling: The secret of the bat genome
title_vid: The secret of the bat genome

title_talk: Let's try emotional correctness | Sally Kohn
description: It's time for liberals and conservatives to transcend their political differences and really listen to each other, says political pundit Sally Kohn. In this optimistic talk, Kohn shares what she learned as a progressive lesbian talking head on Fox News. It’s not about political correctness, she says, but rather, emotional correctness. (Contains profanity.)
name: Sally Kohn: Let’s try emotional correctness
title_vid: Let’s try emotional correctness

title_talk: The shared experience of absurdity | Charlie Todd
description: Charlie Todd causes bizarre, hilarious, and unexpected public scenes: Seventy synchronized dancers in storefront windows, "ghostbusters" running through the New York Public Library, and the annual no-pants subway ride. His group, Improv Everywhere, uses these scenes to bring people together.
name: Charlie Todd: The shared experience of absurdity
title_vid: The shared experience of absurdity

title_talk: Al Gore: Alarming new slides of the worsening climate crisis
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Peter Attia: What if we're wrong about diabetes?
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The coolest animal you know nothing about ... and how we can save it | Patrícia Medici
description: Although the tapir is one of the world's largest land mammals, the lives of these solitary, nocturnal creatures have remained a mystery. Known as "the living fossil," the very same tapir that roams the forests and grasslands of South America today arrived on the evolutionary scene more than 5 million years ago. But threats from poachers, deforestation and pollution, especially in quickly industrializing Brazil, threaten this longevity. In this insightful talk, conservation biologist, tapir expert and TED Fellow Patrícia Medici shares her work with these amazing animals and challenges us with a question: Do we want to be responsible for their extinction?
name: Patrícia Medici: The coolest animal you know nothing about ... and how we can save it
title_vid: The coolest animal you know nothing about ... and how we can save it

title_talk: One year of turning the world inside out | JR
description: Street artist JR made a wish in 2011: Join me in a worldwide photo project to show the world its true face. One year after making his TED Prize wish, he shows how giant posters of human faces, pasted in public, are connecting communities, making change, and turning the world inside out.
name: JR: One year of turning the world inside out
title_vid: One year of turning the world inside out

title_talk: Why thinking you're ugly is bad for you | Meaghan Ramsey
description: About 10,000 people a month Google the phrase, “Am I ugly?” Meaghan Ramsey of the Dove Self-Esteem Project has a feeling that many of them are young girls. In a deeply unsettling talk, she walks us through the surprising impacts of low body and image confidence—from lower grade point averages to greater risk-taking with drugs and alcohol. And then shares the key things all of us can do to disrupt this reality.
name: Meaghan Ramsey: Why thinking you're ugly is bad for you
title_vid: Why thinking you're ugly is bad for you

title_talk: The magic of truth and lies (and iPods) | Marco Tempest
description: Using three iPods like magical props, Marco Tempest spins a clever, surprisingly heartfelt meditation on truth and lies, art and emotion.
name: Marco Tempest: The magic of truth and lies (and iPods)
title_vid: The magic of truth and lies (and iPods)

title_talk: How to grow a forest in your backyard | Shubhendu Sharma
description: Forests don't have to be far-flung nature reserves, isolated from human life. Instead, we can grow them right where we are -- even in cities. Eco-entrepreneur and TED Fellow Shubhendu Sharma grows ultra-dense, biodiverse mini-forests of native species in urban areas by engineering soil, microbes and biomass to kickstart natural growth processes. Follow along as he describes how to grow a 100-year-old forest in just 10 years, and learn how you can get in on this tiny jungle party.
name: Shubhendu Sharma: How to grow a forest in your backyard
title_vid: How to grow a forest in your backyard

title_talk: Miguel Nicolelis: Brain-to-brain communication has arrived. How we did it
description: You may remember neuroscientist Miguel Nicolelis — he built the brain-controlled exoskeleton that allowed a paralyzed man to kick the first ball of the 2014 World Cup. What’s he working on now? Building ways for two minds (rats and monkeys, for now) to send messages brain to brain. Watch to the end for an experiment that, as he says, will go to "the limit of your imagination."
name: Miguel Nicolelis: Brain-to-brain communication has arrived. How we did it
title_vid: Brain-to-brain communication has arrived. How we did it

title_talk: Sean Carroll: Distant time and the hint of a multiverse
description: Cosmologist Sean Carroll attacks -- in an entertaining and thought-provoking tour through the nature of time and the universe -- a deceptively simple question: Why does time exist at all? The potential answers point to a surprising view of the nature of the universe, and our place in it.
name: Sean Carroll: Distant time and the hint of a multiverse
title_vid: Distant time and the hint of a multiverse

title_talk: How I turned a deadly plant into a thriving business | Achenyo Idachaba
description: The water hyacinth may look like a harmless, even beautiful flowering plant -- but it's actually an invasive aquatic weed that clogs waterways, stopping trade, interrupting schooling and disrupting everyday life. In this scourge, green entrepreneur Achenyo Idachaba saw opportunity. Follow her journey as she turns weeds into woven wonders.
name: Achenyo Idachaba: How I turned a deadly plant into a thriving business
title_vid: How I turned a deadly plant into a thriving business

title_talk: Ze Frank: Are you human?
description: Have you ever wondered: Am I a human being? Ze Frank suggests a series of simple questions that will determine this. Please relax and follow the prompts. Let's begin …
name: Ze Frank: Are you human?
title_vid: Are you human?

title_talk: What young women believe about their own sexual pleasure | Peggy Orenstein
description: Why do girls feel empowered to engage in sexual activity but not to enjoy it? For three years, author Peggy Orenstein interviewed girls ages 15 to 20 about their attitudes toward and experiences of sex. She discusses the pleasure that's largely missing from their sexual encounters and calls on us to close the "orgasm gap" by talking candidly with our girls from an early age about sex, bodies, pleasure and intimacy.
name: Peggy Orenstein: What young women believe about their own sexual pleasure
title_vid: What young women believe about their own sexual pleasure

title_talk: The data behind Hollywood's sexism | Stacy Smith
description: Where are all the women and girls in film? Social scientist Stacy Smith analyzes how the media underrepresents and portrays women -- and the potentially destructive effects those portrayals have on viewers. She shares hard data behind gender bias in Hollywood, where on-screen males outnumber females three to one (and behind-the-camera workers fare even worse.)
name: Stacy Smith: The data behind Hollywood's sexism
title_vid: The data behind Hollywood's sexism

title_talk: What we don't know about mother's milk | Katie Hinde
description: Breast milk grows babies' bodies, fuels neurodevelopment, provides essential immunofactors and safeguards against famine and disease -- why, then, does science know more about tomatoes than mother's milk? Katie Hinde shares insights into this complex, life-giving substance and discusses the major gaps scientific research still needs to fill so we can better understand it.
name: Katie Hinde: What we don't know about mother's milk
title_vid: What we don't know about mother's milk

title_talk: Michael Pollan: A plant's-eye view
description: What if human consciousness isn't the end-all and be-all of Darwinism? What if we are all just pawns in corn's clever strategy game to rule the Earth? Author Michael Pollan asks us to see the world from a plant's-eye view.
name: Michael Pollan: A plant's-eye view
title_vid: A plant's-eye view

title_talk: Jill Sobule: A happy song about global warming
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Paul Rothemund: Casting spells with DNA
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The playful wonderland behind great inventions | Steven Johnson
description: Necessity is the mother of invention, right? Well, not always. Steven Johnson shows us how some of the most transformative ideas and technologies, like the computer, didn't emerge out of necessity at all but instead from the strange delight of play. Share this captivating, illustrated exploration of the history of invention. Turns out, you'll find the future wherever people are having the most fun.
name: Steven Johnson: The playful wonderland behind great inventions
title_vid: The playful wonderland behind great inventions

title_talk: How to practice safe sexting | Amy Adele Hasinoff
description: Sexting, like anything that's fun, runs its risks -- but a serious violation of privacy shouldn't be one of them. Amy Adele Hasinoff looks at problematic responses to sexting in mass media, law and education, offering practical solutions for how individuals and tech companies can protect sensitive (and, ahem, potentially scandalous) digital files.
name: Amy Adele Hasinoff: How to practice safe sexting
title_vid: How to practice safe sexting

title_talk: Clay Shirky: How the Internet will (one day) transform government
description: The open-source world has learned to deal with a flood of new, oftentimes divergent, ideas using hosting services like GitHub -- so why can’t governments? In this rousing talk Clay Shirky shows how democracies can take a lesson from the Internet, to be not just transparent but also to draw on the knowledge of all their citizens.
name: Clay Shirky: How the Internet will (one day) transform government
title_vid: How the Internet will (one day) transform government

title_talk: Can a computer write poetry? | Oscar Schwartz
description: If you read a poem and feel moved by it, but then find out it was actually written by a computer, would you feel differently about the experience? Would you think that the computer had expressed itself and been creative, or would you feel like you had fallen for a cheap trick? In this talk, writer Oscar Schwartz examines why we react so strongly to the idea of a computer writing poetry -- and how this reaction helps us understand what it means to be human.
name: Oscar Schwartz: Can a computer write poetry?
title_vid: Can a computer write poetry?

title_talk: A sci-fi vision of love from a 318-year-old hologram | Monica Byrne
description: Science fiction writer Monica Byrne imagines rich worlds populated with characters who defy our racial, social and gender stereotypes. In this performance, Byrne appears as a hologram named Pilar, transmitting a story of love and loss back to us from a near future when humans have colonized the universe. "It's always funny what you think the future is going to be like versus what it turns out to be," she says.
name: Monica Byrne: A sci-fi vision of love from a 318-year-old hologram
title_vid: A sci-fi vision of love from a 318-year-old hologram

title_talk: My son was a Columbine shooter. This is my story | Sue Klebold
description: Sue Klebold is the mother of Dylan Klebold, one of the two shooters who committed the Columbine High School massacre, murdering 12 students and a teacher. She's spent years excavating every detail of her family life, trying to understand what she could have done to prevent her son's violence. In this difficult, jarring talk, Klebold explores the intersection between mental health and violence, advocating for parents and professionals to continue to examine the link between suicidal and homicidal thinking.
name: Sue Klebold: My son was a Columbine shooter. This is my story
title_vid: My son was a Columbine shooter. This is my story

title_talk: Know your worth, and then ask for it | Casey Brown
description: Your boss probably isn't paying you what you're worth -- instead, they're paying you what they think you're worth. Take the time to learn how to shape their thinking. Pricing consultant Casey Brown shares helpful stories and learnings that can help you better communicate your value and get paid for your excellence.
name: Casey Brown: Know your worth, and then ask for it
title_vid: Know your worth, and then ask for it

title_talk: Elizabeth Pisani: Sex, drugs and HIV -- let's get rational
description: Armed with bracing logic, wit and her "public-health nerd" glasses, Elizabeth Pisani reveals the myriad of inconsistencies in today's political systems that prevent our dollars from effectively fighting the spread of HIV. Her research with at-risk populations -- from junkies in prison to sex workers on the street in Cambodia -- demonstrates the sometimes counter-intuitive measures that could stall the spread of this devastating disease.
name: Elizabeth Pisani: Sex, drugs and HIV -- let's get rational
title_vid: Sex, drugs and HIV -- let's get rational

title_talk: Adam Ostrow: After your final status update
description: Many of us have a social media presence -- a virtual personality made up of status updates, tweets and connections, stored in the cloud. Adam Ostrow asks a big question: What happens to that personality after you've died? Could it ... live on?
name: Adam Ostrow: After your final status update
title_vid: After your final status update

title_talk: Bruce Aylward: How we'll stop polio for good
description: Polio is almost completely eradicated. But as Bruce Aylward says: Almost isn't good enough with a disease this terrifying. Aylward lays out the plan to continue the scientific miracle that ended polio in most of the world -- and to snuff it out everywhere, forever.
name: Bruce Aylward: How we'll stop polio for good
title_vid: How we'll stop polio for good

title_talk: Alex Tabarrok on how ideas trump crises
description: The "dismal science" truly shines in this optimistic talk, as economist Alex Tabarrok argues free trade and globalization are shaping our once-divided world into a community of idea-sharing more healthy, happy and prosperous than anyone's predictions.
name: Alex Tabarrok: How ideas trump crises
title_vid: How ideas trump crises

title_talk: Shereen El-Feki: How to fight an epidemic of bad laws
description: There is an epidemic of HIV, and with it an epidemic of bad laws -- laws that effectively criminalize being HIV positive. At the TEDxSummit in Doha, TED Fellow Shereen El-Feki gives a forceful argument that these laws, based in stigma, are actually helping the disease spread.
name: Shereen El-Feki: HIV -- how to fight an epidemic of bad laws
title_vid: HIV -- how to fight an epidemic of bad laws

title_talk: Paul Pholeros: How to reduce poverty? Fix homes
description: In 1985, architect Paul Pholeros was challenged to "stop people getting sick" in a small indigenous community in south Australia. And it meant thinking way beyond medicine. In this sparky, interactive talk, Pholeros shares his work with Healthabitat, which works to reduce poverty through practical design fixes -- in Australia and beyond.
name: Paul Pholeros: How to reduce poverty? Fix homes
title_vid: How to reduce poverty? Fix homes

title_talk: Kwame Anthony Appiah: Is religion good or bad? (This is a trick question)
description: Plenty of good things are done in the name of religion, and plenty of bad things too. But what is religion, exactly — is it good or bad, in and of itself? Philosopher Kwame Anthony Appiah offers a generous, surprising view.
name: Kwame Anthony Appiah: Is religion good or bad? (This is a trick question)
title_vid: Is religion good or bad? (This is a trick question)

title_talk: Tom Wujec demos the 13th-century astrolabe
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Ariel Garten: Know thyself, with a brain scanner
description: Imagine playing a video game controlled by your mind. Now imagine that game also teaches you about your own patterns of stress, relaxation and focus. Ariel Garten shows how looking at our own brain activity gives new meaning to the ancient dictum "know thyself."
name: Ariel Garten: Know thyself, with a brain scanner
title_vid: Know thyself, with a brain scanner

title_talk: Let's use video to reinvent education | Salman Khan
description: Salman Khan talks about how and why he created the remarkable Khan Academy, a carefully structured series of educational videos offering complete curricula in math and, now, other subjects. He shows the power of interactive exercises, and calls for teachers to consider flipping the traditional classroom script -- give students video lectures to watch at home, and do "homework" in the classroom with the teacher available to help.
name: Sal Khan: Let's use video to reinvent education
title_vid: Let's use video to reinvent education

title_talk: Abigail Washburn: Building US-China relations ... by banjo
description: TED Fellow Abigail Washburn wanted to be a lawyer improving US-China relations -- until she picked up a banjo. She tells a moving story of the remarkable connections she's formed touring across the United States and China while playing that banjo and singing in Chinese.
name: Abigail Washburn: Building US-China relations ... by banjo
title_vid: Building US-China relations ... by banjo

title_talk: Brenda Romero: Gaming for understanding
description: It's never easy to get across the magnitude of complex tragedies -- so when Brenda Romero's daughter came home from school asking about slavery, she did what she does for a living -- she designed a game. She describes the surprising effectiveness of this game, and others, in helping the player really understand the story.
name: Brenda Romero: Gaming for understanding
title_vid: Gaming for understanding

title_talk: Lucien Engelen: Crowdsource your health
description: You can use your smartphone to find a local ATM, but what if you need a defibrillator? Lucien Engelen shows us online innovations that are changing the way we save lives, including a crowdsourced map of local AEDs.
name: Lucien Engelen: Crowdsource your health
title_vid: Crowdsource your health

title_talk: I survived a terrorist attack. Here's what I learned | Gill Hicks
description: Gill Hicks's story is one of compassion and humanity, emerging from the ashes of chaos and hate. A survivor of the London terrorist bombings on July 7, 2005, she shares her story of the events of that day -- and the profound lessons that came as she learned how to live on.
name: Gill Hicks: I survived a terrorist attack. Here's what I learned
title_vid: I survived a terrorist attack. Here's what I learned

title_talk: Nicolas Perony: Puppies! Now that I've got your attention, complexity theory
description: Animal behavior isn't complicated, but it is complex. Nicolas Perony studies how individual animals -- be they Scottish Terriers, bats or meerkats -- follow simple rules that, collectively, create larger patterns of behavior. And how this complexity born of simplicity can help them adapt to new circumstances, as they arise.
name: Nicolas Perony: Puppies! Now that I’ve got your attention, complexity theory
title_vid: Puppies! Now that I’ve got your attention, complexity theory

title_talk: Annette Heuser: The 3 agencies with the power to make or break economies
description: The way we rate national economies is all wrong, says rating agency reformer Annette Heuser. With mysterious and obscure methods, three private US-based credit rating agencies wield immense power over national economies across the globe, and the outcomes can be catastrophic. But what if there was another way? In this bold talk, Heuser shares her vision for a nonprofit agency that would bring more equality and justice into the mix.
name: Annette Heuser: The 3 agencies with the power to make or break economies
title_vid: The 3 agencies with the power to make or break economies

title_talk: How we can end sexual harassment at work | Gretchen Carlson
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Marcel Dicke: Why not eat insects?
description: Marcel Dicke makes an appetizing case for adding insects to everyone's diet. His message to squeamish chefs and foodies: delicacies like locusts and caterpillars compete with meat in flavor, nutrition and eco-friendliness.
name: Marcel Dicke: Why not eat insects?
title_vid: Why not eat insects?

title_talk: Raghava KK: My 5 lives as an artist
description: With endearing honesty and vulnerability, Raghava KK tells the colorful tale of how art has taken his life to new places, and how life experiences in turn have driven his multiple reincarnations as an artist -- from cartoonist to painter, media darling to social outcast, and son to father.
name: Raghava KK: My 5 lives as an artist
title_vid: My 5 lives as an artist

title_talk: Anna Deavere Smith: Four American characters
description: Writer and actor Anna Deavere Smith gives life to author Studs Terkel, convict Paulette Jenkins, a Korean shopkeeper and a bull rider, excerpts from her solo show "On the Road: A Search for American Character."
name: Anna Deavere Smith: Four American characters
title_vid: Four American characters

title_talk: Archeology from space | Sarah Parcak
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The mystery box | JJ Abrams
description: J.J. Abrams traces his love for the unseen mystery –- a passion that's evident in his films and TV shows, including Lost, Star Trek and the upcoming Star Wars VII -- back to its magical beginnings.
name: J.J. Abrams: The mystery box
title_vid: The mystery box

title_talk: Marisa Fick-Jordan: The wonders of Zulu wire art
description: In this short, image-packed talk, Marisa Fick-Jordan talks about how a village of traditional Zulu wire weavers built a worldwide market for their dazzling work.
name: Marisa Fick-Jordan: The wonder of Zulu wire art
title_vid: The wonder of Zulu wire art

title_talk: A new way to study the brain's invisible secrets | Ed Boyden
description: Neuroengineer Ed Boyden wants to know how the tiny biomolecules in our brains generate emotions, thoughts and feelings -- and he wants to find the molecular changes that lead to disorders like epilepsy and Alzheimer's. Rather than magnify these invisible structures with a microscope, he wondered: What if we physically enlarge them and make them easier to see? Learn how the same polymers used to make baby diapers swell could be a key to better understanding our brains.
name: Ed Boyden: A new way to study the brain's invisible secrets
title_vid: A new way to study the brain's invisible secrets

title_talk: How I hacked online dating | Amy Webb
description: Amy Webb was having no luck with online dating. The dates she liked didn't write her back, and her own profile attracted crickets (and worse). So, as any fan of data would do: she started making a spreadsheet. Hear the story of how she went on to hack her online dating life -- with frustrating, funny and life-changing results.
name: Amy Webb: How I hacked online dating
speaker_occupation: Founder and CEO, Future Today Institute
title_vid: How I hacked online dating

title_talk: Dave Troy: Social maps that reveal a city's intersections — and separations
description: Every city has its neighborhoods, cliques and clubs, the hidden lines that join and divide people in the same town. What can we learn about cities by looking at what people share online? Starting with his own home town of Baltimore, Dave Troy has been visualizing what the tweets of city dwellers reveal about who lives there, who they talk to — and who they don’t.
name: Dave Troy: Social maps that reveal a city's intersections — and separations
title_vid: Social maps that reveal a city's intersections — and separations

title_talk: Deborah Scranton: Scenes from "The War Tapes"
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: How to see past your own perspective and find truth | Michael Patrick Lynch
description: The more we read and watch online, the harder it becomes to tell the difference between what's real and what's fake. It's as if we know more but understand less, says philosopher Michael Patrick Lynch. In this talk, he dares us to take active steps to burst our filter bubbles and participate in the common reality that actually underpins everything.
name: Michael Patrick Lynch: How to see past your own perspective and find truth
title_vid: How to see past your own perspective and find truth

title_talk: Dare to refuse the origin myths that claim who you are | Chetan Bhatt
description: We all have origin stories and identity myths, our tribal narratives that give us a sense of security and belonging. But sometimes our small-group identities can keep us from connecting with humanity as a whole -- and even keep us from seeing others as human. In a powerful talk about how we understand who we are, Chetan Bhatt challenges us to think creatively about each other and our future. As he puts it: it's time to change the question from "Where are you from?" to "Where are you going?"
name: Chetan Bhatt: Dare to refuse the origin myths that claim who you are
title_vid: Dare to refuse the origin myths that claim who you are

title_talk: How to build a business that lasts 100 years | Martin Reeves
description: If you want to build a business that lasts, there may be no better place to look for inspiration than your own immune system. Join strategist Martin Reeves as he shares startling statistics about shrinking corporate life spans and explains how executives can apply six principles from living organisms to build resilient businesses that flourish in the face of change.
name: Martin Reeves: How to build a business that lasts 100 years
title_vid: How to build a business that lasts 100 years

title_talk: Carolyn Porco: Could a Saturn moon harbor life?
description: Carolyn Porco shares exciting new findings from the Cassini spacecraft's recent sweep of one of Saturn's moons, Enceladus. Samples gathered from the moon's icy geysers hint that an ocean under its surface could harbor life.
name: Carolyn Porco: Could a Saturn moon harbor life?
title_vid: Could a Saturn moon harbor life?

title_talk: Exploring the mind of a killer | Jim Fallon
description: Psychopathic killers are the basis for some must-watch TV, but what really makes them tick? Neuroscientist Jim Fallon talks about brain scans and genetic analysis that may uncover the rotten wiring in the nature (and nurture) of murderers. In a too-strange-for-fiction twist, he shares a fascinating family history that makes his work chillingly personal.
name: Jim Fallon: Exploring the mind of a killer
title_vid: Exploring the mind of a killer

title_talk: The deadly genius of drug cartels | Rodrigo Canales
description: Up to 100,000 people died in drug-related violence in Mexico in the last 6 years. We might think this has nothing to do with us, but in fact we are all complicit, says Yale professor Rodrigo Canales in this unflinching talk that turns conventional wisdom about drug cartels on its head. The carnage is not about faceless, ignorant goons mindlessly killing each other but is rather the result of some seriously sophisticated brand management.
name: Rodrigo Canales: The deadly genius of drug cartels
title_vid: The deadly genius of drug cartels

title_talk: Lee Cronin: Print your own medicine
description: Chemist Lee Cronin is working on a 3D printer that, instead of objects, is able to print molecules. An exciting potential long-term application: printing your own medicine using chemical inks.
name: Lee Cronin: Print your own medicine
title_vid: Print your own medicine

title_talk: Gever Tulley: 5 dangerous things you should let your kids do
description: At TED U, Gever Tulley, founder of the Tinkering School, spells out 5 dangerous things you should let your kids do -- and why a little danger is good for both kids and grownups.
name: Gever Tulley: 5 dangerous things you should let your kids do
title_vid: 5 dangerous things you should let your kids do

title_talk: Ian Ritchie: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee
description: Imagine it's late 1990, and you've just met a nice young man named Tim Berners-Lee, who starts telling you about his proposed system called the World Wide Web. Ian Ritchie was there. And ... he didn't buy it. A short story about information, connectivity and learning from mistakes.
name: Ian Ritchie: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee
title_vid: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee

title_talk: Frank Gehry: From 1990, defending a vision for architecture
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The silent drama of photography | Sebastião Salgado
description: Economics PhD Sebastião Salgado only took up photography in his 30s, but the discipline became an obsession. His years-long projects beautifully capture the human side of a global story that all too often involves death, destruction or decay. Here, he tells a deeply personal story of the craft that nearly killed him, and shows breathtaking images from his latest work, Genesis, which documents the world's forgotten people and places.
name: Sebastião Salgado: The silent drama of photography
title_vid: The silent drama of photography

title_talk: Rainer Strack: The surprising workforce crisis of 2030 — and how to start solving it now
description: It sounds counterintuitive, but by 2030, many of the world's largest economies will have more jobs than adult citizens to do those jobs. In this data-filled -- and quite charming -- talk, human resources expert Rainer Strack suggests that countries ought to look across borders for mobile and willing job seekers. But to do that, they need to start by changing the culture in their businesses.
name: Rainer Strack: The workforce crisis of 2030 -- and how to start solving it now
title_vid: The workforce crisis of 2030 -- and how to start solving it now

title_talk: What the discovery of gravitational waves means | Allan Adams
description: More than a billion years ago, two black holes in a distant galaxy locked into a spiral, falling inexorably toward each other, and collided. "All that energy was pumped into the fabric of time and space itself," says theoretical physicist Allan Adams, "making the universe explode in roiling waves of gravity." About 25 years ago, a group of scientists built a giant laser detector called LIGO to search for these kinds of waves, which had been predicted but never observed. In this mind-bending talk, Adams breaks down what happened when, in September 2015, LIGO detected an unthinkably small anomaly, leading to one of the most exciting discoveries in the history of physics.
name: Allan Adams: What the discovery of gravitational waves means
title_vid: What the discovery of gravitational waves means

title_talk: Jason Pontin: Can technology solve our big problems?
description: In 1969, Buzz Aldrin’s historical step onto the moon leapt mankind into an era of technological possibility. The awesome power of technology was to be used to solve all of our big problems. Fast forward to present day, and what's happened? Are mobile apps all we have to show for ourselves? Journalist Jason Pontin looks closely at the challenges we face to using technology effectively ... for problems that really matter.
name: Jason Pontin: Can technology solve our big problems?
title_vid: Can technology solve our big problems?

title_talk: Damon Horowitz: Philosophy in prison
description: Damon Horowitz teaches philosophy through the Prison University Project, bringing college-level classes to inmates of San Quentin State Prison. In this powerful short talk, he tells the story of an encounter with right and wrong that quickly gets personal.
name: Damon Horowitz: Philosophy in prison
title_vid: Philosophy in prison

title_talk: Gregory Stock: To upgrade is human
description: In this prophetic 2003 talk -- just days before Dolly the sheep was stuffed -- biotech ethicist Gregory Stock looked forward to new, more meaningful (and controversial) technologies, like customizable babies, whose adoption might drive human evolution.
name: Gregory Stock: To upgrade is human
title_vid: To upgrade is human

title_talk: How sampling transformed music | Mark Ronson
description: Sampling isn't about "hijacking nostalgia wholesale," says Mark Ronson. It's about inserting yourself into the narrative of a song while also pushing that story forward. In this mind-blowingly original talk, watch the DJ scramble 15 TED Talks into an audio-visual omelette, and trace the evolution of "La Di Da Di," Doug E. Fresh and Slick Rick's 1984 hit that has been reimagined for every generation since.
name: Mark Ronson: How sampling transformed music
title_vid: How sampling transformed music

title_talk: Andrew Bastawrous: Get your next eye exam on a smartphone
description: Thirty-nine million people in the world are blind, and the majority lost their sight due to curable and preventable diseases. But how do you test and treat people who live in remote areas, where expensive, bulky eye equipment is hard to come by? TED Fellow Andrew Bastawrous demos a smartphone app and cheap hardware that might help.
name: Andrew Bastawrous: Get your next eye exam on a smartphone
title_vid: Get your next eye exam on a smartphone

title_talk: Dean Ornish: The world's killer diet
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: A skateboard, with a boost | Sanjay Dastoor
description: Imagine an electric vehicle that can get you to work -- or anywhere in a six-mile radius -- quickly, without traffic frustrations or gasoline. Now imagine you can pick it up and carry it with you. Yes, this souped-up skateboard could change the face of morning commutes.
name: Sanjay Dastoor: A skateboard, with a boost
title_vid: A skateboard, with a boost

title_talk: Don't fear intelligent machines. Work with them | Garry Kasparov
description: We must face our fears if we want to get the most out of technology -- and we must conquer those fears if we want to get the best out of humanity, says Garry Kasparov. One of the greatest chess players in history, Kasparov lost a memorable match to IBM supercomputer Deep Blue in 1997. Now he shares his vision for a future where intelligent machines help us turn our grandest dreams into reality.
name: Garry Kasparov: Don't fear intelligent machines. Work with them
title_vid: Don't fear intelligent machines. Work with them

title_talk: What's so sexy about math? | Cédric Villani
description: Hidden truths permeate our world; they're inaccessible to our senses, but math allows us to go beyond our intuition to uncover their mysteries. In this survey of mathematical breakthroughs, Fields Medal winner Cédric Villani speaks to the thrill of discovery and details the sometimes perplexing life of a mathematician. "Beautiful mathematical explanations are not only for our pleasure," he says. "They change our vision of the world."
name: Cédric Villani: What's so sexy about math?
title_vid: What's so sexy about math?

title_talk: Hidden Cameras Film Injustice in Dangerous Places | Oren Yakobovich | TED Talks
description: To see is to believe, says Oren Yakobovich — which is why he helps everyday people use hidden cameras to film dangerous situations of violence, political fraud and abuse. His organization, Videre, uncovers, verifies and publicizes human-rights abuses that the world needs to witness.
name: Oren Yakobovich: Hidden cameras that film injustice in the world’s most dangerous places
title_vid: Hidden cameras that film injustice in the world’s most dangerous places

title_talk: The strange story of the teddy bear and what it reveals | Jon Mooallem
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: John Kasaona: How poachers became caretakers
description: In his home of Namibia, John Kasaona is working on an innovative way to protect endangered animal species: giving nearby villagers (including former poachers) responsibility for caring for the animals. And it's working.
name: John Kasaona: How poachers became caretakers
title_vid: How poachers became caretakers

title_talk: 10 things you didn't know about orgasm | Mary Roach
description: "Bonk" author Mary Roach delves into obscure scientific research, some of it centuries old, to make 10 surprising claims about sexual climax, ranging from the bizarre to the hilarious. (This talk is aimed at adults. Viewer discretion advised.)
name: Mary Roach: 10 things you didn't know about orgasm
title_vid: 10 things you didn't know about orgasm

title_talk: 5 ways to listen better | Julian Treasure
description: In our louder and louder world, says sound expert Julian Treasure, "We are losing our listening." In this short, fascinating talk, Treasure shares five ways to re-tune your ears for conscious listening -- to other people and the world around you.
name: Julian Treasure: 5 ways to listen better
title_vid: 5 ways to listen better

title_talk: Charles Anderson discovers dragonflies that cross oceans
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Kevin Kelly tells technology's epic story
description: In this wide-ranging, thought-provoking talk, Kevin Kelly muses on what technology means in our lives -- from its impact at the personal level to its place in the cosmos.
name: Kevin Kelly: Technology's epic story
title_vid: Technology's epic story

title_talk: How Argentina's blind soccer team became champions (with English subtitles) | Gonzalo Vilariño
description: With warmth and respect, Gonzalo Vilariño tells the captivating story of Argentina's blind soccer team -- and how a sincere belief in themselves and their capabilities transformed the players from humble beginnings into two-time World Champions. "You have to get out there and play every game in this beautiful tournament that we call life," Vilariño says.
name: Gonzalo Vilariño: How Argentina's blind soccer team became champions
title_vid: How Argentina's blind soccer team became champions

title_talk: Natalie MacMaster & Thomas Dolby: Fiddling in reel time
description: Natalie MacMaster and her musical partner Donnell Leahy play several tunes from the Cape Breton tradition -- a sprightly, soulful style of folk fiddling. It's an inspired collaboration that will have you clapping (and maybe dancing) along.
name: Natalie MacMaster: Fiddling in reel time
title_vid: Fiddling in reel time

title_talk: A taboo-free way to talk about periods | Aditi Gupta
description: It's true: talking about menstruation makes many people uncomfortable. And that taboo has consequences: in India, three out of every 10 girls don't even know what menstruation is at the time of their first period, and restrictive customs related to periods inflict psychological damage on young girls. Growing up with this taboo herself, Aditi Gupta knew she wanted to help girls, parents and teachers talk about periods comfortably and without shame. She shares how she did it.
name: Aditi Gupta: A taboo-free way to talk about periods
title_vid: A taboo-free way to talk about periods

title_talk: Carmen Agra Deedy: Spinning a story of Mama
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Talking and squawking | Einstein the parrot and Stephanie White
description: This whimsical wrap-up of TED2006 -- presented by Einstein, the African grey parrot, and her trainer, Stephanie White -- simply tickles. Watch for the moment when Einstein has a moment with Al Gore.
name: Einstein the Parrot: A talking, squawking parrot
title_vid: A talking, squawking parrot

title_talk: Your smartphone is a civil rights issue | Christopher Soghoian
description: The smartphone you use reflects more than just personal taste ... it could determine how closely you can be tracked, too. Privacy expert and TED Fellow Christopher Soghoian details a glaring difference between the encryption used on Apple and Android devices and urges us to pay attention to a growing digital security divide. "If the only people who can protect themselves from the gaze of the government are the rich and powerful, that's a problem," he says. "It's not just a cybersecurity problem -- it's a civil rights problem."
name: Christopher Soghoian: Your smartphone is a civil rights issue
title_vid: Your smartphone is a civil rights issue

title_talk: What we didn't know about male anatomy | Diane Kelly
description: We're not done with anatomy. We know a tremendous amount about genomics, proteomics and cell biology, but as Diane Kelly makes clear at TEDMED, there are basic facts about the human body we're still learning. Case in point: How does the mammalian erection work?
name: Diane Kelly: What we didn't know about penis anatomy
title_vid: What we didn't know about penis anatomy

title_talk: Hadyn Parry: Re-engineering mosquitos to fight disease
description: In a single year, there are 200-300 million cases of malaria and 50-100 million cases of dengue fever worldwide. So: Why haven't we found a way to effectively kill mosquitos yet? Hadyn Parry presents a fascinating solution: genetically engineering male mosquitos to make them sterile, and releasing the insects into the wild, to cut down on disease-carrying species.
name: Hadyn Parry: Re-engineering mosquitos to fight disease
title_vid: Re-engineering mosquitos to fight disease

title_talk: The danger of a single story | Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
description: Our lives, our cultures, are composed of many overlapping stories. Novelist Chimamanda Adichie tells the story of how she found her authentic cultural voice -- and warns that if we hear only a single story about another person or country, we risk a critical misunderstanding.
name: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: The danger of a single story
title_vid: The danger of a single story

title_talk: Homeopathy, quackery and fraud | James Randi
description: Legendary skeptic James Randi takes a fatal dose of homeopathic sleeping pills onstage, kicking off a searing 18-minute indictment of irrational beliefs. He throws out a challenge to the world's psychics: Prove what you do is real, and I'll give you a million dollars. (No takers yet.)
name: James Randi: Homeopathy, quackery and fraud
title_vid: Homeopathy, quackery and fraud

title_talk: Ballroom dance that breaks gender roles | Trevor Copp and Jeff Fox
description: Tango, waltz, foxtrot ... these classic ballroom dances quietly perpetuate an outdated idea: that the man always leads and the woman always follows. That's an idea worth changing, say Trevor Copp and Jeff Fox, as they demonstrate their "Liquid Lead" dance technique along with fellow dancer Alida Esmail. Watch as Copp and Fox captivate and command the stage while boldly deconstructing and transforming the art of ballroom dance.
name: Trevor Copp and Jeff Fox: Ballroom dance that breaks gender roles
title_vid: Ballroom dance that breaks gender roles

title_talk: Iain Hutchison: Saving faces
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Deb Roy: The birth of a word
description: MIT researcher Deb Roy wanted to understand how his infant son learned language -- so he wired up his house with videocameras to catch every moment (with exceptions) of his son's life, then parsed 90,000 hours of home video to watch "gaaaa" slowly turn into "water." Astonishing, data-rich research with deep implications for how we learn.
name: Deb Roy: The birth of a word
title_vid: The birth of a word

title_talk: Kary Mullis: Celebrating the scientific experiment
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The mathematician who cracked Wall Street | Jim Simons
description: Jim Simons was a mathematician and cryptographer who realized: the complex math he used to break codes could help explain patterns in the world of finance. Billions later, he's working to support the next generation of math teachers and scholars. TED's Chris Anderson sits down with Simons to talk about his extraordinary life in numbers.
name: Jim Simons: The mathematician who cracked Wall Street
title_vid: The mathematician who cracked Wall Street

title_talk: One more reason to get a good night’s sleep | Jeff Iliff
description: The brain uses a quarter of the body's entire energy supply, yet only accounts for about two percent of the body's mass. So how does this unique organ receive and, perhaps more importantly, rid itself of vital nutrients? New research suggests it has to do with sleep.
name: Jeff Iliff: One more reason to get a good night's sleep
title_vid: One more reason to get a good night's sleep

title_talk: Shimon Steinberg: Natural pest control ... using bugs!
description: What's the difference between a pest and a bug? Shimon Steinberg makes the case for using good bugs to fight bad bugs, avoiding chemicals in our quest for perfect produce.
name: Shimon Steinberg: Natural pest control ... using bugs!
title_vid: Natural pest control ... using bugs!

title_talk: Caroline Lavelle: A cello performance that casts a spell
description: Caroline Lavelle plays the cello like a sorceress casting a spell, occasionally hiding behind her wild mane of blond hair as she sings of pastoral themes. She performs "Farther than the Sun," backed by Thomas Dolby on keyboards.
name: Caroline Lavelle: Casting a spell on the cello
title_vid: Casting a spell on the cello

title_talk: Weird, or just different? | Derek Sivers
description: "There's a flip side to everything," the saying goes, and in 2 minutes, Derek Sivers shows this is true in a few ways you might not expect.
name: Derek Sivers: Weird, or just different?
title_vid: Weird, or just different?

title_talk: Demo: Stunning data visualization in the AlloSphere
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Marvin Minsky: Health, population and the human mind
description: Listen closely -- Marvin Minsky's arch, eclectic, charmingly offhand talk on health, overpopulation and the human mind is packed with subtlety: wit, wisdom and just an ounce of wily, is-he-joking? advice.
name: Marvin Minsky: Health and the human mind
title_vid: Health and the human mind

title_talk: Jonathan Trent: Energy from floating algae pods
description: Call it "fuel without fossils": Jonathan Trent is working on a plan to grow new biofuel by farming micro-algae in floating offshore pods that eat wastewater from cities. Hear his team's bold vision for Project OMEGA (Offshore Membrane Enclosures for Growing Algae) and how it might power the future.
name: Jonathan Trent: Energy from floating algae pods
title_vid: Energy from floating algae pods

title_talk: The lies we tell pregnant women | Sofia Jawed-Wessel
description: "When we tell women that sex isn't worth the risk during pregnancy, what we're telling her is that her sexual pleasure doesn't matter ... that she in fact doesn't matter," says sex researcher Sofia Jawed-Wessel. In this eye-opening talk, Jawed-Wessel mines our views about pregnancy and pleasure to lay bare the relationship between women, sex and systems of power.
name: Sofia Jawed-Wessel: The lies we tell pregnant women
title_vid: The lies we tell pregnant women

title_talk: Patrick Awuah: Educating a new generation of African leaders
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Phil Borges: Documenting our endangered cultures
description: Photographer Phil Borges shows rarely seen images of people from the mountains of Dharamsala, India, and the jungles of the Ecuadorean Amazon. In documenting these endangered cultures, he intends to help preserve them.
name: Phil Borges: Photos of endangered cultures
title_vid: Photos of endangered cultures

title_talk: Jacqueline Novogratz: Investing in Africa's own solutions
description: Jacqueline Novogratz applauds the world's heightened interest in Africa and poverty, but argues persuasively for a new approach.
name: Jacqueline Novogratz: Invest in Africa's own solutions
speaker_occupation: Investor and advocate for moral leadership
title_vid: Invest in Africa's own solutions

title_talk: Imogen Heap plays "Wait It Out"
description: Imogen Heap plays a powerful stripped-down version of "Wait It Out," from her new record, Ellipse.
name: Imogen Heap: "Wait It Out"
title_vid: "Wait It Out"

title_talk: My Country Will Be Underwater Soon -- Unless We Work Together | Anote Tong | TED Talks
description: For the people of Kiribati, climate change isn't something to be debated, denied or legislated against -- it's an everyday reality. The low-lying Pacific island nation may soon be underwater, thanks to rising sea levels. In a personal conversation with TED Curator Chris Anderson, Kiribati President Anote Tong discusses his country's present climate catastrophe and its imperiled future. "In order to deal with climate change, there's got to be sacrifice. There's got to be commitment," he says. "We've got to tell people that the world has changed."
name: Anote Tong: My country will be underwater soon -- unless we work together
speaker_occupation: President of the Republic of Kiribati
title_vid: My country will be underwater soon -- unless we work together

title_talk: Kent Larson: Brilliant designs to fit more people in every city
description: How can we fit more people into cities without overcrowding? Kent Larson shows off folding cars, quick-change apartments and other innovations that could make the city of the future work a lot like a small village of the past.
name: Kent Larson: Brilliant designs to fit more people in every city
title_vid: Brilliant designs to fit more people in every city

title_talk: How to grow fresh air | Kamal Meattle
description: Researcher Kamal Meattle shows how an arrangement of three common houseplants, used in specific spots in a home or office building, can result in measurably cleaner indoor air.
name: Kamal Meattle: How to grow fresh air
title_vid: How to grow fresh air

title_talk: Billy Collins: Everyday moments, caught in time
description: Combining dry wit with artistic depth, Billy Collins shares a project in which several of his poems were turned into delightful animated films in a collaboration with Sundance Channel. Five of them are included in this wonderfully entertaining and moving talk -- and don't miss the hilarious final poem!
name: Billy Collins: Everyday moments, caught in time
title_vid: Everyday moments, caught in time

title_talk: How trees talk to each other | Suzanne Simard
description: "A forest is much more than what you see," says ecologist Suzanne Simard. Her 30 years of research in Canadian forests have led to an astounding discovery -- trees talk, often and over vast distances. Learn more about the harmonious yet complicated social lives of trees and prepare to see the natural world with new eyes.
name: Suzanne Simard: How trees talk to each other
title_vid: How trees talk to each other

title_talk: The brain in love | Helen Fisher
description: Why do we crave love so much, even to the point that we would die for it? To learn more about our very real, very physical need for romantic love, Helen Fisher and her research team took MRIs of people in love -- and people who had just been dumped.
name: Helen Fisher: The brain in love
title_vid: The brain in love

title_talk: Michael Sandel: Why we shouldn't trust markets with our civic life
description: In the past three decades, says Michael Sandel, the US has drifted from a market economy to a market society; it's fair to say that an American's experience of shared civic life depends on how much money they have. (Three key examples: access to education, access to justice, political influence.) In a talk and audience discussion, Sandel asks us to think honestly on this question: In our current democracy, is too much for sale?
name: Michael Sandel: Why we shouldn't trust markets with our civic life
title_vid: Why we shouldn't trust markets with our civic life

title_talk: A project of peace, painted across 50 buildings | eL Seed
description: eL Seed fuses Arabic calligraphy with graffiti to paint colorful, swirling messages of hope and peace on buildings from Tunisia to Paris. The artist and TED Fellow shares the story of his most ambitious project yet: a mural painted across 50 buildings in Manshiyat Naser, a district of Cairo, Egypt, that can only be fully seen from a nearby mountain.
name: eL Seed: A project of peace, painted across 50 buildings
title_vid: A project of peace, painted across 50 buildings

title_talk: The era of blind faith in big data must end | Cathy O'Neil
description: Algorithms decide who gets a loan, who gets a job interview, who gets insurance and much more -- but they don't automatically make things fair. Mathematician and data scientist Cathy O'Neil coined a term for algorithms that are secret, important and harmful: "weapons of math destruction." Learn more about the hidden agendas behind the formulas.
name: Cathy O'Neil: The era of blind faith in big data must end
title_vid: The era of blind faith in big data must end

title_talk: Carl Honore: In praise of slowness
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Who belongs in a city? |  OluTimehin Adegbeye
description: Underneath every shiny new megacity, there's often a story of communities displaced. In this moving, poetic talk, OluTimehin Adegbeye details how government land grabs are destroying the lives of thousands who live in the coastal communities of Lagos, Nigeria, to make way for a "new Dubai." She compels us to hold our governments and ourselves accountable for keeping our cities safe for everyone. "The only cities worth building, indeed the only futures worth dreaming of, are those that include all of us, no matter who we are or how we make homes for ourselves," she says.
name: OluTimehin Adegbeye: Who belongs in a city?
title_vid: Who belongs in a city?

title_talk: Nancy Kanwisher: A neural portrait of the human mind
description: Brain imaging pioneer Nancy Kanwisher, who uses fMRI scans to see activity in brain regions (often her own), shares what she and her colleagues have learned: The brain is made up of both highly specialized components and general-purpose "machinery." Another surprise: There's so much left to learn.
name: Nancy Kanwisher: A neural portrait of the human mind
title_vid: A neural portrait of the human mind

title_talk: Parag Khanna maps the future of countries
description: Many people think the lines on the map no longer matter, but Parag Khanna says they do. Using maps of the past and present, he explains the root causes of border conflicts worldwide and proposes simple yet cunning solutions for each.
name: Parag Khanna: Mapping the future of countries
title_vid: Mapping the future of countries

title_talk: Tom Shannon: The painter and the pendulum
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Phil Plait: How to defend Earth from asteroids
description: What's six miles wide and can end civilization in an instant? An asteroid -- and there are lots of them out there. With humor and great visuals, Phil Plait shows us all the ways asteroids can kill us (yipes), and what we must do to avoid them.
name: Phil Plait: How to defend Earth from asteroids
title_vid: How to defend Earth from asteroids

title_talk: Leah Buechley: How to "sketch" with electronics
description: Designing electronics is generally cumbersome and expensive -- or was, until Leah Buechley and her team at MIT developed tools to treat electronics just like paper and pen. In this talk from TEDYouth 2011, Buechley shows some of her charming designs, like a paper piano you can sketch and then play.
name: Leah Buechley: How to "sketch" with electronics
title_vid: How to "sketch" with electronics

title_talk: Bernie Krause: The voice of the natural world
description: Bernie Krause has been recording wild soundscapes -- the wind in the trees, the chirping of birds, the subtle sounds of insect larvae -- for 45 years. In that time, he has seen many environments radically altered by humans, sometimes even by practices thought to be environmentally safe. A surprising look at what we can learn through nature's symphonies, from the grunting of a sea anemone to the sad calls of a beaver in mourning.
name: Bernie Krause: The voice of the natural world
title_vid: The voice of the natural world

title_talk: Bob Mankoff: Anatomy of a New Yorker cartoon
description: The New Yorker receives around 1,000 cartoons each week; it only publishes about 17 of them. In this hilarious, fast-paced, and insightful talk, the magazine's longstanding cartoon editor and self-proclaimed "humor analyst" Bob Mankoff dissects the comedy within just some of the "idea drawings" featured in the magazine, explaining what works, what doesn't, and why.
name: Bob Mankoff: Anatomy of a New Yorker cartoon
title_vid: Anatomy of a New Yorker cartoon

title_talk: Thomas Insel: Toward a new understanding of mental illness
description: Today, thanks to better early detection, there are 63% fewer deaths from heart disease than there were just a few decades ago. Thomas Insel, the director of the National Institute of Mental Health, wonders: Could we do the same for depression and schizophrenia?
