description: Would you kill for a pair of Air Jordans? Lemon Andersen spins a tale of someone who did, reciting a poem by Reg E. Gaines. These verses taught Lemon that poetry could be about more than self-expression, and could sound like music when given rhythm and infused with the grit of the New York streets around him.
name: Lemon Andersen: Please don't take my Air Jordans
title_vid: Please don't take my Air Jordans

title_talk: Bill Gates: The next outbreak? We’re not ready
description: In 2014, the world avoided a global outbreak of Ebola, thanks to thousands of selfless health workers -- plus, frankly, some very good luck. In hindsight, we know what we should have done better. So, now's the time, Bill Gates suggests, to put all our good ideas into practice, from scenario planning to vaccine research to health worker training. As he says, "There's no need to panic ... but we need to get going."
name: Bill Gates: The next outbreak? We’re not ready
title_vid: The next outbreak? We’re not ready

title_talk: A.J. Jacobs: My year of living biblically
description: Author, philosopher, prankster and journalist AJ Jacobs talks about the year he spent living biblically -- following the rules in the Bible as literally as possible.
name: AJ Jacobs: My year of living biblically
title_vid: My year of living biblically

title_talk: Richard Weller: Could the sun be good for your heart?
description: Our bodies get Vitamin D from the sun, but as dermatologist Richard Weller suggests, sunlight may confer another surprising benefit too. New research by his team shows that nitric oxide, a chemical transmitter stored in huge reserves in the skin, can be released by UV light, to great benefit for blood pressure and the cardiovascular system. What does it mean? Well, it might begin to explain why Scots get sick more than Australians ...
name: Richard Weller: Could the sun be good for your heart?
title_vid: Could the sun be good for your heart?

title_talk: Marco Tempest: The augmented reality of techno-magic
description: Using sleight-of-hand techniques and charming storytelling, illusionist Marco Tempest brings a jaunty stick figure to life onstage at TEDGlobal.
name: Marco Tempest: Augmented reality, techno-magic
title_vid: Augmented reality, techno-magic

title_talk: Charles Elachi: The story of the Mars Rovers
description: At Serious Play 2008, Charles Elachi shares stories from NASA's legendary Jet Propulsion Lab -- including tales and video from the Mars Rover project.
name: Charles Elachi: The story behind the Mars Rovers
title_vid: The story behind the Mars Rovers

title_talk: Tierney Thys: Swim with giant sunfish in the open ocean
description: Marine biologist Tierney Thys asks us to step into the water to visit the world of the Mola mola, or giant ocean sunfish. Basking, eating jellyfish and getting massages, this behemoth offers clues to life in the open sea.
name: Tierney Thys: Swim with the giant sunfish
title_vid: Swim with the giant sunfish

title_talk: Nicholas Negroponte: 5 predictions, in 1984
description: With surprising accuracy, Nicholas Negroponte predicts what will happen with CD-ROMs, web interfaces, service kiosks, the touchscreen interface of the iPhone and his own One Laptop per Child project.
name: Nicholas Negroponte: 5 predictions, from 1984
title_vid: 5 predictions, from 1984

title_talk: Help for kids the education system ignores | Victor Rios
description: Define students by what they contribute, not what they lack -- especially those with difficult upbringings, says educator Victor Rios. Interweaved with his personal tale of perseverance as an inner-city youth, Rios identifies three straightforward strategies to shift attitudes in education and calls for fellow educators to see "at-risk" students as "at-promise" individuals brimming with resilience, character and grit.
name: Victor Rios: Help for kids the education system ignores
title_vid: Help for kids the education system ignores

title_talk: This is what democracy looks like | Anthony D. Romero
description: In a quest to make sense of the political environment in the United States in 2017, lawyer and ACLU executive director Anthony D. Romero turned to a surprising place -- a 14th-century fresco by Italian Renaissance master Ambrogio Lorenzetti. What could a 700-year-old painting possibly teach us about life today? Turns out, a lot. Romero explains all in a talk that's as striking as the painting itself.
name: Anthony D. Romero: This is what democracy looks like
title_vid: This is what democracy looks like

title_talk: Tim Brown: Tales of creativity and play
description: At the 2008 Serious Play conference, designer Tim Brown talks about the powerful relationship between creative thinking and play -- with many examples you can try at home (and one that maybe you shouldn't).
name: Tim Brown: Tales of creativity and play
title_vid: Tales of creativity and play

title_talk: My year of saying yes to everything | Shonda Rhimes
description: Shonda Rhimes, the titan behind Grey's Anatomy, Scandal and How to Get Away With Murder, is responsible for some 70 hours of television per season, and she loves to work. "When I am hard at work, when I am deep in it, there is no other feeling," she says. She has a name for this feeling: The hum. The hum is a drug, the hum is music, the hum is God's whisper in her ear. But what happens when it stops? Is she anything besides the hum? In this moving talk, join Rhimes on a journey through her "year of yes" and find out how she got her hum back.
name: Shonda Rhimes: My year of saying yes to everything
title_vid: My year of saying yes to everything

title_talk: Cynthia Kenyon: Experiments that hint of longer lives
description: What controls aging? Biochemist Cynthia Kenyon has found a simple genetic mutation that can double the lifespan of a simple worm, C. elegans. The lessons from that discovery, and others, are pointing to how we might one day significantly extend youthful human life.
name: Cynthia Kenyon: Experiments that hint of longer lives
title_vid: Experiments that hint of longer lives

title_talk: James Burchfield: Sound stylings by a human beatbox
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Alex Wissner-Gross: A new equation for intelligence
description: Is there an equation for intelligence? Yes. It's F = T ∇ Sτ. In a fascinating and informative talk, physicist and computer scientist Alex Wissner-Gross explains what in the world that means.
name: Alex Wissner-Gross: A new equation for intelligence
title_vid: A new equation for intelligence

title_talk: Philippe Starck: Design and destiny
description: Designer Philippe Starck -- with no pretty slides to show -- spends 18 minutes reaching for the very roots of the question "Why design?" Listen carefully for one perfect mantra for all of us, genius or not.
name: Philippe Starck: Design and destiny
title_vid: Design and destiny

title_talk: Have we reached the end of physics? | Harry Cliff
description: Why is there something rather than nothing? Why does so much interesting stuff exist in the universe? Particle physicist Harry Cliff works on the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and he has some potentially bad news for people who seek answers to these questions. Despite the best efforts of scientists (and the help of the biggest machine on the planet), we may never be able to explain all the weird features of nature. Is this the end of physics? Learn more in this fascinating talk about the latest research into the secret structure of the universe.
name: Harry Cliff: Have we reached the end of physics?
title_vid: Have we reached the end of physics?

title_talk: Tim Harford: Trial, error and the God complex
description: Economics writer Tim Harford studies complex systems -- and finds a surprising link among the successful ones: they were built through trial and error. In this sparkling talk from TEDGlobal 2011, he asks us to embrace our randomness and start making better mistakes.
name: Tim Harford: Trial, error and the God complex
title_vid: Trial, error and the God complex

title_talk: The next species of human | Juan Enriquez
description: While the mega-banks were toppling in early 2009, Juan Enriquez took the stage to say: The really big reboot is yet to come. But don't look for it on the stock exchange or the political ballot. It'll come from science labs, and it promises keener bodies and minds. Our kids are going to be ... different.
name: Juan Enriquez: The next species of human
title_vid: The next species of human

title_talk: Nicholas Negroponte: The vision behind One Laptop Per Child
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Susan Etlinger: What do we do with all this big data?
description: Does a set of data make you feel more comfortable? More successful? Then your interpretation of it is likely wrong. In a surprisingly moving talk, Susan Etlinger explains why, as we receive more and more data, we need to deepen our critical thinking skills. Because it's hard to move beyond counting things to really understanding them.
name: Susan Etlinger: What do we do with all this big data?
title_vid: What do we do with all this big data?

title_talk: Eric Topol: The wireless future of medicine
description: Eric Topol says we'll soon use our smartphones to monitor our vital signs and chronic conditions. At TEDMED, he highlights several of the most important wireless devices in medicine's future -- all helping to keep more of us out of hospital beds.
name: Eric Topol: The wireless future of medicine
title_vid: The wireless future of medicine

title_talk: A small country with big ideas to get rid of fossil fuels | Monica Araya
description: How do we build a society without fossil fuels? Using her native Costa Rica as an example of positive action on environmental protection and renewables, climate advocate Monica Araya outlines a bold vision for a world committed to clean energy in all sectors.
name: Monica Araya: A small country with big ideas to get rid of fossil fuels
title_vid: A small country with big ideas to get rid of fossil fuels

title_talk: Google's driverless car | Sebastian Thrun
description: Sebastian Thrun helped build Google's amazing driverless car, powered by a very personal quest to save lives and reduce traffic accidents. Jawdropping video shows the DARPA Challenge-winning car motoring through busy city traffic with no one behind the wheel, and dramatic test drive footage from TED2011 demonstrates how fast the thing can really go.
name: Sebastian Thrun: Google's driverless car
title_vid: Google's driverless car

title_talk: Melissa Marshall: Talk nerdy to me
description: Melissa Marshall brings a message to all scientists (from non-scientists): We're fascinated by what you're doing. So tell us about it -- in a way we can understand. In just 4 minutes, she shares powerful tips on presenting complex scientific ideas to a general audience.
name: Melissa Marshall: Talk nerdy to me
title_vid: Talk nerdy to me

title_talk: Why some people find exercise harder than others | Emily Balcetis
description: Why do some people struggle more than others to keep off the pounds? Social psychologist Emily Balcetis shows research that addresses one of the many factors: our vision. In an informative talk, she shows how when it comes to fitness, some people quite literally see the world differently -- and offers a surprisingly simple solution to overcome these differences.
name: Emily Balcetis: Why some people find exercise harder than others
title_vid: Why some people find exercise harder than others

title_talk: Why dieting doesn't usually work | Sandra Aamodt
description: In the US, 80% of girls have been on a diet by the time they're 10 years old. In this honest, raw talk, neuroscientist Sandra Aamodt uses her personal story to frame an important lesson about how our brains manage our bodies, as she explores the science behind why dieting not only doesn't work, but is likely to do more harm than good. She suggests ideas for how to live a less diet-obsessed life, intuitively.
name: Sandra Aamodt: Why dieting doesn't usually work
title_vid: Why dieting doesn't usually work

title_talk: Arthur Ganson: Moving sculpture
description: Sculptor and engineer Arthur Ganson talks about his work -- kinetic art that explores deep philosophical ideas and is gee-whiz fun to look at.
name: Arthur Ganson: Moving sculpture
title_vid: Moving sculpture

title_talk: Steve Ramirez and Xu Liu: A mouse. A laser beam. A manipulated memory.
description: Can we edit the content of our memories? It's a sci-fi-tinged question that Steve Ramirez and Xu Liu are asking in their lab at MIT. Essentially, the pair shoot a laser beam into the brain of a living mouse to activate and manipulate its memory. In this unexpectedly amusing talk they share not only how, but -- more important -- why they do this.
name: Steve Ramirez and Xu Liu: A mouse. A laser beam. A manipulated memory.
title_vid: A mouse. A laser beam. A manipulated memory.

title_talk: How we're harnessing nature's hidden superpowers | Oded Shoseyov
description: What do you get when you combine the strongest materials from the plant world with the most elastic ones from the insect kingdom? Super-performing materials that might transform ... everything. Nanobiotechnologist Oded Shoseyov walks us through examples of amazing materials found throughout nature, in everything from cat fleas to sequoia trees, and shows the creative ways his team is harnessing them in everything from sports shoes to medical implants.
name: Oded Shoseyov: How we're harnessing nature's hidden superpowers
title_vid: How we're harnessing nature's hidden superpowers

title_talk: Drawings that show the beauty and fragility of Earth | Zaria Forman
description: Zaria Forman's large-scale compositions of melting glaciers, icebergs floating in glassy water and waves cresting with foam explore moments of transition, turbulence and tranquility. Join her as she discusses the meditative process of artistic creation and the motivation behind her work. "My drawings celebrate the beauty of what we all stand to lose," she says. "I hope they can serve as records of sublime landscapes in flux."
name: Zaria Forman: Drawings that show the beauty and fragility of Earth
title_vid: Drawings that show the beauty and fragility of Earth

title_talk: Josette Sheeran: Ending hunger now
description: Josette Sheeran, the head of the UN's World Food Program, talks about why, in a world with enough food for everyone, people still go hungry, still die of starvation, still use food as a weapon of war. Her vision: "Food is one issue that cannot be solved person by person. We have to stand together."
name: Josette Sheeran: Ending hunger now
title_vid: Ending hunger now

title_talk: Why our universe might exist on a knife-edge | Gian Giudice
description: The biggest surprise of discovering the Higgs boson? That there were no surprises. Gian Giudice talks us through a problem in theoretical physics: what if the Higgs field exists in an ultra-dense state that could mean the collapse of all atomic matter? With wit and charm, Giudice outlines a grim fate -- and why we shouldn't start worrying just yet.
name: Gian Giudice: Why our universe might exist on a knife-edge
title_vid: Why our universe might exist on a knife-edge

title_talk: Nina Tandon: Caring for engineered tissue
description: Tissue engineer and TED Fellow Nina Tandon is growing artificial hearts and bones. To do that, she needs new ways of caring for artificially grown cells -- techniques she's developed by the simple but powerful method of copying their natural environments.
name: Nina Tandon: Caring for engineered tissue
title_vid: Caring for engineered tissue

title_talk: Philip Evans: How data will transform business
description: What does the future of business look like? In an informative talk, Philip Evans gives a quick primer on two long-standing theories in strategy -- and explains why he thinks they are essentially invalid.
name: Philip Evans: How data will transform business
title_vid: How data will transform business

title_talk: Andrew Connolly: What's the next window into our universe?
description: Big Data is everywhere — even the skies. In an informative talk, astronomer Andrew Connolly shows how large amounts of data are being collected about our universe, recording it in its ever-changing moods. Just how do scientists capture so many images at scale? It starts with a giant telescope ...
name: Andrew Connolly: What's the next window into our universe?
title_vid: What's the next window into our universe?

title_talk: A 12-year-old app developer | Thomas Suarez
description: Most 12-year-olds love playing videogames -- but Thomas Suarez taught himself how to create them. After developing iPhone apps like "Bustin Jeiber," a whack-a-mole game, he is now using his skills to help other kids become developers.
name: Thomas Suarez: A 12-year-old app developer
title_vid: A 12-year-old app developer

title_talk: Jeff Smith: Lessons in business ... from prison
description: Jeff Smith spent a year in prison. But what he discovered inside wasn't what he expected -- he saw in his fellow inmates boundless ingenuity and business savvy. He asks: Why don't we tap this entrepreneurial potential to help ex-prisoners contribute to society once they're back outside? (From the TED Talent Search event TED@NewYork.)
name: Jeff Smith: Lessons in business ... from prison
title_vid: Lessons in business ... from prison

title_talk: John Hodgman: A brief digression on matters of lost time
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Bart Weetjens: How I taught rats to sniff out land mines
description: No one knows exactly how many landmines still litter the world, but it's safe to say: millions, waiting to kill and maim unsuspecting civilians. Clearing them is slow, expensive and dangerous. The founder of Apopo, Bart Weetjens, talks about his extraordinary project: training rats to sniff out land mines. He shows clips of his "hero rats" in action, and previews his work's next phase: teaching them to turn up tuberculosis in the lab.
name: Bart Weetjens: How I taught rats to sniff out land mines
title_vid: How I taught rats to sniff out land mines

title_talk: Kiran Bir Sethi teaches kids to take charge
description: Kiran Bir Sethi shows how her groundbreaking Riverside School in India teaches kids life's most valuable lesson: "I can." Watch her students take local issues into their own hands, lead other young people, even educate their parents.
name: Kiran Sethi: Kids, take charge
title_vid: Kids, take charge

title_talk: Laurie Santos: How monkeys mirror human irrationality
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Inside the mind of a former radical jihadist | Manwar Ali
description: "For a long time, I lived for death," says Manwar Ali, a former radical jihadist who participated in violent, armed campaigns in the Middle East and Asia in the 1980s. In this moving talk, he reflects on his experience with radicalization and makes a powerful, direct appeal to anyone drawn to Islamist groups that claim violence and brutality are noble and virtuous: let go of anger and hatred, he says, and instead cultivate your heart to see goodness, beauty and truth in others.
name: Manwar Ali: Inside the mind of a former radical jihadist
title_vid: Inside the mind of a former radical jihadist

title_talk: Eric Whitacre: Virtual Choir Live
description: Composer and conductor Eric Whitacre has inspired millions by bringing together "virtual choirs," singers from many countries spliced together on video. Now, for the first time ever, he creates the experience in real time, as 32 singers from around the world Skype in to join an onstage choir (assembled from three local colleges) for an epic performance of Whitacre's "Cloudburst," based on a poem by Octavio Paz.
name: Eric Whitacre: Virtual Choir Live
title_vid: Virtual Choir Live

title_talk: David Perry: Will videogames become better than life?
description: Game designer David Perry says tomorrow's videogames will be more than mere fun to the next generation of gamers. They'll be lush, complex, emotional experiences -- more involving and meaningful to some than real life. With an excerpt from Michael Highland's film "As Real as Your Life."
name: David Perry: Are games better than life?
title_vid: Are games better than life?

title_talk: Atheism 2.0 | Alain de Botton
description: What aspects of religion should atheists (respectfully) adopt? Alain de Botton suggests a "religion for atheists" -- call it Atheism 2.0 -- that incorporates religious forms and traditions to satisfy our human need for connection, ritual and transcendence.
name: Alain de Botton: Atheism 2.0
title_vid: Atheism 2.0

title_talk: James Balog: Time-lapse proof of extreme ice loss
description: Photographer James Balog shares new image sequences from the Extreme Ice Survey, a network of time-lapse cameras recording glaciers receding at an alarming rate, some of the most vivid evidence yet of climate change.
name: James Balog: Time-lapse proof of extreme ice loss
title_vid: Time-lapse proof of extreme ice loss

title_talk: What I discovered in New York City trash | Robin Nagle
description: New York City residents produce 11,000 tons of garbage every day. Every day! This astonishing statistic is just one of the reasons Robin Nagle started a research project with the city's Department of Sanitation. She walked the routes, operated mechanical brooms, even drove a garbage truck herself--all so she could answer a simple-sounding but complicated question: who cleans up after us?
name: Robin Nagle: What I discovered in New York City  trash
title_vid: What I discovered in New York City  trash

title_talk: What the sugar coating on your cells is trying to tell you | Carolyn Bertozzi
description: Your cells are coated with sugars that store information and speak a secret language. What are they trying to tell us? Your blood type, for one -- and, potentially, that you have cancer. Chemical biologist Carolyn Bertozzi researches how sugars on cancerous cells interact with (and sometimes trick) your immune system. Learn more about how your body detects cancer and how the latest cancer-fighting medicines could help your immune system beat the disease.
name: Carolyn Bertozzi: What the sugar coating on your cells is trying to tell you
title_vid: What the sugar coating on your cells is trying to tell you

title_talk: Auret van Heerden: Making global labor fair
description: FLA head Auret van Heerden talks about the next frontier of workers' rights -- globalized industries where no single national body can keep workers safe and protected. How can we keep our global supply chains honest? Van Heerden makes the business case for fair labor.
name: Auret van Heerden: Making global labor fair
title_vid: Making global labor fair

title_talk: An entertainment icon on living a life of meaning | Norman Lear
description: In the 1970s (and decades following), TV producer Norman Lear touched the lives of millions with culture-altering sitcoms like All in the Family, The Jeffersons and Good Times, pushing the boundaries of the era and giving a primetime voice to underrepresented Americans. In an intimate, smart conversation with Eric Hirshberg, he shares with humility and humor how his early relationship with "the foolishness of the human condition" shaped his life and creative vision.
name: Norman Lear: An entertainment icon on living a life of meaning
title_vid: An entertainment icon on living a life of meaning

title_talk: The tribes we lead | Seth Godin
description: Seth Godin argues the Internet has ended mass marketing and revived a human social unit from the distant past: tribes. Founded on shared ideas and values, tribes give ordinary people the power to lead and make big change. He urges us to do so.
name: Seth Godin: The tribes we lead
title_vid: The tribes we lead

title_talk: Jon Nguyen: Tour the solar system from home
description: Want to navigate the solar system without having to buy a spacecraft? Jon Nguyen demos NASA JPL's "Eyes on the Solar System" -- free-to-use software for exploring the planets, moons, asteroids, and spacecraft that rotate around our sun in real-time.
name: Jon Nguyen: Tour the solar system from home
title_vid: Tour the solar system from home

title_talk: Martin Hanczyc: The line between life and not-life
description: In his lab, Martin Hanczyc makes "protocells," experimental blobs of chemicals that behave like living cells. His work demonstrates how life might have first occurred on Earth ... and perhaps elsewhere too.
name: Martin Hanczyc: The line between life and not-life
title_vid: The line between life and not-life

title_talk: Siddharthan Chandran: Can the damaged brain repair itself?
description: After a traumatic brain injury, it sometimes happens that the brain can repair itself, building new brain cells to replace damaged ones. But the repair doesn't happen quickly enough to allow recovery from degenerative conditions like motor neuron disease (also known as Lou Gehrig's disease or ALS). Siddharthan Chandran walks through some new techniques using special stem cells that could allow the damaged brain to rebuild faster.
name: Siddharthan Chandran: Can the damaged brain repair itself?
title_vid: Can the damaged brain repair itself?

title_talk: Marcus Byrne: The dance of the dung beetle
description: A dung beetle has a brain the size of a grain of rice, and yet it shows a tremendous amount of intelligence when it comes to rolling its food source -- animal excrement -- home. How? It all comes down to a dance.
name: Marcus Byrne: The dance of the dung beetle
title_vid: The dance of the dung beetle

title_talk: Peter van Manen: How can Formula 1 racing help ... babies?
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Half a million secrets | Frank Warren
description: "Secrets can take many forms -- they can be shocking, or silly, or soulful." Frank Warren, the founder of PostSecret.com, shares some of the half-million secrets that strangers have mailed him on postcards.
name: Frank Warren: Half a million secrets
title_vid: Half a million secrets

title_talk: The riddle of experience vs. memory | Daniel Kahneman
description: Using examples from vacations to colonoscopies, Nobel laureate and founder of behavioral economics Daniel Kahneman reveals how our "experiencing selves" and our "remembering selves" perceive happiness differently. This new insight has profound implications for economics, public policy -- and our own self-awareness.
name: Daniel Kahneman: The riddle of experience vs. memory
title_vid: The riddle of experience vs. memory

title_talk: Monika Bulaj: The hidden light of Afghanistan
description: Photographer Monika Bulaj shares powerful, intimate images of Afghanistan -- of home life, of ritual, of men and women. Behind the headlines, what does the world truly know about this place?
name: Monika Bulaj: The hidden light of Afghanistan
title_vid: The hidden light of Afghanistan

title_talk: Your elusive creative genius | Elizabeth Gilbert
description: Elizabeth Gilbert muses on the impossible things we expect from artists and geniuses -- and shares the radical idea that, instead of the rare person "being" a genius, all of us "have" a genius. It's a funny, personal and surprisingly moving talk.
name: Elizabeth Gilbert: Your elusive creative genius
title_vid: Your elusive creative genius

title_talk: Tim Brown urges designers to think big
description: Tim Brown says the design profession has a bigger role to play than just creating nifty, fashionable little objects. He calls for a shift to local, collaborative, participatory "design thinking" -- starting with the example of 19th-century design thinker Isambard Kingdom Brunel.
name: Tim Brown: Designers -- think big!
title_vid: Designers -- think big!

title_talk: Jennifer Healey: If cars could talk, accidents might be avoidable
description: When we drive, we get into a glass bubble, lock the doors and press the accelerator, relying on our eyes to guide us -- even though we can only see the few cars ahead of and behind us. But what if cars could share data with each other about their position and velocity, and use predictive models to calculate the safest routes for everyone on the road? Jennifer Healey imagines a world without car accidents.
name: Jennifer Healey: If cars could talk, accidents might be avoidable
title_vid: If cars could talk, accidents might be avoidable

title_talk: Robots that fly ... and cooperate | Vijay Kumar
description: In his lab at Penn, Vijay Kumar and his team build flying quadrotors, small, agile robots that swarm, sense each other, and form ad hoc teams -- for construction, surveying disasters and far more.
name: Vijay Kumar: Robots that fly ... and cooperate
title_vid: Robots that fly ... and cooperate

title_talk: Steven Pinker and Rebecca Newberger Goldstein: The long reach of reason
description: Here's a TED first: an animated Socratic dialog! In a time when irrationality seems to rule both politics and culture, has reasoned thinking finally lost its power? Watch as psychologist Steven Pinker is gradually, brilliantly persuaded by philosopher Rebecca Newberger Goldstein that reason is actually the key driver of human moral progress, even if its effect sometimes takes generations to unfold. The dialog was recorded live at TED, and animated, in incredible, often hilarious, detail by Cognitive.
main_speaker: Steven Pinker and Rebecca Newberger Goldstein
name: Steven Pinker and Rebecca Newberger Goldstein: The long reach of reason
title_vid: The long reach of reason

title_talk: Peter Gabriel: Fighting injustice with a videocamera
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Eric Giler demos wireless electricity
description: Eric Giler wants to untangle our wired lives with cable-free electric power. Here, he covers what this sci-fi tech offers, and demos MIT's breakthrough version, WiTricity -- a near-to-market invention that may soon recharge your cell phone, car, pacemaker.
name: Eric Giler: A demo of wireless electricity
title_vid: A demo of wireless electricity

title_talk: Adam Davidson: What we learned from teetering on the fiscal cliff
description: At the end of 2012, the US political system was headed for the "fiscal cliff" -- a budget impasse that could only be solved with bipartisan agreement. Adam Davidson, cohost of "Planet Money," shares surprising data on how bipartisan we truly are -- and hints at the disconnect between representatives and the people they represent.
name: Adam Davidson: What we learned from teetering on the fiscal cliff
title_vid: What we learned from teetering on the fiscal cliff

title_talk: Blaise Aguera y Arcas demos augmented-reality maps
description: In a demo that drew gasps at TED2010, Blaise Aguera y Arcas demos new augmented-reality mapping technology from Microsoft.
name: Blaise Agüera y Arcas: Augmented-reality maps
title_vid: Augmented-reality maps

title_talk: Judy MacDonald Johnston: Prepare for a good end of life
description: Thinking about death is frightening, but planning ahead is practical and leaves more room for peace of mind in our final days. In a solemn, thoughtful talk, Judy MacDonald Johnston shares 5 practices for planning for a good end of life.
name: Judy MacDonald Johnston: Prepare for a good end of life
title_vid: Prepare for a good end of life

title_talk: How we explore unanswered questions in physics | James Beacham
description: James Beacham looks for answers to the most important open questions of physics using the biggest science experiment ever mounted, CERN's Large Hadron Collider. In this fun and accessible talk about how science happens, Beacham takes us on a journey through extra-spatial dimensions in search of undiscovered fundamental particles (and an explanation for the mysteries of gravity) and details the drive to keep exploring.
name: James Beacham: How we explore unanswered questions in physics
title_vid: How we explore unanswered questions in physics

title_talk: What if 3D printing was 100x faster? | Joseph DeSimone
description: What we think of as 3D printing, says Joseph DeSimone, is really just 2D printing over and over ... slowly. Onstage at TED2015, he unveils a bold new technique -- inspired, yes, by Terminator 2 -- that's 25 to 100 times faster, and creates smooth, strong parts. Could it finally help to fulfill the tremendous promise of 3D printing?
name: Joseph DeSimone: What if 3D printing was 100x faster?
title_vid: What if 3D printing was 100x faster?

title_talk: Why our IQ levels are higher than our grandparents' | James Flynn
description: It's called the "Flynn effect" -- the fact that each generation scores higher on an IQ test than the generation before it. Are we actually getting smarter, or just thinking differently? In this fast-paced spin through the cognitive history of the 20th century, moral philosopher James Flynn suggests that changes in the way we think have had surprising (and not always positive) consequences.
name: James Flynn: Why our IQ levels are higher than our grandparents'
title_vid: Why our IQ levels are higher than our grandparents'

title_talk: Shekhar Kapur: We are the stories we tell ourselves
description: Where does creative inspiration spring from? At TEDIndia, Hollywood/Bollywood director Shekhar Kapur ("Elizabeth," "Mr. India") pinpoints his source of creativity: sheer, utter panic. He shares a powerful way to unleash your inner storyteller.
name: Shekhar Kapur: We are the stories we tell ourselves
title_vid: We are the stories we tell ourselves

title_talk: Let's end ageism | Ashton Applewhite
description: It's not the passage of time that makes it so hard to get older. It's ageism, a prejudice that pits us against our future selves -- and each other. Ashton Applewhite urges us to dismantle the dread and mobilize against the last socially acceptable prejudice. "Aging is not a problem to be fixed or a disease to be cured," she says. "It is a natural, powerful, lifelong process that unites us all."
name: Ashton Applewhite: Let's end ageism
title_vid: Let's end ageism

title_talk: Anne Curzan: What makes a word "real"?
description: One could argue that slang words like ‘hangry,’ ‘defriend’ and ‘adorkable’ fill crucial meaning gaps in the English language, even if they don't appear in the dictionary. After all, who actually decides which words make it into those pages? Language historian Anne Curzan gives a charming look at the humans behind dictionaries, and the choices they make.
name: Anne Curzan: What makes a word "real"?
title_vid: What makes a word "real"?

title_talk: The most Martian place on Earth | Armando Azua-Bustos
description: How can you study Mars without a spaceship? Head to the most Martian place on Earth -- the Atacama Desert in Chile. Astrobiologist Armando Azua-Bustos grew up in this vast, arid landscape and now studies the rare life forms that have adapted to survive there, some in areas with no reported rainfall for the past 400 years. Explore the possibility of finding life elsewhere in the universe without leaving the planet with this quick, funny talk.
name: Armando Azua-Bustos: The most Martian place on Earth
title_vid: The most Martian place on Earth

title_talk: Christopher Soghoian: Government surveillance — this is just the beginning
description: Privacy researcher Christopher Soghoian sees the landscape of government surveillance shifting beneath our feet, as an industry grows to support monitoring programs. Through private companies, he says, governments are buying technology with the capacity to break into computers, steal documents and monitor activity — without detection. This TED Fellow gives an unsettling look at what's to come.
name: Christopher Soghoian: Government surveillance — this is just the beginning
title_vid: Government surveillance — this is just the beginning

title_talk: How to tie your shoes | Terry Moore
description: Terry Moore found out he'd been tying his shoes the wrong way his whole life. In the spirit of TED, he takes the stage to share a better way.
name: Terry Moore: How to tie your shoes
title_vid: How to tie your shoes

title_talk: Yann Arthus-Bertrand captures fragile Earth in wide-angle
description: In this image-filled talk, Yann Arthus-Bertrand displays his three most recent projects on humanity and our habitat -- stunning aerial photographs in his series "The Earth From Above," personal interviews from around the globe featured in his web project "6 billion Others," and his soon-to-be-released movie, "Home," which documents human impact on the environment through breathtaking video.
name: Yann Arthus-Bertrand: A wide-angle view of fragile Earth
title_vid: A wide-angle view of fragile Earth

title_talk: Derek Paravicini and Adam Ockelford: In the key of genius
description: Born three and a half months prematurely, Derek Paravicini is blind and has severe autism. But with perfect pitch, innate talent and a lot of practice, he became a concert pianist by the age of 10. Here, his longtime piano teacher, Adam Ockelford, explains his student's unique relationship to music, while Paravicini shows how he has ripped up the "Chopsticks" rulebook.
name: Derek Paravicini and Adam Ockelford: In the key of genius
title_vid: In the key of genius

title_talk: Future tech will give you the benefits of city life anywhere | Julio Gil
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: A tale of mental illness | Elyn Saks
description: "Is it okay if I totally trash your office?" It's a question Elyn Saks once asked her doctor, and it wasn't a joke. A legal scholar, in 2007 Saks came forward with her own story of schizophrenia, controlled by drugs and therapy but ever-present. In this powerful talk, she asks us to see people with mental illness clearly, honestly and compassionately.
name: Elyn Saks: A tale of mental illness -- from the inside
title_vid: A tale of mental illness -- from the inside

title_talk: Tim Jackson: An economic reality check
description: As the world faces recession, climate change, inequity and more, Tim Jackson delivers a piercing challenge to established economic principles, explaining how we might stop feeding the crises and start investing in our future.
name: Tim Jackson: An economic reality check
title_vid: An economic reality check

title_talk: Use art to turn the world inside out | JR
description: French street artist JR uses his camera to show the world its true face, by pasting photos of the human face across massive canvases. At TED2011, he makes his audacious TED Prize wish: to use art to turn the world inside out.
name: JR: My wish: Use art to turn the world inside out
title_vid: My wish: Use art to turn the world inside out

title_talk: Lauren Zalaznick: The conscience of television
description: TV executive Lauren Zalaznick thinks deeply about pop television. Sharing results of a bold study that tracks attitudes against TV ratings over five decades, she makes a case that television reflects who we truly are -- in ways we might not have expected.
name: Lauren Zalaznick: The conscience of television
title_vid: The conscience of television

title_talk: Michael Porter: Why business can be good at solving social problems
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Steve Howard: Let's go all-in on selling sustainability
description: The big blue buildings of Ikea have sprouted solar panels and wind turbines; inside, shelves are stocked with LED lighting and recycled cotton. Why? Because as Steve Howard puts it: “Sustainability has gone from a nice-to-do to a must-do.” Howard, the chief sustainability officer at the furniture megastore, talks about his quest to sell eco-friendly materials and practices -- both internally and to worldwide customers -- and lays a challenge for other global giants.
name: Steve Howard: Let's go all-in on selling sustainability
title_vid: Let's go all-in on selling sustainability

title_talk: Military robots and the future of war | P.W. Singer
description: In this powerful talk, P.W. Singer shows how the widespread use of robots in war is changing the realities of combat. He shows us scenarios straight out of science fiction -- that now may not be so fictitious.
name: P.W. Singer: Military robots and the future of war
title_vid: Military robots and the future of war

title_talk: Hunting for dinosaurs showed me our place in the universe | Kenneth Lacovara
description: What happens when you discover a dinosaur? Paleontologist Kenneth Lacovara details his unearthing of Dreadnoughtus -- a 77-million-year-old sauropod that was as tall as a two-story house and as heavy as a jumbo jet -- and considers how amazingly improbable it is that a tiny mammal living in the cracks of the dinosaur world could evolve into a sentient being capable of understanding these magnificent creatures. Join him in a celebration of the Earth's geological history and contemplate our place in deep time.
name: Kenneth Lacovara: Hunting for dinosaurs showed me our place in the universe
title_vid: Hunting for dinosaurs showed me our place in the universe

title_talk: Catarina Mota: Play with smart materials
description: Ink that conducts electricity; a window that turns from clear to opaque at the flip of a switch; a jelly that makes music. All this stuff exists, and Catarina Mota says: It's time to play with it. Mota leads us on a tour of surprising and cool new materials, and suggests that the way we'll figure out what they're good for is to experiment, tinker and have fun.
name: Catarina Mota: Play with smart materials
title_vid: Play with smart materials

title_talk: Sir Martin Rees: Earth in its final century?
description: Speaking as both an astronomer and "a concerned member of the human race," Sir Martin Rees examines our planet and its future from a cosmic perspective. He urges action to prevent dark consequences from our scientific and technological development.
name: Martin Rees: Is this our final century?
title_vid: Is this our final century?

title_talk: Heather Brooke: My battle to expose government corruption
description: Our leaders need to be held accountable, says journalist Heather Brooke. And she should know: Brooke uncovered the British Parliamentary financial expenses that led to a major political scandal in 2009. She urges us to ask our leaders questions through platforms like Freedom of Information requests -- and to finally get some answers.
name: Heather Brooke: My battle to expose government corruption
title_vid: My battle to expose government corruption

title_talk: Could a drug prevent depression and PTSD? | Rebecca Brachman
description: The path to better medicine is paved with accidental yet revolutionary discoveries. In this well-told tale of how science happens, neuroscientist Rebecca Brachman shares news of a serendipitous breakthrough treatment that may prevent mental disorders like depression and PTSD from ever developing. And listen for an unexpected -- and controversial -- twist.
name: Rebecca Brachman: Could a drug prevent depression and PTSD?
title_vid: Could a drug prevent depression and PTSD?

title_talk: Harish Manwani: Profit's not always the point
description: You might not expect the chief operating officer of a major global corporation to look too far beyond either the balance sheet or the bottom line. But Harish Manwani, COO of Unilever, makes a passionate argument that doing so to include value, purpose and sustainability in top-level decision-making is not just savvy, it's the only way to run a 21st century business responsibly.
name: Harish Manwani: Profit’s not always the point
title_vid: Profit’s not always the point

title_talk: Jeff Skoll: Making movies that make change
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Niels Diffrient: Rethinking the way we sit down
description: Design legend Niels Diffrient talks about his life in industrial design (and the reason he became a designer instead of a jet pilot). He details his quest to completely rethink the office chair starting from one fundamental data set: the human body.
name: Niels Diffrient: Rethinking the way we sit down
title_vid: Rethinking the way we sit down

title_talk: Abraham Verghese: A doctor's touch
description: Modern medicine is in danger of losing a powerful, old-fashioned tool: human touch. Physician and writer Abraham Verghese describes our strange new world where patients are merely data points, and calls for a return to the traditional one-on-one physical exam.
name: Abraham Verghese: A doctor's touch
title_vid: A doctor's touch

title_talk: Lalitesh Katragadda: Making maps to fight disaster, build economies
description: As of 2005, only 15 percent of the world was mapped. This slows the delivery of aid after a disaster -- and hides the economic potential of unused lands and unknown roads. In this short talk, Google's Lalitesh Katragadda demos Map Maker, a group map-making tool that people around the globe are using to map their world.
name: Lalitesh Katragadda: Making maps to fight disaster, build economies
title_vid: Making maps to fight disaster, build economies

title_talk: Kakenya Ntaiya: A girl who demanded school
description: Kakenya Ntaiya made a deal with her father: She would undergo a traditional Maasai rite of passage, female circumcision, if he would let her go to high school. Ntaiya tells the fearless story of continuing on to college, and of working with her village elders to build a school for girls in her community, changing the destiny of 125 young women.
name: Kakenya Ntaiya: A girl who demanded school
title_vid: A girl who demanded school

title_talk: Jennifer Senior: For parents, happiness is a very high bar
description: The parenting section of the bookstore is overwhelming—it's "a giant, candy-colored monument to our collective panic," as writer Jennifer Senior puts it. Why is parenthood filled with so much anxiety? Because the goal of modern, middle-class parents—to raise happy children—is so elusive. In this honest talk, she offers some kinder and more achievable aims.
name: Jennifer Senior: For parents, happiness is a very high bar
title_vid: For parents, happiness is a very high bar

title_talk: Daria van den Bercken: Why I take the piano on the road … and in the air
description: Pianist Daria van den Bercken fell in love with the baroque keyboard music of George Frideric Handel. Now, she aims to ignite this passion in others. In this talk, she plays us through the emotional roller coaster of his music — while sailing with her piano through the air, driving it down the street, and of course playing on the stage.
name: Daria van den Bercken: Why I take the piano on the road ... and in the air
title_vid: Why I take the piano on the road ... and in the air

title_talk: Lisa Gansky: The future of business is the "mesh"
description: Lisa Gansky, author of "The Mesh," talks about a future of business that's about sharing all kinds of stuff, either via smart and tech-enabled rental or, more boldly, peer-to-peer. Examples across industries -- from music to cars -- show how close we are to this meshy future.
name: Lisa Gansky: The future of business is the "mesh"
title_vid: The future of business is the "mesh"

title_talk: Dare to disagree | Margaret Heffernan
description: Most people instinctively avoid conflict, but as Margaret Heffernan shows us, good disagreement is central to progress. She illustrates (sometimes counterintuitively) how the best partners aren’t echo chambers -- and how great research teams, relationships and businesses allow people to deeply disagree.
name: Margaret Heffernan: Dare to disagree
title_vid: Dare to disagree

title_talk: Letting go of God | Julia Sweeney
description: When two young Mormon missionaries knock on Julia Sweeney's door one day, it touches off a quest to completely rethink her own beliefs, in this excerpt from Sweeney's solo show "Letting Go of God."
name: Julia Sweeney: Letting go of God
title_vid: Letting go of God

title_talk: Hector Ruiz: The power to connect the world
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Strange answers to the psychopath test | Jon Ronson
description: Is there a definitive line that divides crazy from sane? With a hair-raising delivery, Jon Ronson, author of The Psychopath Test, illuminates the gray areas between the two. (With live-mixed sound by Julian Treasure and animation by Evan Grant.)
name: Jon Ronson: Strange answers to the psychopath test
title_vid: Strange answers to the psychopath test

title_talk: Daniel Kish: How I use sonar to navigate the world
description: Daniel Kish has been blind since he was 13 months old, but has learned to "see" using a form of echolocation. He clicks his tongue and sends out flashes of sound that bounce off surfaces in the environment and return to him, helping him to construct an understanding of the space around him. In a rousing talk, Kish shows how this works -- and asks us all to let go of our fear of the dark unknown.
name: Daniel Kish: How I use sonar to navigate the world
title_vid: How I use sonar to navigate the world

title_talk: Unveiling game-changing wearable tech | Pattie Maes
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: How the blockchain will radically transform the economy | Bettina Warburg
description: Say hello to the decentralized economy -- the blockchain is about to change everything. In this lucid explainer of the complex (and confusing) technology, Bettina Warburg describes how the blockchain will eliminate the need for centralized institutions like banks or governments to facilitate trade, evolving age-old models of commerce and finance into something far more interesting: a distributed, transparent, autonomous system for exchanging value.
name: Bettina Warburg: How the blockchain will radically transform the economy
title_vid: How the blockchain will radically transform the economy

title_talk: Karima Bennoune: The side of terrorism that doesn't make headlines
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Diébédo Francis Kéré: How to build with clay... and community
description: Diébédo Francis Kéré knew exactly what he wanted to do when he got his degree in architecture... He wanted to go home to Gando in Burkina Faso, to help his neighbors reap the benefit of his education. In this charming talk, Kéré shows off some of the beautiful structures he's helped to build in his small village in the years since then, including an award-winning primary school made from clay by the entire community.
name: Diébédo Francis Kéré: How to build with clay ... and community
title_vid: How to build with clay ... and community

title_talk: E.O. Wilson calls for an Encyclopedia of Life
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Poetry that frees the soul (with English subtitles) | Cristina Domenech
description: "It's said that to be a poet, you have to go to hell and back." Cristina Domenech teaches writing at an Argentinian prison, and she tells the moving story of helping incarcerated people express themselves, understand themselves — and glory in the freedom of language. Watch for a powerful reading from one of her students, an inmate, in front of an audience of 10,000. In Spanish with subtitles.
name: Cristina Domenech: Poetry that frees the soul
title_vid: Poetry that frees the soul

title_talk: Insightful human portraits made from data | R. Luke DuBois
description: Artist R. Luke DuBois makes unique portraits of presidents, cities, himself and even Britney Spears using data and personality. In this talk, he shares nine projects -- from maps of the country built using information taken from millions of dating profiles to a gun that fires a blank every time a shooting is reported in New Orleans. His point: the way we use technology reflects on us and our culture, and we reduce others to data points at our own peril.
name: R. Luke DuBois: Insightful human portraits made from data
title_vid: Insightful human portraits made from data

title_talk: Sebastian Junger: Why veterans miss war
description: Civilians don't miss war. But soldiers often do. Journalist Sebastian Junger shares his experience embedded with American soldiers at Restrepo, an outpost in Afghanistan's Korengal Valley that saw heavy combat. Giving a look at the "altered state of mind" that comes with war, he shows how combat gives soldiers an intense experience of connection. In the end, could it actually be "the opposite of war" that soldiers miss?
name: Sebastian Junger: Why veterans miss war
title_vid: Why veterans miss war

title_talk: How your brain decides what is beautiful | Anjan Chatterjee
description: Anjan Chatterjee uses tools from evolutionary psychology and cognitive neuroscience to study one of nature's most captivating concepts: beauty. Learn more about the science behind why certain configurations of line, color and form excite us in this fascinating, deep look inside your brain.
name: Anjan Chatterjee: How your brain decides what is beautiful
title_vid: How your brain decides what is beautiful

title_talk: How a blind astronomer found a way to hear the stars | Wanda Diaz Merced
description: Wanda Diaz Merced studies the light emitted by gamma-ray bursts, the most energetic events in the universe. When she lost her sight and was left without a way to do her science, she had a revelatory insight: the light curves she could no longer see could be translated into sound. Through sonification, she regained mastery over her work, and now she's advocating for a more inclusive scientific community. "Science is for everyone," she says. "It has to be available to everyone, because we are all natural explorers."
name: Wanda Diaz Merced: How a blind astronomer found a way to hear the stars
title_vid: How a blind astronomer found a way to hear the stars

title_talk: Jan Chipchase: The anthropology of mobile phones
description: Nokia researcher Jan Chipchase's investigation into the ways we interact with technology has led him from the villages of Uganda to the insides of our pockets. He's made some unexpected discoveries along the way.
name: Jan Chipchase: The anthropology of mobile phones
title_vid: The anthropology of mobile phones

title_talk: Alberto Cairo: There are no scraps of men
description: Alberto Cairo's clinics in Afghanistan used to close down during active fighting. Now, they stay open. In this powerful talk, Cairo tells the moving story of why -- and how he found humanity and dignity in the midst of war.
name: Alberto Cairo: There are no scraps of men
title_vid: There are no scraps of men

title_talk: Lewis Pugh's mind-shifting Mt. Everest swim
description: After he swam the North Pole, Lewis Pugh vowed never to take another cold-water dip. Then he heard of Lake Imja in the Himalayas, created by recent glacial melting, and Lake Pumori, a body of water at an altitude of 5300 m on Everest -- and so began a journey that would teach him a radical new way to approach swimming and think about climate change.
name: Lewis Pugh: My mind-shifting Everest swim
title_vid: My mind-shifting Everest swim

title_talk: Jay Bradner: Open-source cancer research
description: How does cancer know it's cancer? At Jay Bradner's lab, they found a molecule that might hold the answer, JQ1. But instead of patenting it and reaping the profits (as many other labs have done) -- they published their findings and mailed samples to 40 other labs to work on. An inspiring look at the open-source future of medical research.
name: Jay Bradner: Open-source cancer research
title_vid: Open-source cancer research

title_talk: Sonia Shah: 3 reasons we still haven't gotten rid of malaria
description: We’ve known how to cure malaria since the 1600s, so why does the disease still kill hundreds of thousands every year? It’s more than just a problem of medicine, says journalist Sonia Shah. A look into the history of malaria reveals three big-picture challenges to its eradication. Photos: Adam Nadel.
name: Sonia Shah: 3 reasons we still haven’t gotten rid of malaria
title_vid: 3 reasons we still haven’t gotten rid of malaria

title_talk: Raghava KK: What's your 200-year plan?
description: You might have a 5-year plan, but what about a 200-year plan? Artist Raghava KK has set his eyes on an ultra-long-term horizon; at TEDxSummit, he shows how it helps guide today's choices and tomorrow's goals -- and encourages you to make your own 200-year plan too.
name: Raghava KK: What's your 200-year plan?
title_vid: What's your 200-year plan?

title_talk: Liz Coleman's call to reinvent liberal arts education
description: Bennington president Liz Coleman delivers a call-to-arms for radical reform in higher education. Bucking the trend to push students toward increasingly narrow areas of study, she proposes a truly cross-disciplinary education -- one that dynamically combines all areas of study to address the great problems of our day.
name: Liz Coleman: A call to reinvent liberal arts education
title_vid: A call to reinvent liberal arts education

title_talk: Theremin, the untouchable music | Pamelia Kurstin
description: Virtuoso Pamelia Kurstin performs and discusses her theremin, the not-just-for-sci-fi electronic instrument that is played without being touched. Songs include "Autumn Leaves," "Lush Life" and David Mash’s "Listen, Words Are Gone."
name: Pamelia Kurstin: The untouchable music of the theremin
title_vid: The untouchable music of the theremin

title_talk: Carl Schoonover: How to look inside the brain
description: There have been remarkable advances in understanding the brain, but how do you actually study the neurons inside it? Using gorgeous imagery, neuroscientist and TED Fellow Carl Schoonover shows the tools that let us see inside our brains.
name: Carl Schoonover: How to look inside the brain
title_vid: How to look inside the brain

title_talk: Dianna Cohen: Tough truths about plastic pollution
description: Artist Dianna Cohen shares some tough truths about plastic pollution in the ocean and in our lives -- and some thoughts on how to free ourselves from the plastic gyre.
name: Dianna Cohen: Tough truths about plastic pollution
title_vid: Tough truths about plastic pollution

title_talk: Anil Ananthaswamy: What it takes to do extreme astrophysics
description: All over the planet, giant telescopes and detectors are looking (and listening) for clues to the workings of the universe. At the INK Conference, science writer Anil Ananthaswamy tours us around these amazing installations, taking us to some of the most remote and silent places on Earth.
name: Anil Ananthaswamy: What it takes to do extreme astrophysics
title_vid: What it takes to do extreme astrophysics

title_talk: Alessandra Orofino: It’s our city. Let’s fix it
description: Too often, people feel checked out of politics — even at the level of their own city. But urban activist Alessandra Orofino thinks that can change, using a mix of tech and old-fashioned human connection. Sharing examples from her hometown of Rio, she says: "It is up to us to decide whether we want schools or parking lots, recycling projects or construction sites, cars or buses, loneliness or solidarity."
name: Alessandra Orofino: It’s our city. Let’s fix it
title_vid: It’s our city. Let’s fix it

title_talk: Paola Antonelli: Design and the elastic mind
description: MOMA design curator Paola Antonelli previews the groundbreaking show Design and the Elastic Mind -- full of products and designs that reflect the way we think now.
name: Paola Antonelli: Design and the Elastic Mind
title_vid: Design and the Elastic Mind

title_talk: Natalie Merchant sings old poems to life
description: Natalie Merchant sings from her new album, "Leave Your Sleep." Lyrics from near-forgotten 19th-century poetry pair with her unmistakable voice for a performance that brought the TED audience to its feet.
name: Natalie Merchant: Singing old poems to life
title_vid: Singing old poems to life

title_talk: Forget Wi-Fi. Meet the new Li-Fi Internet | Harald Haas
description: What if we could use existing technologies to provide Internet access to the more than 4 billion people living in places where the infrastructure can't support it? Using off-the-shelf LEDs and solar cells, Harald Haas and his team have pioneered a new technology that transmits data using light, and it may just be the key to bridging the digital divide. Take a look at what the future of the Internet could look like.
name: Harald Haas: Forget Wi-Fi. Meet the new Li-Fi Internet
title_vid: Forget Wi-Fi. Meet the new Li-Fi Internet

title_talk: Ethan Nadelmann: Why we need to end the War on Drugs
description: Is the War on Drugs doing more harm than good? In a bold talk, drug policy reformist Ethan Nadelmann makes an impassioned plea to end the "backward, heartless, disastrous" movement to stamp out the drug trade. He gives two big reasons we should focus on intelligent regulation instead.
name: Ethan Nadelmann: Why we need to end the War on Drugs
title_vid: Why we need to end the War on Drugs

title_talk: Beth Noveck: Demand a more open-source government
description: What can governments learn from the open-data revolution? In this stirring talk, Beth Noveck, the former deputy CTO at the White House, shares a vision of practical openness -- connecting bureaucracies to citizens, sharing data, creating a truly participatory democracy. Imagine the "writable society" ...
name: Beth Noveck: Demand a more open-source government
title_vid: Demand a more open-source government

title_talk: Paul Root Wolpe: It's time to question bio-engineering
description: Glowing dogs ... mice that grow human ears ... bioethicist Paul Root Wolpe describes an astonishing series of recent bio-engineering experiments, and asks: Isn't it time to set some ground rules?
name: Paul Root Wolpe: It's time to question bio-engineering
title_vid: It's time to question bio-engineering

title_talk: Aakash Odedra: A dance in a hurricane of paper, wind and light
description: Choreographer Aakash Odedra is dyslexic and has always felt that his best expression comes through movement. “Murmur” is his ode to that experience, teaming up with co-creators Lewis Major and Ars Electronica Futurelab. Watch him spin his way through the center of a storm, as pages of books take flight all around him.
name: Aakash Odedra: A dance in a hurricane of paper, wind and light
title_vid: A dance in a hurricane of paper, wind and light

title_talk: Esta Soler: How we turned the tide on domestic violence (Hint: the Polaroid helped)
description: When Esta Soler lobbied for a bill outlawing domestic violence in 1984, one politician called it the "Take the Fun Out of Marriage Act." "If only I had Twitter then," she mused. In this sweeping, optimistic talk, Soler charts 30 years of tactics and technologies -- from the Polaroid camera to social media -- that led to a 64% drop in domestic violence in the U.S.
name: Esta Soler: How we turned the tide on domestic violence (Hint: the Polaroid helped)
title_vid: How we turned the tide on domestic violence (Hint: the Polaroid helped)

title_talk: Gabriel Barcia-Colombo: Capturing memories in video art
description: Using video mapping and projection, artist Gabriel Barcia-Colombo captures and shares his memories and friendships. At TED Fellow Talks, he shows his charming, thoughtful work -- which appears to preserve the people in his life in jars, suitcases, blenders ...
name: Gabriel Barcia-Colombo: Capturing memories in video art
title_vid: Capturing memories in video art

title_talk: Charles Leadbeater: The era of open innovation
description: In this deceptively casual talk, Charles Leadbeater weaves a tight argument  that innovation isn't just for professionals anymore. Passionate amateurs, using new tools, are creating products and paradigms that companies can't.
name: Charles Leadbeater: The era of open innovation
title_vid: The era of open innovation

title_talk: George Papandreou: Imagine a European democracy without borders
description: Greece has been the poster child for European economic crisis, but former Prime Minister George Papandreou wonders if it's just a preview of what's to come. “Our democracies," he says, "are trapped by systems that are too big to fail, or more accurately, too big to control” -- while "politicians like me have lost the trust of their peoples." How to solve it? Have citizens re-engage more directly in a new democratic bargain.
name: George Papandreou: Imagine a European democracy without borders
title_vid: Imagine a European democracy without borders

title_talk: Let's clean up the space junk orbiting Earth | Natalie Panek
description: Our lives depend on a world we can't see: the satellite infrastructure we use every day for information, entertainment, communication and so much more. But Earth orbit isn't a limitless resource, and the problem of space debris will get worse without a significant change to our behavior. Natalie Panek challenges us to consider the environmental impact of the satellites we rely on. Our orbital environment is breathtakingly beautiful and our gateway to exploration, she says. It's up to us to keep it that way.
name: Natalie Panek: Let's clean up the space junk orbiting Earth
title_vid: Let's clean up the space junk orbiting Earth

title_talk: Thulasiraj Ravilla: How low-cost eye care can be world-class
description: India's revolutionary Aravind Eye Care System has given sight to millions. Thulasiraj Ravilla looks at the ingenious approach that drives its treatment costs down and quality up, and why its methods should trigger a re-think of all human services.
name: Thulasiraj Ravilla: How low-cost eye care can be world-class
title_vid: How low-cost eye care can be world-class

title_talk: Andrew McAfee: Are droids taking our jobs?
description: Robots and algorithms are getting good at jobs like building cars, writing articles, translating -- jobs that once required a human. So what will we humans do for work? Andrew McAfee walks through recent labor data to say: We ain't seen nothing yet. But then he steps back to look at big history, and comes up with a surprising view of what comes next.
name: Andrew McAfee: Are droids taking our jobs?
title_vid: Are droids taking our jobs?

title_talk: The design genius of Charles + Ray Eames
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The voices in my head | Eleanor Longden
description: To all appearances, Eleanor Longden was just like every other student, heading to college full of promise and without a care in the world. That was until the voices in her head started talking. Initially innocuous, these internal narrators became increasingly antagonistic and dictatorial, turning her life into a living nightmare. Diagnosed with schizophrenia, hospitalized, drugged, Longden was discarded by a system that didn't know how to help her. Longden tells the moving tale of her years-long journey back to mental health, and makes the case that it was through learning to listen to her voices that she was able to survive.
name: Eleanor Longden: The voices in my head
title_vid: The voices in my head

title_talk: Nick Sears: Presenting the Orb
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Yossi Vardi: Help fight local warming
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: The future of money | Neha Narula
description: What happens when the way we buy, sell and pay for things changes, perhaps even removing the need for banks or currency exchange bureaus? That's the radical promise of a world powered by cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Ethereum. We're not there yet, but in this sparky talk, digital currency researcher Neha Narula describes the collective fiction of money -- and paints a picture of a very different looking future.
name: Neha Narula: The future of money
title_vid: The future of money

title_talk: Glow-in-the-dark sharks and other stunning sea creatures | David Gruber
description: Just a few meters below the waves, marine biologist and explorer-photographer David Gruber discovered something amazing -- a surprising new range of sea creatures that glow in many colors in the ocean's dim blue light. Join his journey in search of biofluorescent sharks, seahorses, sea turtles and more, and learn how these light-up creatures could illuminate a new understanding of our own brains.
name: David Gruber: Glow-in-the-dark sharks and other stunning sea creatures
title_vid: Glow-in-the-dark sharks and other stunning sea creatures

title_talk: Finding happiness in body and soul | Eve Ensler
description: Eve Ensler, creator of "The Vagina Monologues," shares how a discussion about menopause with her friends led to talking about all sorts of sexual acts onstage, waging a global campaign to end violence toward women and finding her own happiness.
name: Eve Ensler: Happiness in body and soul
title_vid: Happiness in body and soul

title_talk: Asia's rise -- how and when | Hans Rosling
description: Hans Rosling was a young guest student in India when he first realized that Asia had all the capacities to reclaim its place as the world's dominant economic force. At TEDIndia, he graphs global economic growth since 1858 and predicts the exact date that India and China will outstrip the US.
name: Hans Rosling: Asia's rise -- how and when
title_vid: Asia's rise -- how and when

title_talk: A highly scientific taxonomy of haters | Negin Farsad
description: TED Fellow Negin Farsad weaves comedy and social commentary to cleverly undercut stereotypes of her culture. In this uproarious talk/stand-up hybrid, Farsad speaks on her documentary, The Muslims Are Coming!, narrates her fight with the MTA in New York and offers a detailed breakdown of the different types of haters she's encountered in her work. "Comedy is one of our best weapons," she says. "We've tried a lot of approaches to social justice, like war and competitive ice dancing -- but a lot of things are still kind of awful. I think it's time we try and tell a really good poop joke."
name: Negin Farsad: A highly scientific taxonomy of haters
title_vid: A highly scientific taxonomy of haters

title_talk: Pirates, nurses and other rebel designers | Alice Rawsthorn
description: In this ode to design renegades, Alice Rawsthorn highlights the work of unlikely heroes, from Blackbeard to Florence Nightingale. Drawing a line from these bold thinkers to some early modern visionaries like Buckminster Fuller, Rawsthorn shows how the greatest designers are often the most rebellious.
name: Alice Rawsthorn: Pirates, nurses and other rebel designers
title_vid: Pirates, nurses and other rebel designers

title_talk: A Saudi woman who dared to drive | Manal al-Sharif
description: There's no actual law against women driving in Saudi Arabia. But it's forbidden. Two years ago, Manal al-Sharif decided to encourage women to drive by doing so -- and filming herself for YouTube. Hear her story of what happened next.
name: Manal al-Sharif: A Saudi woman who dared to drive
title_vid: A Saudi woman who dared to drive

title_talk: Paul Kemp-Robertson: Bitcoin. Sweat. Tide. Meet the future of branded currency.
description: Currency -- the bills and coins you carry in your wallet and in your bank account -- is founded on marketing, on the belief that banks and governments are trustworthy. Now, Paul Kemp-Robertson walks us through a new generation of currency, supported by that same marketing ... but on behalf of a private brand. From Nike Sweat Points to bottles of Tide (which are finding an unexpected use in illegal markets), meet the non-bank future of currencies.
name: Paul Kemp-Robertson: Bitcoin. Sweat. Tide. Meet the future of branded currency.
title_vid: Bitcoin. Sweat. Tide. Meet the future of branded currency.

title_talk: 12 truths I learned from life and writing | Anne Lamott
description: A few days before she turned 61, writer Anne Lamott decided to write down everything she knew for sure. She dives into the nuances of being a human who lives in a confusing, beautiful, emotional world, offering her characteristic life-affirming wisdom and humor on family, writing, the meaning of God, death and more.
name: Anne Lamott: 12 truths I learned from life and writing
title_vid: 12 truths I learned from life and writing

title_talk: Kristina Gjerde: Making law on the high seas
description: Kristina Gjerde studies the law of the high seas -- the 64 percent of our ocean that isn't protected by any national law at all. Gorgeous photos show the hidden worlds that Gjerde and other lawyers are working to protect from trawling and trash-dumping, through smart policymaking and a healthy dose of PR.
name: Kristina Gjerde: Making law on the high seas
title_vid: Making law on the high seas

title_talk: Why genetic research must be more diverse | Keolu Fox
description: Ninety-six percent of genome studies are based on people of European descent. The rest of the world is virtually unrepresented -- and this is dangerous, says geneticist and TED Fellow Keolu Fox, because we react to drugs differently based on our genetic makeup. Fox is working to democratize genome sequencing, specifically by advocating for indigenous populations to get involved in research, with the goal of eliminating health disparities. "The research community needs to immerse itself in indigenous culture," he says, "or die trying."
name: Keolu Fox: Why genetic research must be more diverse
title_vid: Why genetic research must be more diverse

title_talk: Katherine Fulton: You are the future of philanthropy
description: In this uplifting talk, Katherine Fulton sketches the new future of philanthropy -- one where collaboration and innovation allow regular people to do big things, even when money is scarce. Giving five practical examples of crowd-driven philanthropy, she calls for a new generation of citizen leaders.
name: Katherine Fulton: You are the future of philanthropy
title_vid: You are the future of philanthropy

title_talk: Ben Saunders: To the South Pole and back — the hardest 105 days of my life
description: This year, explorer Ben Saunders attempted his most ambitious trek yet. He set out to complete Captain Robert Falcon Scott’s failed 1912 polar expedition — a four-month, 1,800-mile round trip journey from the edge of Antarctica to the South Pole and back. In the first talk given after his adventure, just five weeks after his return, Saunders offers a raw, honest look at this “hubris”-tinged mission that brought him to the most difficult decision of his life.
name: Ben Saunders: To the South Pole and back — the hardest 105 days of my life
title_vid: To the South Pole and back — the hardest 105 days of my life

title_talk: Janine Benyus: Biomimicry in action
description: Janine Benyus has a message for inventors: When solving a design problem, look to nature first. There you'll find inspired designs for making things waterproof, aerodynamic, solar-powered and more. Here she reveals dozens of new products that take their cue from nature with spectacular results.
name: Janine Benyus: Biomimicry in action
title_vid: Biomimicry in action

title_talk: The beauty of data visualization | David McCandless
description: David McCandless turns complex data sets (like worldwide military spending, media buzz, Facebook status updates) into beautiful, simple diagrams that tease out unseen patterns and connections. Good design, he suggests, is the best way to navigate information glut -- and it may just change the way we see the world.
name: David McCandless: The beauty of data visualization
title_vid: The beauty of data visualization

title_talk: Jennifer Golbeck: The curly fry conundrum: Why social media "likes" say more than you might think
description: Do you like curly fries? Have you Liked them on Facebook? Watch this talk to find out the surprising things Facebook (and others) can guess about you from your random Likes and Shares. Computer scientist Jennifer Golbeck explains how this came about, how some applications of the technology are not so cute -- and why she thinks we should return the control of information to its rightful owners.
name: Jennifer Golbeck: Your social media "likes" expose more than you think
title_vid: Your social media "likes" expose more than you think

title_talk: Are you a giver or a taker? | Adam Grant
description: In every workplace, there are three basic kinds of people: givers, takers and matchers. Organizational psychologist Adam Grant breaks down these personalities and offers simple strategies to promote a culture of generosity and keep self-serving employees from taking more than their share.
name: Adam Grant: Are you a giver or a taker?
title_vid: Are you a giver or a taker?

title_talk: Why Brexit happened -- and what to do next | Alexander Betts
description: We are embarrassingly unaware of how divided our societies are, and Brexit grew out of a deep, unexamined divide between those that fear globalization and those that embrace it, says social scientist Alexander Betts. How do we now address that fear as well as growing disillusionment with the political establishment, while refusing to give in to xenophobia and nationalism? Join Betts as he discusses four post-Brexit steps toward a more inclusive world.
name: Alexander Betts: Why Brexit happened -- and what to do next
title_vid: Why Brexit happened -- and what to do next

title_talk: Greg Stone: Saving the ocean one island at a time
description: Aboard Mission Blue, scientist Greg Stone tells the story of how he helped the Republic of Kiribati to create an enormous protected area in the middle of the Pacific -- protecting fish, sealife and perhaps the island nation itself.
name: Greg Stone: Saving the ocean one island at a time
title_vid: Saving the ocean one island at a time

title_talk: Chris Burkard: The joy of surfing in ice-cold water
description: "Anything that is worth pursuing is going to require us to suffer, just a little bit," says surf photographer Chris Burkard, as he explains his obsession with the coldest, choppiest, most isolated beaches on earth. With jawdropping photos and stories of places few humans have ever seen -- much less surfed -- he draws us into his "personal crusade against the mundane."
name: Chris Burkard: The joy of surfing in ice-cold water
title_vid: The joy of surfing in ice-cold water

title_talk: Marlene Zuk: What we learn from insects’ kinky sex lives
description: In this enlightening, funny talk, Marlene Zuk shares just some of the ways that insects are truly astonishing -- and not least for the creative ways they have sex.
name: Marlene Zuk: What we learn from insects' sex lives
title_vid: What we learn from insects' sex lives

title_talk: Torsten Reil: Using biology to make better animation
description: NA
name: NA
title_vid: NA

title_talk: Francis de los Reyes: Sanitation is a basic human right
description: Warning: This talk might contain much more than you'd ever want to know about the way the world poops. But as sanitation activist (and TED Fellow) Francis de los Reyes asks — doesn't everyone deserve a safe place to go?
name: Francis de los Reyes: Sanitation is a basic human right
title_vid: Sanitation is a basic human right

title_talk: What will you tell your daughters about 2016? | Chinaka Hodge
description: With words like shards of glass, Chinaka Hodge cuts open 2016 and lets 12 months of violence, grief, fear, shame, courage and hope spill out in this original poem about a year none of us will soon forget.
name: Chinaka Hodge: What will you tell your daughters about 2016?
title_vid: What will you tell your daughters about 2016?

title_talk: A beatboxing lesson from a father-daughter duo | Nicole Paris and Ed Cage
